the darker screw belongs in the screw hole next to the dock connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following three Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear panel: One 1.9 mm screw Two 2.3 mm screws The darker screw belongs in the screw hole next to the dock connector.

Lines.Text: using the tip of a spudger , flip up the control button ribbon cable retaining flap .
be sure you are prying up on the retaining flap , '''not''' the socket itself .
this socket is found under the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the tip of a spudger, flip up the control button ribbon cable retaining flap. Be sure you are prying up on the retaining flap, '''not''' the socket itself. This socket is found under the battery.

Lines.Text: use a pair of tweezers to pull the control button ribbon cable straight out of its socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a pair of tweezers to pull the control button ribbon cable straight out of its socket.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back the protective rubber grommet to reveal a hidden phillips screw .
it is not necessary to completely remove this flap .
remove the hidden phillips screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back the protective rubber grommet to reveal a hidden Phillips screw. It is not necessary to completely remove this flap. Remove the hidden Phillips screw.

Lines.Text: remove the two remaining phillips screws securing the upper logic board to the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two remaining Phillips screws securing the upper logic board to the rear panel.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to separate the wi-fi ribbon cable from the adhesive securing it to the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to separate the Wi-Fi ribbon cable from the adhesive securing it to the rear panel.

Lines.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger between the metal rear panel and wi-fi ribbon cable to further loosen the adhesive along the length of the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger between the metal rear panel and Wi-Fi ribbon cable to further loosen the adhesive along the length of the cable.

Lines.Text: use your hands to continue peeling the wi-fi ribbon off the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your hands to continue peeling the Wi-Fi ribbon off the rear panel.

Lines.Text: pull the small upper portion of the logic board away from the top edge of the touch to separate it from the rear panel .
allow the board to rest on the outside of the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the small upper portion of the logic board away from the top edge of the Touch to separate it from the rear panel. Allow the board to rest on the outside of the rear panel.

Lines.Text: gently pull the lower portion of the logic board away from the bottom edge of the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull the lower portion of the logic board away from the bottom edge of the rear panel.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the logic board assembly out of the rear case , minding any edges that may get caught .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the logic board assembly out of the rear case, minding any edges that may get caught.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips screws securing the power/volume controls to the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips screws securing the power/volume controls to the rear panel.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to remove the yellow kapton tape covering the power/volume control ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to remove the yellow kapton tape covering the power/volume control ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips screws securing the power/volume controls to the rear panel .
lift the power/volume controls out of the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips screws securing the power/volume controls to the rear panel. Lift the power/volume controls out of the rear panel.

Lines.Text: power/volume controls remain .

Steps.Text_raw: Power/Volume controls remain.

Title: iPod Nano 4th Generation Click Wheel Replacement

Lines.Text: insert the edge of an ipod opening tool into the gap between the outer case and the top bezel .
pry the top bezel off the adhesive securing it to the display retainer .
at this point the hold switch slider is free and may fall . be careful not to lose it .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool into the gap between the outer case and the top bezel. Pry the top bezel off the adhesive securing it to the display retainer. At this point the hold switch slider is free and may fall. Be careful not to lose it.

Lines.Text: remove the hold switch slider from the top of the nano .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the hold switch slider from the top of the Nano.

Lines.Text: remove the two angled phillips screws from the two corners of the display retainer .
these screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two angled Phillips screws from the two corners of the display retainer. These screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped.

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool between the outer case and the display retainer .
use the tool to slide the display assembly out of the case slightly .
do not rotate the display retainer about the top edge of the display , as it is attached to a thin steel bracket that is easily broken .
do not forcefully remove the display retainer , as the hold switch cable is liable to snap .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool between the outer case and the display retainer. Use the tool to slide the display assembly out of the case slightly. Do not rotate the display retainer about the top edge of the display, as it is attached to a thin steel bracket that is easily broken. Do not forcefully remove the display retainer, as the hold switch cable is liable to snap.

Lines.Text: slide the display out of the nano . it will move about . 5 until the display data cable limits its travel .
do not put unnecessary tension on the very thin display data cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the display out of the Nano. It will move about .5" until the display data cable limits its travel. Do not put unnecessary tension on the very thin display data cable.

Lines.Text: with the display pulled out of the case as much as possible , gently press on the lower edge of the glass panel until it pops in slightly ( 1 mm ) .
use your thumbs on the lower edge of the glass panel to slide the glass down and into the case until the top edge pops up out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: With the display pulled out of the case as much as possible, gently press on the lower edge of the glass panel until it pops in slightly (~1 mm). Use your thumbs on the lower edge of the glass panel to slide the glass down and into the case until the top edge pops up out of the case.

Lines.Text: lift the glass panel out of the nano .
before reinstalling the glass panel , be sure to clean the face of the display and the inside of the panel as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the nano is turned on .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the glass panel out of the Nano. Before reinstalling the glass panel, be sure to clean the face of the display and the inside of the panel as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the Nano is turned on.

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to separate the hold switch from the adhesive securing it to the top edge of the display .
the hold switch ribbon cable is extremely fragile and easily broken . work gently .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to separate the hold switch from the adhesive securing it to the top edge of the display. The hold switch ribbon cable is extremely fragile and easily broken. Work gently.

Lines.Text: peel back the kapton tape covering the display data cable socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel back the Kapton tape covering the display data cable socket.

Lines.Text: while holding the light colored socket down with one finger , use the tip of a spudger to flip the zif cable lock up toward the bottom of the nano .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the light colored socket down with one finger, use the tip of a spudger to flip the ZIF cable lock up toward the bottom of the Nano.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to peel the display data cable off the thin metal plate attached to the display .
be careful not to rip the display data cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to peel the display data cable off the thin metal plate attached to the display. Be careful not to rip the display data cable.

Lines.Text: pull the display out of the nano , minding the hold switch cable that may get caught .
as you pull the display out of the case , '''be careful not to break the hold switch cable''' .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the display out of the Nano, minding the hold switch cable that may get caught. As you pull the display out of the case, '''be careful not to break the hold switch cable'''.

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool between the bottom bezel and the dock connector .
separate the bottom bezel from the adhesive securing it to the nano and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool between the bottom bezel and the dock connector. Separate the bottom bezel from the adhesive securing it to the Nano and set it aside.

Lines.Text: remove the three phillips screws along the bottom of the nano .
these screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped .
the slightly longer of the three screws belongs in the middle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three Phillips screws along the bottom of the Nano. These screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped. The slightly longer of the three screws belongs in the middle.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to pry the aluminum dock bezel out of the nano .
the dock bezel is very thin cast aluminum . to avoid breaking it , do not excessively flex it during removal .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to pry the aluminum dock bezel out of the Nano. The dock bezel is very thin cast aluminum. To avoid breaking it, do not excessively flex it during removal.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to separate the battery from the adhesive securing it to the outer case .
the lithium polymer battery used in the nano is very flexible . try not to deform it excessively while separating it from the outer case .
use the flat end of a spudger to push the logic board assembly and battery slightly out of the bottom of the nano . stop once it pops out a little bit .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to separate the battery from the adhesive securing it to the outer case. The lithium polymer battery used in the Nano is very flexible. Try not to deform it excessively while separating it from the outer case. Use the flat end of a spudger to push the logic board assembly and battery slightly out of the bottom of the Nano. Stop once it pops out a little bit.

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to peel the click wheel ribbon cable and its zif socket off the dock connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to peel the click wheel ribbon cable and its ZIF socket off the dock connector.

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to flip the zif cable lock up toward the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to flip the ZIF cable lock up toward the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: use a pair of tweezers to slide the click wheel ribbon cable out of its socket .
before proceeding , be sure that '''both''' the '''click wheel ribbon cable socket''' ''and'' '''its cable''' are freed from the adhesive securing them to the dock connector and logic board .
peel back the cable on both ends !

Steps.Text_raw: Use a pair of tweezers to slide the click wheel ribbon cable out of its socket. Before proceeding, be sure that '''both''' the '''click wheel ribbon cable socket''' ''and'' '''its cable''' are freed from the adhesive securing them to the dock connector and logic board. Peel back the cable on both ends!

Lines.Text: pull the logic board assembly out of the outer case , minding the hold switch and click wheel cables that may get caught .

when reassembling , ensure the click wheel cable is toward the front of the nano and not in the grooves on the side . if it is in the groove you will probably cut it while sliding the logic board into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the logic board assembly out of the outer case, minding the hold switch and click wheel cables that may get caught. When reassembling, ensure the click wheel cable is toward the front of the Nano and not in the grooves on the side. If it is in the groove you will probably cut it while sliding the logic board into place.

Lines.Text: press down firmly around the perimeter of the click wheel to separate it from the adhesive securing it to the outer case .
this requires a good amount of force . work slowly .
it may be helpful to use an edged tool to separate the adhesive from the click wheel on the inside of the nano while pressing it down from the outside .
remove the click wheel from the inside of the nano .
be careful not to let the click-wheel slide on the metal plate supporting it , as it will break the flat cable . apply force perpendicular to the click-wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Press down firmly around the perimeter of the click wheel to separate it from the adhesive securing it to the outer case. This requires a good amount of force. Work slowly. It may be helpful to use an edged tool to separate the adhesive from the click wheel on the inside of the Nano while pressing it down from the outside. Remove the click wheel from the inside of the Nano. Be careful not to let the click-wheel slide on the metal plate supporting it, as it will break the flat cable. Apply force perpendicular to the click-wheel.

If it is in the groove you will probably cut it while sliding the logic board into place.

Lines.Text: peel the hold switch cable from along the edge of the battery and lay it aside . the hold switch cable is not attached to the battery .
the battery is held on to the logic board by a strong adhesive . force may be required to remove the battery from the logic board .
pry the battery off the adhesive securing it to the metal tray on the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel the hold switch cable from along the edge of the battery and lay it aside. The hold switch cable is not attached to the battery. The battery is held on to the logic board by a strong adhesive. Force may be required to remove the battery from the logic board. Pry the battery off the adhesive securing it to the metal tray on the logic board.

Lines.Text: the battery on the fourth generation nano is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board . in this step , you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board .
'''do not''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger . shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board .

beware of overheating the board and the cable . only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt . excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable . consider letting the board cool off between melting each solder pad .

start working from one side of the battery ribbon cable . in our case , we started on the left . heat the leftmost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery on the fourth generation nano is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board. In this step, you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board. '''DO NOT''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger. Shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board. Beware of overheating the board and the cable. Only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt. Excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable. Consider letting the board cool off between melting each solder pad. Start working from one side of the battery ribbon cable. In our case, we started on the left. Heat the leftmost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board.

Lines.Text: repeat the previous step for each of the two remaining pads , working either right to left or left to right .
at this point , the battery should be free from the logic board .
lift the old battery out of the nano and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the previous step for each of the two remaining pads, working either right to left or left to right. At this point, the battery should be free from the logic board. Lift the old battery out of the nano and set it aside.

when reassembling , ensure the click wheel cable is toward the front of the nano and not in the grooves on the side . if it is in the groove you will probably cut it while sliding the logic board into place .

Lines.Text: press down firmly around the perimeter of the click wheel to separate it from the adhesive securing it to the outer case .

remove the click wheel from the inside of the nano .
be careful not to let the click-wheel slide on the metal plate supporting it , as it will break the flat cable . apply force perpendicular to the click-wheel .

Title: Microsoft Zune 30 GB Back Case Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the plastic screw cover located on the bottom of the device . insert a small flatheaded screwdriver into one side of the cover and gently ease it out . repeat on the other side .
be gentle when removing the screw cover as it is brittle and will break if forced .
you will need a 00 phillips screwdriver to remove the two 2.6 mm screws that are exposed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic screw cover located on the bottom of the device. Insert a small flat-headed screwdriver into one side of the cover and gently ease it out. Repeat on the other side. Be gentle when removing the screw cover as it is brittle and will break if forced. You will need a #00 Phillips screwdriver to remove the two 2.6 mm screws that are exposed.

Lines.Text: use the blue plastic opening tool to slowly work your way around the edges of the case , releasing the front plate from the bottom case .
be gentle when prying the device open .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the blue plastic opening tool to slowly work your way around the edges of the case, releasing the front plate from the bottom case. Be gentle when prying the device open.

Lines.Text: turn the zune over so the screen faces downward . this will ensure the battery does not fall out and pull on the cable .
the battery is not fastened to the inside of the case . it will fall out .
pry up from the bottom of the zune because the headphone jack will not allow you to remove the back case in one pull . you must slide the case up and away from the rest of the zune .
the case is now separated . you can replace the case , if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the Zune over so the screen faces downward. This will ensure the battery does not fall out and pull on the cable. The battery is not fastened to the inside of the case. It will fall out. Pry up from the bottom of the Zune because the headphone jack will not allow you to remove the back case in one pull.  You must slide the case up and away from the rest of the Zune. The case is now separated. You can replace the case, if needed.

Subject: Back Case

Lines.Text: with the zune facing down , as pictured , the battery ribbon cable is attached to the bottom right hand side of the logic board .
use the small flat head screwdriver to gently lift the brown clamp .
the clamp will release the battery ribbon cable from the logic board , freeing the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: With the Zune facing down, as pictured, the battery ribbon cable is attached to the bottom right hand side of the logic board. Use the small flat head screw driver to gently lift the brown clamp. The clamp will release the battery ribbon cable from the logic board, freeing the battery.

Lines.Text: you can now replace the battery .
the battery is a lithium ion 3.7 v .

Steps.Text_raw: You can now replace the battery. The battery is a Lithium ion 3.7 V.

Lines.Text: now the back cover is off and the battery is removed , so the hard drive is clearly visible .
there are four 4.2 mm screws securing the hard drive to the logic board .
remove all four screws using a phillips 00 screwdriver .
don't lose any of the screws ! if necessary , use a magnetized screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Now the  back cover is off and the battery is removed, so the hard drive is clearly visible. There are four 4.2 mm screws securing the hard drive to the logic board. Remove all four screws using a Phillips #00 screwdriver. Don't lose any of the screws! If necessary, use a magnetized screw driver.

Lines.Text: carefully tilt the hard drive up from the logic board .
do not pull the hard drive all the way off . it is still connected to the logic board by a ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully tilt the hard drive up from the logic board. Do not pull the hard drive all the way off. It is still connected to the logic board by a ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: flip the hard drive over the top to expose the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the hard drive over the top to expose the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: this may be difficult to move , so take your time and be careful .
the ribbon cable is held in place by a black latch on the hard drive .
using a small flat head screwdriver , flip the black latch up 90 degrees .
make sure you are only flipping the black latch . do not try to lift any wires or the white connector piece .

Steps.Text_raw: This may be difficult to move, so take your time and be careful. The ribbon cable is held in place by a black latch on the hard drive. Using a small flat head screwdriver, flip the black latch up 90 degrees. Make sure you are only flipping the black latch. Do not try to lift any wires or the white connector piece.

Lines.Text: carefully detach the ribbon cable from the hard drive .
now you have completely detached the hard drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully detach the ribbon cable from the hard drive. Now you have completely detached the hard drive.

Lines.Text: the ribbon cable for the button sensor pad is attached with a small clamp to the bottom left corner of the logic board .
use a small flathead screwdriver to lift the brown clasp and remove the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: The ribbon cable for the button sensor pad is attached with a small clamp to the bottom left corner of the logic board. Use a small flathead screwdriver to lift the brown clasp and remove the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: with a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the six 4.2 mm screws that attach the logic board to the front plate .

Steps.Text_raw: With a Philips #00 screwdriver, remove the six 4.2 mm screws that attach the logic board to the front plate.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the logic board off of the front plate .
the button pad is free underneath and can fall out . make sure to place it in a secure place .
the logic board is now free .
follow the guide repair guide to detach lcd display from logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the logic board off of the front plate. The button pad is free underneath and can fall out. Make sure to place it in a secure place. The logic board is now free. Follow the [guide|1227|LCD] repair guide to detach LCD display from logic board.

Subject: Logic Board

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger or zune opening tool to remove the small silver plastic cap on top of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger or Zune opening tool to remove the small silver plastic cap on top of the device.

Lines.Text: there are two t4 screws under the cap . remove both with a t4 screwdriver .
be careful removing the screws ; the screw heads can break very easily .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two T4 screws under the cap. Remove both with a T4 screwdriver. Be careful removing the screws; the screw heads can break very easily.

Lines.Text: using a metal spudger or zune opening tool , remove the aluminum backing starting from the top . there are 5 clips on each side and two on the bottom .
be careful not to press the tools in too far ; there are exposed cables right inside the edge of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a metal spudger or Zune opening tool, remove the aluminum backing starting from the top. There are 5 clips on each side and two on the bottom. Be careful not to press the tools in too far; there are exposed cables right inside the edge of the device.

Lines.Text: remove the silver tape from the bottom center and the top right . this allows access to the hard drive and the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the silver tape from the bottom center and the top right. This allows access to the hard drive and the battery.

Lines.Text: unclick the black bar connecting the orange hard drive cable to the bottom of the hard drive . gently push towards the bottom of the device on the black bar until you hear a click sound , it is now disengaged from the hard drive .
if the cable doesn't come off easily , the black bar has not been un-clicked .
now gently pull the orange hard drive cable to remove it from the hard drive .
lift the hard drive from the device .
hard drive replacement only : check to make sure the hard drive cable is in good condition and then connect the new hard drive in the same place , following the steps in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Unclick the black bar connecting the orange hard drive cable to the bottom of the hard drive. Gently push towards the bottom of the device on the black bar until you hear a click sound, it is now disengaged from the hard drive. If the cable doesn't come off easily, the black bar has not been un-clicked. Now gently pull the orange hard drive cable to remove it from the hard drive. Lift the hard drive from the device. Hard Drive Replacement Only:  Check to make sure the hard drive cable is in good condition and then connect the new hard drive in the same place, following the steps in reverse order.

Lines.Text: remove two more pieces of silver tape from the bottom of the device . one of these pieces is below the other .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove two more pieces of silver tape from the bottom of the device. One of these pieces is below the other.

Lines.Text: remove the two t4 screws holding the headphone jack receiver on the top left corner of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two T4 screws holding the headphone jack receiver on the top left corner of the device.

Lines.Text: remove the two t4 screws holding the metal brackets on both sides of the bottom of the device .
remove the screws , brackets , and clips from the device . these are small pieces , so put them in a safe place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two T4 screws holding the metal brackets on both sides of the bottom of the device. Remove the screws, brackets, and clips from the device. These are small pieces, so put them in a safe place.

Lines.Text: the orange audio board cable is clipped in with a small black bar , same as the hard drive cable . un-clip the bar by pushing upwards on the edge of the black bar towards the orange cable . you will hear it click when is disengages .
warning : if the cable doesn't come off easily , the black bar has not been un-clicked .

Steps.Text_raw: The orange audio board cable is clipped in with a small black bar, same as the hard drive cable. Un-clip the bar by pushing upwards on the edge of the black bar towards the orange cable. You will hear it click when is disengages. WARNING: If the cable doesn't come off easily, the black bar has not been un-clicked.

Lines.Text: flip the black bar to unclip the left side of the hard drive cable . you can now remove the hard drive cable .
warning : if the cable doesn't come off easily , the black bar has not been un-clicked .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the black bar to unclip the left side of the hard drive cable. You can now remove the hard drive cable. WARNING: If the cable doesn't come off easily, the black bar has not been un-clicked.

Lines.Text: remove the two t4 screws that hold the charging port on the bottom of the device .
remove the charging port .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two T4 screws that hold the charging port on the bottom of the device. Remove the charging port.

Lines.Text: remove the battery from the device with the cables still connected .
carefully lift up the mother board located at the base of the zune . unclip the orange ribbon cable in the same manner as in the previous steps .
remove the mother board from the zune , leaving the black wire connected .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery from the device with the cables still connected. Carefully lift up the mother board located at the base of the Zune. Unclip the orange ribbon cable in the same manner as in the previous steps. Remove the mother board from the Zune, leaving the black wire connected.

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger or zune opening tool to remove the small silver plastic cap on top of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger or Zune opening tool to remove the small silver plastic cap on top of the device.

Lines.Text: there are two t4 screws under the cap . remove both with a t4 screwdriver .
be careful removing the screws ; the screw heads can break very easily .

be careful not to press the tools in too far ; there are exposed cables right inside the edge of the device .

Lines.Text: insert the edge of a zune opening tool between the black lower bezel and the front case .
pry the lower bezel up off the front case and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of a Zune opening tool between the black lower bezel and the front case. Pry the lower bezel up off the front case and set it aside.

Lines.Text: lift the upper bezel off the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the upper bezel off the front case.

Lines.Text: remove the single t5 torx screw securing the front case to the inner chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single T5 Torx screw securing the front case to the inner chassis.

Lines.Text: use a zune opening tool to peel the digitizer and display ribbon cables off the foam tape securing them to the inner chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Zune opening tool to peel the digitizer and display ribbon cables off the foam tape securing them to the inner chassis.

Lines.Text: use a zune opening tool to gently lift the media button lever off the post cast into the inner chassis .
try not excessively rotate the media button lever about this post .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Zune opening tool to gently lift the media button lever off the post cast into the inner chassis. Try not excessively rotate the media button lever about this post.

Lines.Text: the inner chassis attaches to the front case by several clips around its perimeter ( shown in red ) . the clips emanating from the front case are plastic and inherently delicate , so work carefully .

the five plastic clips along the side of the zune lock onto small aluminum tabs cast into the inner chassis . to separate these clips , the plastic portion must be pushed toward the inside of the zune while prying the inner chassis up off the front case .

the two plastic clips attached to the front case along the top edge of the zune ( second picture ) simply clip onto the inner chassis . to separate the top edge , carefully push each clip away from the inside of the zune while prying the inner chassis off the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: The inner chassis attaches to the front case by several clips around its perimeter (shown in red). The clips emanating from the front case are plastic and inherently delicate, so work carefully. The five plastic clips along the side of the Zune lock onto small aluminum tabs cast into the inner chassis. To separate these clips, the plastic portion must be pushed toward the inside of the Zune while prying the inner chassis up off the front case. The two plastic clips attached to the front case along the top edge of the Zune (second picture) simply clip onto the inner chassis. To separate the top edge, carefully push each clip away from the inside of the Zune while prying the inner chassis off the front case.

Lines.Text: this job can be completed alone , but we used a second set of hands for picture taking purposes .

use a zune opening tool to gently pry the inner chassis off the front case while simultaneously using another zune opening tool to push the plastic clip near the control cable connector toward the inside of the zune .
work your way along the media button side of the zune to separate both clips securing the front case to the inner chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: This job can be completed alone, but we used a second set of hands for picture taking purposes. Use a Zune opening tool to gently pry the inner chassis off the front case while simultaneously using another Zune opening tool to push the plastic clip near the control cable connector toward the inside of the Zune. Work your way along the media button side of the Zune to separate both clips securing the front case to the inner chassis.

Lines.Text: use a zune opening tool to very carefully bend both plastic clips along the top edge of the zune away from the inner chassis while simultaneously prying the respective side of the inner chassis up off the front case .
once the top edge of the inner chassis has been released from the front case , separate the clips along the right edge of the zune .
lift the inner chassis off the front case , minding the digitizer and display ribbon cables routed through a slot near its center .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Zune opening tool to very carefully bend both plastic clips along the top edge of the Zune away from the inner chassis while simultaneously prying the respective side of the inner chassis up off the front case. Once the top edge of the inner chassis has been released from the front case, separate the clips along the right edge of the Zune. Lift the inner chassis off the front case, minding the digitizer and display ribbon cables routed through a slot near its center.

Lines.Text: carefully insert the edge of a zune opening tool between the oled display panel and the inner chassis near its top edge .
carefully pry the top edge of the oled display panel off the foam tape securing it to the inner chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully insert the edge of a Zune opening tool between the OLED display panel and the inner chassis near its top edge. Carefully pry the top edge of the OLED display panel off the foam tape securing it to the inner chassis.

Lines.Text: insert the edge of your zune opening tool between the left side of the oled display panel and the inner chassis .
carefully pry the oled display off the foam tape securing it to the inner chassis .
at this point , the oled display should be lifted enough to completely separate it from the inner chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of your Zune opening tool between the left side of the OLED display panel and the inner chassis. Carefully pry the OLED display off the foam tape securing it to the inner chassis. At this point, the OLED display should be lifted enough to completely separate it from the inner chassis.

Lines.Text: carefully de-route the display data cable through the inner chassis and remove the oled display .

be sure both the face of the oled display and the inner side of the digitizer are perfectly clean before reassembly , as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the zune is turned on .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully de-route the display data cable through the inner chassis and remove the OLED display. Be sure both the face of the OLED display and the inner side of the digitizer are perfectly clean before reassembly, as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the Zune is turned on.

Subject: OLED Display

Subject: Inner Chassis

Lines.Text: insert the edge of an ipod opening tool into the gap between the outer case and the top bezel .
pry the top bezel off the adhesive securing it to the display retainer .
at this point the hold switch slider is free and may fall . be careful not to lose it .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool into the gap between the outer case and the top bezel. Pry the top bezel off the adhesive securing it to the display retainer. At this point the hold switch slider is free and may fall. Be careful not to lose it.

Lines.Text: remove the hold switch slider from the top of the nano .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the hold switch slider from the top of the Nano.

Lines.Text: remove the two angled phillips screws from the two corners of the display retainer .
these screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two angled Phillips screws from the two corners of the display retainer. These screw heads are extremely small and easily stripped.

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool between the outer case and the display retainer .
use the tool to slide the display assembly out of the case slightly .
do not rotate the display retainer about the top edge of the display , as it is attached to a thin steel bracket that is easily broken .
do not forcefully remove the display retainer , as the hold switch cable is liable to snap .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool between the outer case and the display retainer. Use the tool to slide the display assembly out of the case slightly. Do not rotate the display retainer about the top edge of the display, as it is attached to a thin steel bracket that is easily broken. Do not forcefully remove the display retainer, as the hold switch cable is liable to snap.

Lines.Text: slide the display out of the nano . it will move about . 5 until the display data cable limits its travel .
do not put unnecessary tension on the very thin display data cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the display out of the Nano. It will move about .5" until the display data cable limits its travel. Do not put unnecessary tension on the very thin display data cable.

Lines.Text: with the display pulled out of the case as much as possible , gently press on the lower edge of the glass panel until it pops in slightly ( 1 mm ) .
use your thumbs on the lower edge of the glass panel to slide the glass down and into the case until the top edge pops up out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: With the display pulled out of the case as much as possible, gently press on the lower edge of the glass panel until it pops in slightly (~1 mm). Use your thumbs on the lower edge of the glass panel to slide the glass down and into the case until the top edge pops up out of the case.

Lines.Text: lift the glass panel out of the nano .
before reinstalling the glass panel , be sure to clean the face of the display and the inside of the panel as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the nano is turned on .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the glass panel out of the Nano. Before reinstalling the glass panel, be sure to clean the face of the display and the inside of the panel as any dust or fingerprints will be annoyingly visible when the Nano is turned on.

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to separate the hold switch from the adhesive securing it to the top edge of the display .
the hold switch ribbon cable is extremely fragile and easily broken . work gently .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to separate the hold switch from the adhesive securing it to the top edge of the display. The hold switch ribbon cable is extremely fragile and easily broken. Work gently.

Lines.Text: peel back the kapton tape covering the display data cable socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel back the Kapton tape covering the display data cable socket.

Lines.Text: while holding the light colored socket down with one finger , use the tip of a spudger to flip the zif cable lock up toward the bottom of the nano .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the light colored socket down with one finger, use the tip of a spudger to flip the ZIF cable lock up toward the bottom of the Nano.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to peel the display data cable off the thin metal plate attached to the display .
be careful not to rip the display data cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to peel the display data cable off the thin metal plate attached to the display. Be careful not to rip the display data cable.

Lines.Text: pull the display out of the nano , minding the hold switch cable that may get caught .
as you pull the display out of the case , '''be careful not to break the hold switch cable''' .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the display out of the Nano, minding the hold switch cable that may get caught. As you pull the display out of the case, '''be careful not to break the hold switch cable'''.

Lines.Text: if present , remove the strip of tape covering the display electronics .

Steps.Text_raw: If present, remove the strip of tape covering the display electronics.

Lines.Text: the display bracket is attached to the display by a strip of adhesive around its perimeter .
use the edge of an ipod opening tool to carefully pry the display bracket off the rear of the display .
continue separating the display bracket along the side of the display .

Steps.Text_raw: The display bracket is attached to the display by a strip of adhesive around its perimeter. Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to carefully pry the display bracket off the rear of the display. Continue separating the display bracket along the side of the display.

Lines.Text: separate the display bracket from the other side of the display .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the display bracket from the other side of the display.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to carefully peel the display electronics off the display bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to carefully peel the display electronics off the display bracket.

Lines.Text: remove the display from the display bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the display from the display bracket.

Title: iPod Nano 5th Generation Click Wheel Replacement

Lines.Text: use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the plastic bezel at the bottom of the ipod .
use a low heat setting and do not hold the heat gun in place for too long to avoid melting the plastic bezel .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the bezel from the case of the ipod and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the plastic bezel at the bottom of the iPod. Use a low heat setting and do not hold the heat gun in place for too long to avoid melting the plastic bezel. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the bezel from the case of the iPod and remove it.

Lines.Text: unscrew two screws from the metal retainer at the bottom of the ipod :
4.4 mm angled phillips screw
5.4 mm phillips screw .
even if they are loose , the screws may not come out on their own . be sure not to lose the screws when removing the retainer .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the metal retainer out from the bottom of the ipod and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew two screws from the metal retainer at the bottom of the iPod: 4.4 mm angled Phillips screw 5.4 mm Phillips screw. Even if they are loose, the screws may not come out on their own. Be sure not to lose the screws when removing the retainer. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the metal retainer out from the bottom of the iPod and remove it.

Lines.Text: insert a metal spudger into the slot at the bottom of the ipod just above the dock connector .
use the metal spudger to pry up the bottom edge of the click wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a metal spudger into the slot at the bottom of the iPod just above the dock connector. Use the metal spudger to pry up the bottom edge of the click wheel.

Lines.Text: place a guitar pick between the click wheel and the case of the nano and remove the metal spudger .
pry up the edges of the click wheel with the guitar pick until the click wheel comes free from the case .
do not try to completely remove the click wheel yet , as it is still held in place by a ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Place a guitar pick between the click wheel and the case of the Nano and remove the metal spudger. Pry up the edges of the click wheel with the guitar pick until the click wheel comes free from the case. Do not try to completely remove the click wheel yet, as it is still held in place by a ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: lift the click wheel out of the way with one hand and use a plastic opening tool to pry the click wheel ribbon cable connector off its socket on the logic board .
remove the click wheel .

Title: iPod Nano 5th Generation Glass Panel Replacement

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool between the outer case and top bezel near the screen .
lifting up on the ipod opening tool , gently pry the top panel off of the device .
the bezel is attached with adhesive , and may require some force to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool between the outer case and top bezel near the screen. Lifting up on the iPod opening tool, gently pry the top panel off of the device. The bezel is attached with adhesive, and may require some force to remove.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to pry the hold switch button off of the hold switch plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to pry the hold switch button off of the hold switch plate.

Lines.Text: remove the two 3.2 mm screws .
these screws are angled toward the outer case and are also very small . use a sharp screwdriver and be careful not to strip the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 3.2 mm screws. These screws are angled toward the outer case and are also very small. Use a sharp screwdriver and be careful not to strip the screws.

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool between the outer case and the metal hold switch plate near the top of the screen .
while slightly lifting up on the ipod opening tool , pull the hold switch plate out of the ipod .
the hold switch plate is still attached to ipod by a very thin , very fragile ribbon cable . be careful not to break it .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool between the outer case and the metal hold switch plate near the top of the screen . While slightly lifting up on the iPod opening tool, pull the hold switch plate out of the iPod. The hold switch plate is still attached to iPod by a very thin, very fragile ribbon cable. Be careful not to break it.

Lines.Text: the glass panel is held in place by adhesive on all four sides . in the following steps , work carefully to avoid cracking the glass .
insert an ipod opening tool between the display and the glass panel at the top of the device .
rotate the ipod opening tool towards the rear of the device , slightly lifting the top of the glass out of the outer case .
the glass panel does not raise very far . do not attempt to completely remove the panel yet , or you are likely to break the display screen .

Steps.Text_raw: The glass panel is held in place by adhesive on all four sides. In the following steps, work carefully to avoid cracking the glass. Insert an iPod opening tool between the display and the glass panel at the top of the device. Rotate the iPod opening tool towards the rear of the device, slightly lifting the top of the glass out of the outer case. The glass panel does not raise very far. Do not attempt to completely remove the panel yet, or you are likely to break the display screen.

Lines.Text: while lifting the screen up with one ipod opening tool , insert a second ipod opening tool in between the outer case and the top left edge of the glass panel .
remove the first ipod opening tool from between the glass and lcd in the top of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: While lifting the screen up with one iPod opening tool, insert a second iPod opening tool in between the outer case and the top left edge of the glass panel. Remove the first iPod opening tool from between the glass and LCD in the top of the device.

Lines.Text: prying up slightly on the ipod opening tool , insert a second ipod opening tool in between the front glass and the outer case , on the right side of the screen .
slide the second ipod opening tool along the right edge of the panel to remove the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Prying up slightly on the iPod opening tool, insert a second iPod opening tool in between the front glass and the outer case, on the right side of the screen. Slide the second iPod opening tool along the right edge of the panel to remove the adhesive.

Lines.Text: with one ipod opening tool still between the glass and outer case , insert a second ipod opening tool inbetween the front glass and outer case , on the right side .
slide the second ipod opening tool toward the bottom of the device to remove the adhesive .

Title: iPod Nano 5th Generation Click Wheel Replacement

Lines.Text: use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the plastic bezel at the bottom of the ipod .
use a low heat setting and do not hold the heat gun in place for too long to avoid melting the plastic bezel .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the bezel from the case of the ipod and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the plastic bezel at the bottom of the iPod. Use a low heat setting and do not hold the heat gun in place for too long to avoid melting the plastic bezel. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the bezel from the case of the iPod and remove it.

Lines.Text: unscrew three screws from the bottom of the ipod :
two 4.4 mm angled phillips screws
one 5.4 mm phillips screw .
these screws may not come out on their own , so be sure not to lose them when removing the retainer .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the metal retainer out from the bottom of the ipod and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew three screws from the bottom of the iPod: Two 4.4 mm angled Phillips screws One 5.4 mm Phillips screw. These screws may not come out on their own, so be sure not to lose them when removing the retainer. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the metal retainer out from the bottom of the iPod and remove it.

Lines.Text: insert a metal spudger into the slot at the bottom of the ipod just above the dock connector .
use the metal spudger to pry up the bottom edge of the click wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a metal spudger into the slot at the bottom of the iPod just above the dock connector. Use the metal spudger to pry up the bottom edge of the click wheel.

Lines.Text: place a guitar pick between the click wheel and the case of the nano and remove the metal spudger .
pry up the edges of the click wheel with the guitar pick until the click wheel comes free from the case .
do not try to completely remove the click wheel yet , as it is still held in place by a ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Place a guitar pick between the click wheel and the case of the Nano and remove the metal spudger. Pry up the edges of the click wheel with the guitar pick until the click wheel comes free from the case. Do not try to completely remove the click wheel yet, as it is still held in place by a ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: lift the click wheel out of the way with one hand and use a plastic opening tool to pry the click wheel ribbon cable connector off its socket on the logic board .
remove the click wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the click wheel out of the way with one hand and use a plastic opening tool to pry the click wheel ribbon cable connector off its socket on the logic board. Remove the click wheel.

Lines.Text: use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the camera/microphone cover .
pry the camera/microphone cover off the case with a metal spudger and remove it .
it is extremely difficult , if not impossible , to avoid damaging the ipod case near the camera . while this will not affect the ipod's functionality , it will hurt its cosmetic appearance .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the camera/microphone cover. Pry the camera/microphone cover off the case with a metal spudger and remove it. It is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to avoid damaging the iPod case near the camera. While this will not affect the iPod's functionality, it will hurt its cosmetic appearance.

Lines.Text: from the top of the ipod , insert a metal spudger between the outer case and the battery to remove the adhesive that holds the battery in place .
be extremely careful not to poke or puncture the battery itself , as this may cause the battery to combust .

Steps.Text_raw: From the top of the iPod, insert a metal spudger between the outer case and the battery to remove the adhesive that holds the battery in place. Be extremely careful not to poke or puncture the battery itself, as this may cause the battery to combust.

Lines.Text: there is a small white retainer between the camera and microphone that keeps the inner components from sliding around .
insert a push pin into the hole at the corner of the retainer and lift it out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a small white retainer between the camera and microphone that keeps the inner components from sliding around. Insert a push pin into the hole at the corner of the retainer and lift it out of the case.

Lines.Text: once the retainer has been pushed past its hole in the outer case , the spudger used to depress it is no longer necessary .
using gentle but steady force , push on the top of the lcd to slide the logic board assembly out of the bottom of the ipod .
do not push on the battery , as this may puncture it and cause it to combust .
constantly mind the hold switch plate , making sure it doesn't snag on an edge and tear the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the retainer has been pushed past its hole in the outer case, the spudger used to depress it is no longer necessary. Using gentle but steady force, push on the top of the LCD to slide the logic board assembly out of the bottom of the iPod. Do not push on the battery, as this may puncture it and cause it to combust. Constantly mind the hold switch plate, making sure it doesn't snag on an edge and tear the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: continue to push the logic board assembly through the outer case of the ipod with a spudger .
tolerances inside the nano are extremely tight . be very patient and go slowly when removing the logic board assembly , and make sure no components or ribbon cables get caught on the case .
to make sure that the hold switch plate does not catch on the housing of the ipod and tear the cable , feed the switch straight down the center of the device , where the opening is the widest .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue to push the logic board assembly through the outer case of the iPod with a spudger. Tolerances inside the Nano are extremely tight. Be very patient and go slowly when removing the logic board assembly, and make sure no components or ribbon cables get caught on the case. To make sure that the hold switch plate does not catch on the housing of the iPod and tear the cable, feed the switch straight down the center of the device, where the opening is the widest.

Lines.Text: once the top of the lcd has cleared the bottom edge of the outer case , remove the logic board assembly from the body of the ipod .
again , be sure to mind the hold switch plate , that it doesn't catch on the bottom of the click wheel hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the top of the LCD has cleared the bottom edge of the outer case, remove the logic board assembly from the body of the iPod. Again, be sure to mind the hold switch plate, that it doesn't catch on the bottom of the click wheel hole.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to carefully lift the battery off the back of the lcd , starting at the top of the lcd .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to carefully lift the battery off the back of the LCD, starting at the top of the LCD.

Lines.Text: turn the battery over so the orange hold button ribbon cable is visible along the underside of the battery .
peel the hold button ribbon off the battery .
the delicate ribbon cable is held in place by adhesive . work slowly , taking care not to tear the ribbon .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the battery over so the orange hold button ribbon cable is visible along the underside of the battery. Peel the hold button ribbon off the battery. The delicate ribbon cable is held in place by adhesive. Work slowly, taking care not to tear the ribbon.

Lines.Text: use a pair of tweezers to remove the orange tape that covers the three solder connections for the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a pair of tweezers to remove the orange tape that covers the three solder connections for the battery.

Lines.Text: the battery on the nano is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board . in this step , you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board .
'''do not''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger . shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board .

beware of overheating the board and the cable . only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt . excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable .
start working from the right side of the battery ribbon cable . heat the rightmost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery on the Nano is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board. In this step, you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board. '''DO NOT''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger. Shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board. Beware of overheating the board and the cable. Only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt. Excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable. Start working from the right side of the battery ribbon cable. Heat the rightmost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board.

Lines.Text: repeat the previous step for the two remaining solder pads , working from right to left .
once the three connections have been desoldered , lift the old battery off the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the previous step for the two remaining solder pads, working from right to left. Once the three connections have been desoldered, lift the old battery off the logic board.

Lines.Text: the glass panel is held in place by adhesive on all four sides . in the following steps , work carefully to avoid cracking the glass .

rotate the ipod opening tool towards the rear of the device , slightly lifting the top of the glass out of the outer case .
the glass panel does not raise very far . do not attempt to completely remove the panel yet , or you are likely to break the display screen .

it is extremely difficult , if not impossible , to avoid damaging the ipod case near the camera . while this will not affect the ipod's functionality , it will hurt its cosmetic appearance .

do not push on the battery , as this may puncture it and cause it to combust .
constantly mind the hold switch plate , making sure it doesn't snag on an edge and tear the ribbon cable .

Lines.Text: lift the bottom of the rear case and remove it from the rest of the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the bottom of the rear case and remove it from the rest of the iPod.

Lines.Text: disconnect the headphone jack and shuffle switch connector by prying it off the logic board with a spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the headphone jack and shuffle switch connector by prying it off the logic board with a spudger.

Lines.Text: remove the single phillips screw securing the logic board to the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single Phillips screw securing the logic board to the front case.

remove the logic board and battery from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel the battery up from the front case with an iPod opening tool. Remove the logic board and battery from the iPod.

Lines.Text: pry the headphone jack from the front case with an ipod opening tool .
don't attempt to remove the headphone jack yet , it is connected to the shuffle switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry the headphone jack from the front case with an iPod opening tool. Don't attempt to remove the headphone jack yet, it is connected to the shuffle switch.

Lines.Text: using the pointed tip of a spudger , push the shuffle switch in to separate it from the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the pointed tip of a spudger, push the shuffle switch in to separate it from the front case.

Lines.Text: remove the headphone jack and shuffle switch from the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the headphone jack and shuffle switch from the front case.

Lines.Text: widen the small gap between the front and rear case by inserting a metal spudger into the gap near the top of the ipod .
be careful when using a metal spudger , as you may scratch the outer case .

Steps.Text_raw: Widen the small gap between the front and rear case by inserting a metal spudger into the gap near the top of the iPod. Be careful when using a metal spudger, as you may scratch the outer case.

Lines.Text: insert an ipod opening tool into the newly widened gap , and pry the rear case up and away from the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert an iPod opening tool into the newly widened gap, and pry the rear case up and away from the front case.

Lines.Text: insert the ipod shuffle opening tool into the gap between the front and rear case on the same side , at the bottom corner of the ipod .
pry the rear case away from the front case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the iPod Shuffle opening tool into the gap between the front and rear case on the same side, at the bottom corner of the iPod. Pry the rear case away from the front case.

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the bottom of the rear case and remove it from the rest of the iPod.

Lines.Text: disconnect the headphone jack and shuffle switch connector by prying it off the logic board with a spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the headphone jack and shuffle switch connector by prying it off the logic board with a spudger.
