remove the four 1.5 mm screws on the back of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling the device, make sure it is powered off. Remove the four 1.5mm screws on the back of the device.

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , lift the metal backing from the front of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, lift the metal backing from the front of the device.

Lines.Text: pull the rear panel off of the sansa e260 r .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the rear panel off of the Sansa e260R.

Lines.Text: grip the bottom of the battery with your thumb and forefinger and pull it away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the bottom of the battery with your thumb and forefinger and pull it away from the device.

Lines.Text: remove the four 1.5 mm screws on the inner casing of the device .
these screws are very small and hard to extract from the casing . it may be helpful to use a magnetic screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 1.5mm screws on the inner casing of the device. These screws are very small and hard to extract from the casing.  It may be helpful to use a magnetic screwdriver.

Lines.Text: flip the device so that the front is facing you .
slide a plastic opening tool between the plastic front cover and the metal back cover of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device so that the front is facing you. Slide a plastic opening tool between the plastic front cover and the metal back cover of the device.

Lines.Text: pull the front cover away from the rest of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the front cover away from the rest of the device.

Lines.Text: near the charging port , pull the case away from the motherboard to create clearance to remove the motherboard .
use the spudger to push the motherboard in and pop the metal edge of the charging port up and inside the plastic case .

Steps.Text_raw: Near the charging port, pull the case away from the motherboard to create clearance to remove the motherboard. Use the spudger to push the motherboard in and pop the metal edge of the charging port up and inside the plastic case.

Lines.Text: pull the bottom of the motherboard up and then out .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the bottom of the motherboard up and then out.

Lines.Text: on the back of the motherboard , there is a rectangle of rubber .
peel the rectangle off slowly .

Steps.Text_raw: On the back of the motherboard, there is a rectangle of rubber. Peel the rectangle off slowly.

Lines.Text: under the rubber rectangle , there is a strip of black tape .
peel the tape off about halfway so that it is no longer attached to the memory board .

Steps.Text_raw: Under the rubber rectangle, there is a strip of black tape. Peel the tape off about halfway so that it is no longer attached to the memory board.

Lines.Text: carefully peel the memory board away from the rest of the motherboard

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully peel the memory board away from the rest of the motherboard

Lines.Text: before disassembling the device , make sure it is powered off .
remove the four 1.5 mm screws on the back of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling the device, make sure it is powered off. Remove the four 1.5mm screws on the back of the device.

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , lift the metal backing from the front of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, lift the metal backing from the front of the device.

Lines.Text: pull the rear panel off of the sansa e260 r .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the rear panel off of the Sansa e260R.

Lines.Text: grip the bottom of the battery with your thumb and forefinger and pull it away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the bottom of the battery with your thumb and forefinger and pull it away from the device.

Title: Creative Nomad II Headphone Jack Replacement

Lines.Text: using your thumb , slide down and remove the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your thumb, slide down and remove the battery cover.

Lines.Text: using your index finger , remove the old aa battery .
install the new aa battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your index finger, remove the old AA battery. Install the new AA battery.

Lines.Text: slide down the eject button .
pull out the old smartmedia card .
insert the new smartmedia card .
the notched corner of the smartmedia card should go in the top left corner .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide down the eject button. Pull out the old SmartMedia Card. Insert the new SmartMedia Card. The notched corner of the SmartMedia card should go in the top left corner.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 7.5 mm screws located on the left and right side of the back cover , respectively .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 7.5 mm screws located on the left and right side of the back cover, respectively.

Lines.Text: remove the back cover of the nomad ii .
remove the following items located on the left and right side of the device :
the rubber usb port cover
the plastic lock/unlock switch cover
the buttons located on the left side of the device

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back cover of the Nomad II. Remove the following items located on the left and right side of the device: The rubber USB port cover The plastic lock/unlock switch cover The buttons located on the left side of the device

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 5.5 mm screws located in the bottom corners of the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 5.5 mm screws located in the bottom corners of the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: using your fingers , carefully remove the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your fingers, carefully remove the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 5.5 mm screws located on the left and right edges of the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 5.5 mm screws located on the left and right edges of the circuit board.

Lines.Text: using a pair of tweezers , carefully remove the metal loop attached to the circuit board from its plastic case on the left side of the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pair of tweezers, carefully remove the metal loop attached to the circuit board from its plastic case on the left side of the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: pull out the circuit boards .
when reinserting the circuit boards , press the front face of the boards into the device case until you hear a click .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the circuit boards. When reinserting the circuit boards, press the front face of the boards into the device case until you hear a click.

Lines.Text: position the circuit boards with the usb port facing up .
gently separate the circuit boards .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the circuit boards with the USB port facing up. Gently separate the circuit boards.

Lines.Text: using a pair of tweezers , gently lift and peel back the thin copper film covering the headphone jack .
only peel back the film enough to expose the headphone jack .
completely removing the copper film can damage the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pair of tweezers, gently lift and peel back the thin copper film covering the headphone jack. Only peel back the film enough to expose the headphone jack. Completely removing the copper film can damage the device.

Lines.Text: gently remove the black adhesive tape from the underside of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently remove the black adhesive tape from the underside of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: desolder the four solder joints securing the headphone jack .
remove the old headphone jack .
install the new headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the four solder joints securing the headphone jack. Remove the old headphone jack. Install the new headphone jack.

Subject: Headphone Jack

Title: Creative Nomad II Lock/Unlock Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: using your thumb , slide down and remove the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your thumb, slide down and remove the battery cover.

Lines.Text: using your index finger , remove the old aa battery .
install the new aa battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your index finger, remove the old AA battery. Install the new AA battery.

Lines.Text: slide down the eject button .
pull out the old smartmedia card .
insert the new smartmedia card .
the notched corner of the smartmedia card should go in the top left corner .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide down the eject button. Pull out the old SmartMedia Card. Insert the new SmartMedia Card. The notched corner of the SmartMedia card should go in the top left corner.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 7.5 mm screws from the sides of the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 7.5mm screws from the sides of the back cover.

Lines.Text: lift the back cover off of the nomad ii .
remove the rubber usb port cover , the connected buttons along the left edge , and the plastic lock/unlock button on the upper right edge of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the back cover off of the NOMAD II. Remove the rubber USB port cover, the connected buttons along the left edge, and the plastic lock/unlock button on the upper right edge of the device.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 5.5 mm screws from the sides of the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 5.5mm screws from the sides of the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the two 5.5 mm screws on the left and right edges of the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #00 Screwdriver, remove the two 5.5mm screws on the left and right edges of the circuit board.

Lines.Text: using a pair of tweezers , carefully pry the metal loop on the left side of the battery compartment away from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pair of tweezers, carefully pry the metal loop on the left side of the battery compartment away from the case.

Lines.Text: pull the circuit boards out of the back cover .
during reinstallation , firmly press the top of the circuit boards into the cover until you hear a click .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the circuit boards out of the back cover. During reinstallation, firmly press the top of the circuit boards into the cover until you hear a click.

Lines.Text: gently pry the circuit boards apart .
this must be done with the usb port facing up , as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pry the circuit boards apart. This must be done with the USB port facing up, as shown.

Lines.Text: desolder the seven solder joints which hold the lock switch in place .
install the new lock/unlock switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the seven solder joints which hold the lock switch in place. Install the new lock/unlock switch.

Subject: Lock/Unlock Switch

Lines.Text: remove the battery ( which also functions as the back cover ) from the device . this step is not explicitly shown , but a picture without the battery cover shows the device post-battery removal .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery (which also functions as the back cover) from the device. This step is not explicitly shown, but a picture without the battery cover shows the device post-battery removal.

Lines.Text: use a phillip's head screwdriver to remove the screws from the case .
place the screws in a small container to avoid losing them .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Philip's head screw driver to remove the screws from the case. Place the screws in a small container to avoid losing them.

Lines.Text: remove the front cover .
first , insert a small pry bar where the black front cover and white back cover meet .
begin prying the black plastic up , slowing moving around to the bottom and other side .
at an angle , carefully pull up on the front cover separate the two pieces .
excellent ! now you have removed the front cover !

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the front cover. First, insert a small pry bar where the black front cover and white back cover meet. Begin prying the black plastic up, slowing moving around to the bottom and other side. At an angle, carefully pull up on the front cover separate the two pieces. Excellent! Now you have removed the front cover!

Lines.Text: while looking down at the device , place your index finger at the top of the circuit board and your thumb on the device screen .

Steps.Text_raw: While looking down at the device, place your index finger at the top of the circuit board and your thumb on the device screen.

Lines.Text: using your fingers , gently pull the top of the circuit board up toward you while also sliding the bottom of the circuit board away from the bottom of the sirius stiletto 100 back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your fingers, gently pull the top of the circuit board up toward you while also sliding the bottom of the circuit board away from the bottom of the Sirius Stiletto 100 back cover.

Lines.Text: congratulations ! you have successfully removed the internal circuit board from the sirius stiletto 100 back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Congratulations! You have successfully removed the internal circuit board from the Sirius Stiletto 100 back cover.

Lines.Text: locate the power button on the side of the device ( the power button is circled in orange in the photograph ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the power button on the side of the device (the power button is circled in orange in the photograph).

Lines.Text: turn the case so that you can see the other side of the power button ( so that you are looking at it from inside the device ) . the power button is indicated by an orange circle in the photograph .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the case so that you can see the other side of the power button (so that you are looking at  it from "inside" the device).  The power button is indicated by an orange circle in the photograph.

Lines.Text: grasping the button as shown , slide the power button all the way to the right .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the button as shown, slide the power button all the way to the right.

Lines.Text: push upwards with your thumb to lift the left side of the button over the plastic ridge .
if the button hits the plastic ridge as you push upwards , try pushing it to the right with your index finger as you push upwards with your thumb .

Steps.Text_raw: Push upwards with your thumb to lift the left side of the button over the plastic ridge. If the button hits the plastic ridge as you push upwards, try pushing it to the right with your index finger as you push upwards with your thumb.

Lines.Text: remove the power button by sliding the power button to the left , over the plastic ridge .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the power button by sliding the power button to the left, over the plastic ridge.

Lines.Text: place the new power button in the slot so that the right end of the power button is under the plastic ridge on the right and the left end of the power button is on top of the plastic ridge on the left .

make sure the power button is oriented the same way as the slot . the bottom left corner of the power button should stick out more than the top left corner , and the top right corner should stick out more than the bottom right corner . a simple way to check this is to held the power button in place and look at the side of the device ( from the outside of the device ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the new power button in the slot so that the right end of the power button is under the plastic ridge on the right and the left end of the power button is on top of the plastic ridge on the left. Make sure the power button is oriented the same way as the slot. The bottom left corner of the power button should stick out more than the top left corner, and the top right corner should stick out more than the bottom right corner.  A simple way to check this is to held the power button in place and look at the side of the device (from the "outside" of the device).

Lines.Text: grasping the power button between your index finger and your thumb , slide the power button to the right .
as you do this , the left side of the power button will come off of the plastic ridge it was resting on . the power button will rest against the case .
move the power button back and forth to make sure it is in the correct position and free to move .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the power button between your index finger and your thumb, slide the power button to the right. As you do this, the left side of the power button will come off of the plastic ridge it was resting on.  The power button will rest against the case. Move the power button back and forth to make sure it is in the correct position and free to move.

the volume button will pop out .

Lines.Text: shown here are the locations of the four small metal tabs discussed in the next step-go ahead and locate them , as they are small and difficult to show in pictures .

Steps.Text_raw: Shown here are the locations of the four small metal tabs discussed in the next step-go ahead and locate them, as they are small and difficult to show in pictures.

Lines.Text: using a pry bar , bend the 4 metal tabs holding the scroll wheel in place away from the scroll wheel .

the scroll wheel has four plastic tabs held in place by the 4 metal tabs . after you bend all four metal tabs away from the scroll bar , lift one of the plastic tabs above the metal tab holding it in place . you may need to bend the metal tab more while you try to lift the plastic tab above the metal tab .
repeat this for every plastic tab .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pry bar, bend the 4 metal tabs holding the scroll wheel in place away from the scroll wheel. The scroll wheel has four plastic tabs held in place by the 4 metal tabs.  After you bend all four metal tabs away from the scroll bar, lift one of the plastic tabs above the metal tab holding it in place.  You may need to bend the metal tab more while you try to lift the plastic tab above the metal tab. Repeat this for every plastic tab.

Lines.Text: remove the scroll wheel .
remove the center button . the center button will just lift off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the scroll wheel. Remove the center button.  The center button will just lift off.

Lines.Text: when installing a new scroll wheel , the center button and the scroll wheel must be placed on the board correctly .

the center button has two small indentions on either side . the center button must be placed so that these two small indentions line up with the two metal prongs in the center of the circuit board . the indentions on the center button and the metal prongs in the middle of the circuit board are circled with orange circles in the photographs .
place the center button in the circuit board , being sure to line up the indentions with the metal prongs in the middle of the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: When installing a new scroll wheel, the center button and the scroll wheel must be placed on the board correctly. The center button has two small indentions on either side.  The center button must be placed so that these two small indentions line up with the two metal prongs in the center of the circuit board.  The indentions on the center  button and the metal prongs in the middle of the circuit board are circled with orange circles in the photographs. Place the center button in the circuit board, being sure to line up the indentions with the metal prongs in the middle of the circuit board.

Lines.Text: there are two slots on the bottom of the scroll wheel . these two slots must line up with two components on the circuit board . these two components and the two slots are indicated with an orange circle in the photographs .
place the scroll wheel on the board , being sure to line up the two slots with the components .
hold the scroll wheel in place so that the 4 plastic tabs are lined up with the 4 metal tabs . bend the metal tabs back over the plastic tabs .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two slots on the bottom of the scroll wheel.  These two slots must line up with two components on the circuit board.  These two components and the two slots are indicated with an orange circle in the photographs. Place the scroll wheel on the board, being sure to line up the two slots with the components. Hold the scroll wheel in place so that the 4 plastic tabs are lined up with the 4 metal tabs.  Bend the metal tabs back over the plastic tabs.

use a phillip's head screwdriver to remove the screw from the back of the internal antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the circuit board over to look at the back side, so that LCD screen is facing away from you. Use a Phillip's head screwdriver to remove the screw from the back of the internal antenna.

Lines.Text: use your fingers to pry the internal antenna off of the circuit board . you may need to wiggle it back and forth to successfully remove it .
woohoo ! you have removed the internal antenna !

Steps.Text_raw: Use your fingers to pry the internal antenna off of the circuit board. You may need to wiggle it back and forth to successfully remove it. Woohoo! You have removed the internal antenna!

Lines.Text: wedge the px 3688 plastic opening tool between the glass front panel and the plastic frame . start near the top where the volume control buttons are located and stay on one side of ipod .
turn the tool in a hinge-like rotation away from the ipod and pry the glass panel out of its case .
be careful to work at a slow and gentle pace . avoid breaking anything inside the ipod , especially the screen .

lift the front panel out of the bottom case .
be careful not to damage the touch screen connector cable still attached near the upper left corner of the ipod .

Lines.Text: insert a px 3688 plastic opening tool with the edge angled up , toward the underside of the display , between the white plastic backlight and the metal beneath it .
pry the lower edge of the display up until it's at about a 45 degree angle with the rest of the ipod .
hold the display in this position with one hand for the next step to avoid damaging the display ribbon cable .

do not peel off the copper tape that is attached to the metal display tray .

Lines.Text: rotate the metal display tray to the top of the ipod , being careful of the ribbon connecting the battery to the logic board .

place the battery back in the rear panel .

Lines.Text: using a pair of tweezers , remove the small strip of tape covering the end of the battery cable .

Lines.Text: flip the battery over and place it in the rear panel , face down .

Lines.Text: the battery on the ipod touch is attached via solder pads .
heat the solder of the solder pads individually and use your metal spudger to pry them from the logic board .
when soldering , work from one side of the ribbon cable . heat the side while using the spudger to gently lift the ribbon cable from the board . repeat this process for the other two pads .
only solder the solder pads on the board and the ribbon cable . soldering outside the correct area has potential to ruin the logic board .
make sure to only hold the tip of the iron against the solder pad long enough to complete the melt . overheating can ruin the logic board and the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery on the iPod Touch is attached via solder pads. Heat the solder of the solder pads individually and use your metal spudger to pry them from the logic board. When soldering, work from one side of the ribbon cable. Heat the side while using the spudger to gently lift the ribbon cable from the board. Repeat this process for the other two pads. Only solder the solder pads on the board and the ribbon cable. Soldering outside the correct area has potential to ruin the logic board. Make sure to only hold the tip of the iron against the solder pad long enough to complete the melt. Overheating can ruin the logic board and the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: the battery should be free from the logic board by now .
lift the old battery out of the ipod and set it aside in a safe location .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery should be free from the logic board by now. Lift the old battery out of the iPod and set it aside in a safe location.

Title: iPod Touch 4th Generation Home Button Replacement

Lines.Text: the ipod touch 4th generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive . the use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended .
with the heat gun set on low , begin heating the lower portion of the touch near the home button .
it is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device .

Steps.Text_raw: The iPod Touch 4th Generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive. The use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended. With the heat gun set on "low", begin heating the lower portion of the Touch near the home button. It is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device.

Lines.Text: beware , as the touch will be very hot . it may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying .
insert the edge of an ipod opening tool between the front glass panel and the black plastic bezel near the home button .
do not try to pry between the black plastic bezel and the steel rear case .
pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward , being careful not to bend the glass excessively .
if it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly , reheat it and try again .

Steps.Text_raw: Beware, as the Touch will be very hot. It may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying. Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool between the front glass panel and the black plastic bezel near the home button. Do not try to pry between the black plastic bezel and the steel rear case. Pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward, being careful not to bend the glass excessively. If it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly, reheat it and try again.

Lines.Text: when there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel , lift the front panel away from the body of the touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges .
if the adhesive is too difficult to separate , use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding .

Steps.Text_raw: When there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel, lift the front panel away from the body of the Touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges. If the adhesive is too difficult to separate, use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding.

Lines.Text: due to the construction of the touch , the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed . use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly , as it is attached to the rest of the touch by the very delicate digitizer cable .

the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly . if it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly , be sure to disconnect it with a plastic opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the touch .
carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the touch , minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components .

Steps.Text_raw: Due to the construction of the Touch, the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed. Use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly, as it is attached to the rest of the Touch by the very delicate digitizer cable. The display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly. If it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly, be sure to disconnect it with a plastic opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the Touch. Carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the Touch, minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components.

Lines.Text: being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device , lay the device out so that you can access the back side of the display assembly .
insert a plastic opening tool under the rubber holding the home button in place .
slide the tool around the perimeter of the button , prying up as you go .
lift the home button out of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device, lay the device out so that you can access the back side of the display assembly. Insert a plastic opening tool under the rubber holding the home button in place. Slide the tool around the perimeter of the button, prying up as you go. Lift the home button out of the device.

Subject: Home Button

Lines.Text: the ipod touch 4th generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive . the use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended .
with the heat gun set on low , begin heating the lower portion of the touch near the home button .
it is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device .

Steps.Text_raw: The iPod Touch 4th Generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive. The use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended. With the heat gun set on "low", begin heating the lower portion of the Touch near the home button. It is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device.

Lines.Text: beware , as the touch will be very hot . it may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying .
insert the edge of an ipod opening tool between the front glass panel and the plastic bezel near the home button .
do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case .
pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward , being careful not to bend the glass excessively .
if it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly , reheat it and try again .

Steps.Text_raw: Beware, as the Touch will be very hot. It may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying. Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool between the front glass panel and the  plastic bezel near the home button. Do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case. Pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward, being careful not to bend the glass excessively. If it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly, reheat it and try again.

Lines.Text: when there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel , lift it away from the body of the touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges .
if the adhesive is too difficult to separate , use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding .

Steps.Text_raw: When there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel, lift it away from the body of the Touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges. If the adhesive is too difficult to separate, use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding.

Lines.Text: due to the construction of the 4th generation touch , the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed . use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly , as it is attached to the rest of the touch by the very delicate digitizer cable .

also , the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly . if it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly , be sure to disconnect it with an ipod opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the touch .
carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the touch , minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components .

Steps.Text_raw: Due to the construction of the 4th generation Touch, the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed. Use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly, as it is attached to the rest of the Touch by the very delicate digitizer cable. Also, the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly. If it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly, be sure to disconnect it with an iPod opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the Touch. Carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the Touch, minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components.

Lines.Text: remove the following eight phillips 00 screws :
one 3.5 mm phillips screw
two 3.0 mm phillips screws
one 2.3 mm phillips screw
one 2.4 mm phillips screw
three 2.0 mm phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following eight Phillips #00 screws: One 3.5 mm Phillips screw Two 3.0 mm Phillips screws One 2.3 mm Phillips screw One 2.4 mm Phillips screw Three 2.0 mm Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera .
note the small spring located near the bezel next to the camera ( highlighted in yellow ) .
remove the steel cover from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera. Note the small spring located near the bezel next to the camera (highlighted in yellow). Remove the steel cover from the iPod.

Lines.Text: insert the edge of an ipod opening tool under the steel mid plate near the bottom left corner of the touch .
pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case .
if the plate is still attached to the logic board re-warm the area to loosen the adhesive , then separate the plate from the logic board using the opening tool
use extreme care , the speaker is under the area shown in photo . it is connected with very thin and short wires .

there is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board . try to work around this area like shown so not to rip the cable . be sure to hold down this cable when lifting the plate . it could stick to the plate due to residual glue . it is extremely fragile .
this cable will tear very easily if you are not careful .
there is also adhesive under the area shown in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool under the steel mid plate near the bottom left corner of the Touch. Pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case. If the plate is still attached to the logic board re-warm the area to loosen the adhesive, then separate the plate from the logic board using the opening tool Use extreme care, the speaker is under the area shown in photo. It is connected with very thin and short wires. There is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board. Try to work around this area like shown so not to rip the cable. Be sure to hold down this cable when lifting the plate. It could stick to the plate due to residual glue. It is extremely fragile. This cable will tear very easily if you are not careful. There is also adhesive under the area shown in red.

Lines.Text: slightly tilt the steel mid plane to dislodge it from the rear case .
be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel mid plane .
lift the steel mid plane up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera .

Steps.Text_raw: Slightly tilt the steel mid plane to dislodge it from the rear case. Be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel mid plane. Lift the steel mid plane up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the single 2.6 mm phillips screw securing the headphone jack assembly to the rear case .
the screw is at a '''90 ''' degree angle . make sure to remove it at such an angle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single 2.6 mm Phillips screw securing the headphone jack assembly to the rear case. The screw is at a '''90''' degree angle. Make sure to remove it at such an angle.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to gently lift the edge of the headphone jack nearest the battery out of its recess .
remove the headphone jack from its housing within the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to gently lift the edge of the headphone jack nearest the battery out of its recess. Remove the headphone jack from its housing within the rear case.

Lines.Text: remove the following three screws near the top edge of the logic board :
one 2.0 mm phillips screw
two 2.3 mm phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following three screws near the top edge of the logic board: One 2.0 mm Phillips screw Two 2.3 mm Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to gently pry , but not remove , the rear-facing camera away from the rear case .
do '''not''' attempt to remove the rear-facing camera yet .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to gently pry, but not remove, the rear-facing camera away from the rear case. Do '''not''' attempt to remove the rear-facing camera yet.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to slightly lift the edge of the logic board next to the battery enough to grab it with your other hand .
do not excessively bend the logic board , as it is very thin and fragile .
be very careful not to lift too much as the volume control ribbon cable is still connected and will tear '''very''' easily .
while gently lifting the logic board with one hand , use an ipod opening tool to lift the logic board near the copper tape at the logic board's top edge .
the logic board will be lifted adequately when the last display assembly connector has cleared the top edge of the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to slightly lift the edge of the logic board next to the battery enough to grab it with your other hand. Do not excessively bend the logic board, as it is very thin and fragile. Be very careful not to lift too much as the volume control ribbon cable is still connected and will tear '''very''' easily. While gently lifting the  logic board with one hand, use an iPod opening tool to lift the logic board near the copper tape at the logic board's top edge. The logic board will be lifted adequately when the last display assembly connector has cleared the top edge of the rear case.

Lines.Text: with a plastic opening tool , gently pry the ipod's speaker out of its recess in the outer case .
do not try to completely remove the speaker . it is still soldered to the underside of the logic board .
allow the speaker to rest above the battery so that you can proceed with battery installation .

Steps.Text_raw: With a plastic opening tool, gently pry the iPod's speaker out of its recess in the outer case. Do not try to completely remove the speaker. It is still soldered to the underside of the logic board. Allow the speaker to rest above the battery so that you can proceed with battery installation.

Lines.Text: in the next few steps , you will loosen the adhesive from underneath the battery , the logic board , and the frame under the battery . do this slowly , carefully , and evenly . take care not to puncture the battery or bend the logic board .
use a plastic opening tool to pry up the adhesive around the three exposed edges of the battery .
do not try to pry the battery out , just start loosening the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: In the next few steps, you will loosen the adhesive from underneath the battery, the logic board, and the frame under the battery. Do this slowly, carefully, and evenly. Take care not to puncture the battery or bend the logic board. Use a plastic opening tool to pry up the adhesive around the three exposed edges of the battery. Do not try to pry the battery out, just start loosening the adhesive.

Lines.Text: after the edges of the battery are loosened , begin prying up the edge of the logic board . start at the top and work your way down the side of the board .

to prevent bending/breaking the logic board , do not try to remove the logic board , yet . the dock connector is still embedded in the frame . again , you are only trying to loosen more of the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: After the edges of the battery are loosened, begin prying up the edge of the logic board. Start at the top and work your way down the side of the board. To prevent bending/breaking the logic board, do not try to remove the logic board, yet. The dock connector is still embedded in the frame. Again, you are only trying to loosen more of the adhesive.

Lines.Text: with a plastic opening tool , carefully push the dock connector out of its outer case recess . work each corner evenly until the connector comes free .
since the dock connector is attached to the logic board , pushing it out of the case may cause the logic board to begin to flex . take extra care not to permanently warp the board .

Steps.Text_raw: With a plastic opening tool, carefully push the dock connector out of its outer case recess. Work each corner evenly until the connector comes free. Since the dock connector is attached to the logic board, pushing it out of the case may cause the logic board to begin to flex. Take extra care not to permanently warp the board.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is freed from under the logic board/battery assembly , lift the assembly up from the side and carefully rotate it over to access the underside of the battery .
the logic board is still attached to the rear case . do not try to completely separate the assembly , or you will rip this ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is freed from under the logic board/battery assembly, lift the assembly up from the side and carefully rotate it over to access the underside of the battery. The logic board is still attached to the rear case. Do not try to completely separate the assembly, or you will rip this ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: grip the copper shield located on the bottom of the battery with one hand while firmly holding the battery with the other .
carefully peel the copper shield up off the battery .
do not rapidly peel the copper shield . doing so may cause irreversible damage to the battery .
when installing a new battery , the copper shield must be as flat as possible . otherwise the ruffled shield will add to the thickness of the battery and lcd combined .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the copper shield located on the bottom of the battery with one hand while firmly holding the battery with the other. Carefully peel the copper shield up off the battery. Do not rapidly peel the copper shield. Doing so may cause irreversible damage to the battery. When installing a new battery, the copper shield must be as flat as possible. Otherwise the ruffled shield will add to the thickness of the battery and LCD combined.

Lines.Text: if necessary , use a plastic opening tool to peel the piece of yellow kapton tape located near the bottom of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: If necessary, use a plastic opening tool to peel the piece of yellow kapton tape located near the bottom of the battery.

Lines.Text: at this point , the battery should only be attached to the logic board by a single cable .
rotate the battery up and away from the logic board .
flip the assembly over to reveal the battery solder points .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, the battery should only be attached to the logic board by a single cable. Rotate the battery up and away from the logic board. Flip the assembly over to reveal the battery solder points.

Lines.Text: in the next few steps , you will desolder the three battery solder joints on the logic board .

prior to desoldering the 3 leads , there may be some silicon/glue covering them . remove as much as possible with a plastic or metal spudger ( if metal , be extremely careful not to bridge the connections ) before applying soldering tip to points .

Steps.Text_raw: In the next few steps, you will desolder the three battery solder joints on the logic board. Prior to desoldering the 3 leads, there may be some silicon/glue covering them.  Remove as much as possible with a plastic or metal spudger (if metal, be extremely careful not to bridge the connections) before applying soldering tip to points.

Lines.Text: the battery on the fourth generation touch is attached via solder pads with small holes that go ''through'' the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board . in this step , you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board .
'''do not''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger . shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board .

beware of overheating the board and the cable . only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt . excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable .

start working from the outside of the battery ribbon cable . heat the outermost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board . repeat this process for each of the two remaining pads , working from the outside in .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery on the fourth generation Touch is attached via solder pads with small holes that go ''through'' the battery ribbon cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board. In this step, you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board. '''DO NOT''' bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger. Shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board. Beware of overheating the board and the cable. Only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt. Excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable. Start working from the outside of the battery ribbon cable. Heat the outermost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board. Repeat this process for each of the two remaining pads, working from the outside in.

Lines.Text: at this point , the battery should be free from the logic board .
remove the old battery from the logic board and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, the battery should be free from the logic board. Remove the old battery from the logic board and set it aside.

Lines.Text: next , use the tip of a soldering iron to flatten out the solder on the logic board solder pads . the pictures show a 'before' and 'after' shot .
remember not to heat up the pads too much .

Steps.Text_raw: Next, use the tip of a soldering iron to flatten out the solder on the logic board solder pads. The pictures show a 'before' and 'after' shot. Remember not to heat up the pads too much.

Lines.Text: place the new battery in place and align the far contact with the outer solder pad . use a small strip of electrical tape to hold the cable against the solder pads .
installing the battery upside down ( with the cable facing up ) will destroy the logic board .
place the strip of tape over the end of the battery ribbon cable to cover two of the solder pads and hold the contacts down against the logic board .
heat the rightmost contact until the solder below melts , then apply a small amount of solder to the contact , allowing it to flow through the two holes in the cable and down to the logic board .
do not apply too much solder . the amount required for a proper bond is miniscule .
as soon as the solder has flowed into the joint , remove both the solder and the iron .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the new battery in place and align the far contact with the outer solder pad. Use a small strip of electrical tape to hold the cable against the solder pads. Installing the battery upside down (with the cable facing up) will destroy the logic board. Place the strip of tape over the end of the battery ribbon cable to cover two of the solder pads and hold the contacts down against the logic board. Heat the rightmost contact until the solder below melts, then apply a small amount of solder to the contact, allowing it to flow through the two holes in the cable and down to the logic board. Do not apply too much solder. The amount required for a proper bond is miniscule. As soon as the solder has flowed into the joint, remove both the solder and the iron.

Lines.Text: move the piece of tape so that it no longer covers the remaining two leads . if you are satisfied with the position of the cable relative to the pads on the board , proceed . if not , de-solder the first connection and try again .
solder the two remaining pads to the logic board , being mindful of overheating the cable or board .

Steps.Text_raw: Move the piece of tape so that it no longer covers the remaining two leads. If you are satisfied with the position of the cable relative to the pads on the board, proceed. If not, de-solder the first connection and try again. Solder the two remaining pads to the logic board, being mindful of overheating the cable or board.

Title: iPod Touch 4th Generation Volume/Power Button Cable Replacement

Lines.Text: the ipod touch 4th generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive . the use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended .
with the heat gun set on low , begin heating the lower portion of the touch near the home button .
it is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device .

Steps.Text_raw: The iPod Touch 4th Generation front panel is attached to the rear case by adhesive. The use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended. With the heat gun set on "low", begin heating the lower portion of the Touch near the home button. It is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device.

Lines.Text: beware , as the touch will be very hot . it may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying .
insert the edge of an ipod opening tool between the front glass panel and the plastic bezel near the home button .
do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case .
pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward , being careful not to bend the glass excessively .
if it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly , reheat it and try again .

Steps.Text_raw: Beware, as the Touch will be very hot. It may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying. Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool between the front glass panel and the  plastic bezel near the home button. Do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case. Pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward, being careful not to bend the glass excessively. If it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly, reheat it and try again.

Lines.Text: when there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel , lift it away from the body of the touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges .
if the adhesive is too difficult to separate , use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding .

Steps.Text_raw: When there is enough room to grab the bottom edge of the front panel, lift it away from the body of the Touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges. If the adhesive is too difficult to separate, use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding.

Lines.Text: due to the construction of the 4th generation touch , the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed . use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly , as it is attached to the rest of the touch by the very delicate digitizer cable .

also , the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly . if it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly , be sure to disconnect it with an ipod opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the touch .
carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the touch , minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components .

Steps.Text_raw: Due to the construction of the 4th generation Touch, the digitizer cable cannot be disconnected until the logic board is removed. Use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly, as it is attached to the rest of the Touch by the very delicate digitizer cable. Also, the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the top of the front panel assembly. If it does not become disconnected while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly, be sure to disconnect it with an iPod opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the Touch. Carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the Touch, minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components.

Lines.Text: remove the following eight phillips 00 screws :
one 3.5 mm phillips screw
two 3.0 mm phillips screws
one 2.3 mm phillips screw
one 2.4 mm phillips screw
three 2.0 mm phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following eight Phillips #00 screws: One 3.5 mm Phillips screw Two 3.0 mm Phillips screws One 2.3 mm Phillips screw One 2.4 mm Phillips screw Three 2.0 mm Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera .
note the small spring located near the bezel next to the camera ( highlighted in yellow ) .
remove the steel cover from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera. Note the small spring located near the bezel next to the camera (highlighted in yellow). Remove the steel cover from the iPod.

Lines.Text: insert the edge of an ipod opening tool under the steel mid plate near the bottom left corner of the touch .
pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case .
if the plate is still attached to the logic board re-warm the area to loosen the adhesive , then separate the plate from the logic board using the opening tool
use extreme care , the speaker is under the area shown in photo . it is connected with very thin and short wires .

there is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board . try to work around this area like shown so not to rip the cable . be sure to hold down this cable when lifting the plate . it could stick to the plate due to residual glue . it is extremely fragile .
this cable will tear very easily if you are not careful .
there is also adhesive under the area shown in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of an iPod opening tool under the steel mid plate near the bottom left corner of the Touch. Pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case. If the plate is still attached to the logic board re-warm the area to loosen the adhesive, then separate the plate from the logic board using the opening tool Use extreme care, the speaker is under the area shown in photo. It is connected with very thin and short wires. There is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board. Try to work around this area like shown so not to rip the cable. Be sure to hold down this cable when lifting the plate. It could stick to the plate due to residual glue. It is extremely fragile. This cable will tear very easily if you are not careful. There is also adhesive under the area shown in red.

Lines.Text: slightly tilt the steel mid plane to dislodge it from the rear case .
be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel mid plane .
lift the steel mid plane up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera .

Steps.Text_raw: Slightly tilt the steel mid plane to dislodge it from the rear case. Be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel mid plane. Lift the steel mid plane up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the single 2.6 mm phillips screw securing the headphone jack assembly to the rear case .
the screw is at a '''90 ''' degree angle . make sure to remove it at such an angle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single 2.6 mm Phillips screw securing the headphone jack assembly to the rear case. The screw is at a '''90''' degree angle. Make sure to remove it at such an angle.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to gently lift the edge of the headphone jack nearest the battery out of its recess .
remove the headphone jack from its housing within the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to gently lift the edge of the headphone jack nearest the battery out of its recess. Remove the headphone jack from its housing within the rear case.

Lines.Text: remove the following three screws near the top edge of the logic board :
one 2.0 mm phillips screw
two 2.3 mm phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following three screws near the top edge of the logic board: One 2.0 mm Phillips screw Two 2.3 mm Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the edge of an ipod opening tool to gently pry , but not remove , the rear-facing camera away from the rear case .
do '''not''' attempt to remove the rear-facing camera yet .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of an iPod opening tool to gently pry, but not remove, the rear-facing camera away from the rear case. Do '''not''' attempt to remove the rear-facing camera yet.

Lines.Text: use an ipod opening tool to slightly lift the edge of the logic board next to the battery enough to grab it with your other hand .
do not excessively bend the logic board , as it is very thin and fragile .
be very careful not to lift too much as the volume control ribbon cable is still connected and will tear '''very''' easily .
while gently lifting the logic board with one hand , use an ipod opening tool to lift the logic board near the copper tape at the logic board's top edge .
the logic board will be lifted adequately when the last display assembly connector has cleared the top edge of the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an iPod opening tool to slightly lift the edge of the logic board next to the battery enough to grab it with your other hand. Do not excessively bend the logic board, as it is very thin and fragile. Be very careful not to lift too much as the volume control ribbon cable is still connected and will tear '''very''' easily. While gently lifting the  logic board with one hand, use an iPod opening tool to lift the logic board near the copper tape at the logic board's top edge. The logic board will be lifted adequately when the last display assembly connector has cleared the top edge of the rear case.

Lines.Text: with a plastic opening tool , gently pry the ipod's speaker out of its recess in the outer case .
do not try to completely remove the speaker . it is still soldered to the underside of the logic board .
allow the speaker to rest above the battery so that you can proceed with battery installation .

Steps.Text_raw: With a plastic opening tool, gently pry the iPod's speaker out of its recess in the outer case. Do not try to completely remove the speaker. It is still soldered to the underside of the logic board. Allow the speaker to rest above the battery so that you can proceed with battery installation.

Lines.Text: in the next few steps , you will loosen the adhesive from underneath the battery , the logic board , and the frame under the battery . do this slowly , carefully , and evenly . take care not to puncture the battery or bend the logic board .
use a plastic opening tool to pry up the adhesive around the three exposed edges of the battery .
do not try to pry the battery out , just start loosening the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: In the next few steps, you will loosen the adhesive from underneath the battery, the logic board, and the frame under the battery. Do this slowly, carefully, and evenly. Take care not to puncture the battery or bend the logic board. Use a plastic opening tool to pry up the adhesive around the three exposed edges of the battery. Do not try to pry the battery out, just start loosening the adhesive.

Lines.Text: after the edges of the battery are loosened , begin prying up the edge of the logic board . start at the top and work your way down the side of the board .

to prevent bending/breaking the logic board , do not try to remove the logic board , yet . the dock connector is still embedded in the frame . again , you are only trying to loosen more of the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: After the edges of the battery are loosened, begin prying up the edge of the logic board. Start at the top and work your way down the side of the board. To prevent bending/breaking the logic board, do not try to remove the logic board, yet. The dock connector is still embedded in the frame. Again, you are only trying to loosen more of the adhesive.

Lines.Text: with a plastic opening tool , carefully push the dock connector out of its outer case recess . work each corner evenly until the connector comes free .
since the dock connector is attached to the logic board , pushing it out of the case may cause the logic board to begin to flex . take extra care not to permanently warp the board .

Steps.Text_raw: With a plastic opening tool, carefully push the dock connector out of its outer case recess. Work each corner evenly until the connector comes free. Since the dock connector is attached to the logic board, pushing it out of the case may cause the logic board to begin to flex. Take extra care not to permanently warp the board.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is freed from under the logic board/battery assembly , lift the assembly up from the side and carefully rotate it over to access the underside of the battery .
the logic board is still attached to the rear case . do not try to completely separate the assembly , or you will rip this ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is freed from under the logic board/battery assembly, lift the assembly up from the side and carefully rotate it over to access the underside of the battery. The logic board is still attached to the rear case. Do not try to completely separate the assembly, or you will rip this ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: remove the two 1.3 mm phillips 00 screws securing the volume/power button cable metal cover .
lift and remove the metal cover out from the rear panel assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 1.3 mm Phillips #00 screws securing the Volume/Power button cable metal cover. Lift and remove the metal cover out from the rear panel assembly.

Lines.Text: with the corner of a plastic opening tool , gently move the ribbon cable out of the way so you can get to the screw beneath it .
you do not need to bend or rip the cable , just move it enough to access the screw .

Steps.Text_raw: With the corner of a plastic opening tool, gently move the ribbon cable out of the way so you can get to the screw beneath it. You do not need to bend or rip the cable, just move it enough to access the screw.

Lines.Text: remove the two 2.0 mm phillips screws securing the power button assembly to the rear panel assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.0 mm Phillips screws securing the power button assembly to the rear panel assembly.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to peel the piece of copper tape covering the volume/power button assembly .
lift and remove the piece of copper tape out of the touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to peel the piece of copper tape covering the volume/power button assembly. LIft and remove the piece of copper tape out of the Touch.

Lines.Text: slide the plastic opening tool under the length of the ribbon cable to release it from the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the plastic opening tool under the length of the ribbon cable to release it from the rear panel.

Lines.Text: wedge the plastic opening tool under each volume controller and pry the assembly loose from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge the plastic opening tool under each volume controller and pry the assembly loose from the case.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board/battery assembly over to access the ribbon cable solder joints .
in the next few steps , you will desolder the four volume/power button ribbon cable solder joints on the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board/battery assembly over to access the ribbon cable solder joints. In the next few steps, you will desolder the four volume/power button ribbon cable solder joints on the logic board.

Lines.Text: the volume/power button cable is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board . in this step , you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board .
do not bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger . shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board .

beware of overheating the board and the cable . only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt . excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable .

start working from the outside of the ribbon cable . heat the outermost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board . repeat this process for each of the three remaining pads , working from right to left .

Steps.Text_raw: The volume/power button cable is attached via solder pads with small holes that go through the cable and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board. In this step, you will heat each solder pad individually while using a metal spudger to pry it up from the logic board. DO NOT bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable with your spudger. Shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board. Beware of overheating the board and the cable. Only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt. Excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable. Start working from the outside of the ribbon cable. Heat the outermost solder pad while gently prying up from under the ribbon cable to free it from the board. Repeat this process for each of the three remaining pads, working from right to left.

Lines.Text: at this point , the cable should be free from the logic board .
lift the old cable out of the touch and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, the cable should be free from the logic board. Lift the old cable out of the Touch and set it aside.

Lines.Text: place the replacement cable in place and align the far right contact with the far right solder point . use two small strips of electrical tape to hold the cable against the solder pads .
place two strips of tape over the end of the ribbon cable to both cover the two left-most solder pads and hold the contacts down against the logic board .
heat the right-most contact until the solder below melts , then apply a small amount of solder to the contact , allowing it to flow through the two holes in the cable and down to the logic board .
do not apply too much solder . the amount required for a proper bond is miniscule .
as soon as the solder has flowed into the joint , remove both the solder and the iron .
repeat this process with the second solder pad .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the replacement cable in place and align the far right contact with the far right solder point. Use two small strips of electrical tape to hold the cable against the solder pads. Place two strips of tape over the end of the ribbon cable to both cover the two left-most solder pads and hold the contacts down against the logic board. Heat the right-most contact until the solder below melts, then apply a small amount of solder to the contact, allowing it to flow through the two holes in the cable and down to the logic board. Do not apply too much solder. The amount required for a proper bond is miniscule. As soon as the solder has flowed into the joint, remove both the solder and the iron. Repeat this process with the second solder pad.

Lines.Text: remove the old tape , and place a new piece of tape to hold the cable in place , but uncover the remaining two pads . if you are satisfied with the position of the cable relative to the pads on the board , proceed . if not , de-solder the first connection and try again .
solder the two remaining pads to the logic board , being mindful of overheating the cable or board .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the old tape, and place a new piece of tape to hold the cable in place, but uncover the remaining two pads. If you are satisfied with the position of the cable relative to the pads on the board, proceed. If not, de-solder the first connection and try again. Solder the two remaining pads to the logic board, being mindful of overheating the cable or board.

Subject: Volume/Power Button Cable

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips screws from the top .
remove the two phillips screws from the right side .
remove the two phillips screws from the left side .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips screws from the top. Remove the two Phillips screws from the right side. Remove the two Phillips screws from the left side.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips screws from the bottom .
you can now remove the back cover bezel .
remove the two phillips screws from the hard drive back plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips screws from the bottom. You can now remove the back cover bezel. Remove the two Phillips screws from the hard drive back plate.

Lines.Text: remove the hard drive back plate
the hard drive is mounted to the archos via 4 allen screws . two on the top and two on the bottom
use the allen wrench to remove the two screws on the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the hard drive back plate The hard drive is mounted to the Archos via 4 Allen screws. Two on the top and two on the bottom Use the Allen wrench to remove the two screws on the top.

Lines.Text: remove the two allen screws from the bottom .
another view of the two allen screws on the top part .
with the four screws removed , gently lift the non-connector side of the hard drive . it will only need to come up by about 1 /4 of an inch .
do not lift it to high on that side , it may bend the pins on the connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Allen screws from the bottom. Another view of the two Allen screws on the top part. With the four screws removed, gently lift the non-connector side of the hard drive. It will only need to come up by about 1/4 of an inch. DO NOT lift it to high on that side, it may bend the pins on the connector.

Lines.Text: with the hard drive still angled , slide it out and away from the connector .
remove the hard drive completely from the archos .
the battery can now be fully seen .
the battery is soldered to the logic board . the battery cannot be removed , yet .

Steps.Text_raw: With the hard drive still angled, slide it out and away from the connector. Remove the hard drive completely from the Archos. The battery can now be fully seen. The battery is soldered to the logic board. The battery cannot be removed, yet.

Lines.Text: to remove the battery , the display will have to be removed . the two screws that were previously removed actually held the display to the frame .
fingernails will be a perfect tool to just slightly lift the screen out of the frame .
the display is snapped into place on the side of the dock connector . this end can come loose first by using your fingernails between the frame and the display .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the battery, the display will have to be removed. The two screws that were previously removed actually held the display to the frame. Fingernails will be a perfect tool to just slightly lift the screen out of the frame. The Display is snapped into place on the side of the dock connector. This end can come loose first by using your fingernails between the frame and the display.

Lines.Text: this is the maximum angle at which to hold the display to remove it from that side .
gently pull the display away from the button bar , until it just clears the snaps on that side .
angle the display upwards to see the :
ribbon cable connector
soldered ground connection

Steps.Text_raw: This is the maximum angle at which to hold the display to remove it from that side. Gently pull the display away from the button bar, until it just clears the snaps on that side. Angle the display upwards to see the: Ribbon cable connector Soldered ground connection

Lines.Text: open the clip that holds the ribbon cable into the connector , by flipping it away from the cable side .
unsolder the ground cable from the logic board . using desoldering braid will ease this task .
both connections from the display are now removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the clip that holds the ribbon cable into the connector, by flipping it away from the cable side. Unsolder the ground cable from the logic board. Using desoldering braid will ease this task. Both connections from the display are now removed.

Lines.Text: remove the display from the archos .
the logic board is fastened to the housing by four phillips screws .
remove those screws with the phillips screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the display from the Archos. The logic board is fastened to the housing by four Phillips screws. Remove those screws with the Phillips screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the bottom right side phillips screw .
remove the top right side phillips screw .
the top left side phillips screw is colored black and is mounted within a plate coming of the button bar . just remove the screw , not the bar .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bottom right side Phillips screw. Remove the top right side Phillips screw. The top left side Phillips screw is colored black and is mounted within a plate coming of the button bar. Just remove the screw, not the bar.

Lines.Text: the battery has an extremely tight fit within the archos . to maximize that room , the upper and lower hard drive rail need to be removed .
remove the single phillips screw that holds the top rail to the frame .
remove the single phillips screw that holds the bottom rail to the frame .
this shows how the rail fits to the frame . besides the screw , it also clips to the frame and requires a slight twist .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery has an extremely tight fit within the Archos. To maximize that room, the upper and lower hard drive rail need to be removed. Remove the single Phillips screw that holds the top rail to the frame. Remove the single Phillips screw that holds the bottom rail to the frame. This shows how the rail fits to the frame. Besides the screw, it also clips to the frame and requires a slight twist.

Lines.Text: this shows the bottom rail and its orientation to the housing .
remove the cellophane that covers the batery connectors as well as part of the logic board .
do not discard the cellophane , it will have to be replaced during the reassembly .
loosen the cellophane that comes from the battery to the logic board . it can not be removed completely , but must be lifted off of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: This shows the bottom rail and its orientation to the housing. Remove the cellophane that covers the batery connectors as well as part of the logic board. Do not discard the cellophane, it will have to be replaced during the reassembly. Loosen the cellophane that comes from the battery to the logic board. It can not be removed completely, but must be lifted off of the logic board.

Lines.Text: unsolder the red and black wire from th logic board .
here is the reason for loosening the logic board . push it lightly below the level of the battery .
shimmy the battery toward the logic board . it will just clear the back of the housing .
angle the battery to one side to remove it from the housing . the plastic of the housing , as well as the battery have a very small amount of flex . this flex is enough to free the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Unsolder the red and black wire from th logic board. Here is the reason for loosening the logic board. Push it lightly below the level of the battery. Shimmy the battery toward the logic board. It will just clear the back of the housing. Angle the battery to one side to remove it from the housing. The plastic of the housing, as well as the battery have a very small amount of flex. This flex is enough to free the battery.

Lines.Text: remove the battery from the archos . take a break , reorganize and install the new battery .
this is the result that is expected . a fully working archos that maintains a charge .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery from the Archos. Take a break, reorganize and install the new battery. This is the result that is expected. A fully working Archos that maintains a charge.

as you do this the logic board should move off with it .

then plug back in making sure it is completely connected .

Lines.Text: set the device with the adapter facing up .
remove the following screws :
two 10 mm phillips 0

the adapter will still be connected with wires , so make sure not to pull too hard .

four 7 mm phillips 0

flip the ihome so the speakers are laying on a flat surface , and you have the concealed battery areas facing you .

Lines.Text: using your fingers , press down firmly on the plastic slide and push in the direction of the arrows shown above the word open on the plastic .
remove the plastic slide from its location and set it aside .
these plastic slides are not interchangeable , so make sure each goes back to its original location in reassembly .
remove all 4 aa batteries by placing your fingernail at one end of the battery and applying force upwards until the battery is freed from its holder .
set the batteries aside , careful to not get them wet .
insert your fingernail or a prying tool under the notch of the plastic slide that is protecting the watch battery .
apply force in the direction of the arrow shown above the word open on the plastic . the plastic piece covering the watch battery should come loose .
set this plastic covering aside as well .

eight 10 mm phillips 0

be careful not to pry too hard . cracking the plastic connections could make reassembly harder .

you should have visible access to most of the components inside the ihome now .

pull upwards and dislodge the connector .
