Lines.Text: using the scissors on your wire strippers , cut the connecting wires .
using your wire strippers , remove about 1 /4 of the plastic tubing surrounding the end of your exposed wire , careful to not damage the wires .
using a wire-nut or electrician's tape , connect the wires of the replacement power connector to your exposed wires . connect white wire to white , and black to black .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the scissors on your wire strippers, cut the connecting wires. Using your wire strippers, remove about  1/4 " of the plastic tubing surrounding the end of your exposed wire, careful to not damage the wires. Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation Front Panel Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation LCD Shield Plate Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Lines.Text: flip the lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board .
the display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board .
use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board. The display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board. Use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the display assembly from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the display assembly from the iPod.

Subject: Display Assembly

Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation Wi-Fi Antenna Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the headphone jack , lightning connector , and speaker .
three 2.6 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the headphone jack, Lightning connector, and speaker. Three 2.6 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case .
do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, as it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

Lines.Text: grasping the large ribbon cable , gently pull the lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the large ribbon cable, gently pull the Lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the wi-fi antenna connector off the back of the logic board .
this cable is very delicate ; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the wi-fi antenna connector off the back of the logic board. This cable is very delicate; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board assembly back into the rear case to expose the wi-fi antenna .
remove the following screws securing the antenna to the rear case :
two 1.3 mm phillips 000 screws
one 1.5 mm phillips 000 screw

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board assembly back into the rear case to expose the Wi-Fi antenna. Remove the following screws securing the antenna to the rear case: Two 1.3 mm Phillips #000 screws One 1.5 mm Phillips #000 screw

Lines.Text: flip the screen back over onto the rest of the ipod to expose the edge of the antenna .
use the flat end of a spudger to gently pry the antenna up from its foam adhesive backing .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the screen back over onto the rest of the iPod to expose the edge of the antenna. Use the flat end of a spudger to gently pry the antenna up from its foam adhesive backing.

Lines.Text: remove the wi-fi antenna from the ipod touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Wi-Fi antenna from the iPod Touch.

Subject: Wi-Fi Antenna

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the headphone jack , lightning connector , and speaker .
three 2.6 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the headphone jack, Lightning connector, and speaker. Three 2.6 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case .
do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, as it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

Lines.Text: grasping the large ribbon cable , gently pull the lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the large ribbon cable, gently pull the Lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case.

Lines.Text: flip the entire assembly over , exposing the back of the logic board .
use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the entire assembly over, exposing the back of the logic board. Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket in the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket in the logic board.

Lines.Text: flip the lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board .
the display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board .
use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board. The display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board. Use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the display assembly from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the display assembly from the iPod.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back .
use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board .
this cable is very delicate ; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back. Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board. This cable is very delicate; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna.

Lines.Text: disconnect the button ribbon cable connector from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the button ribbon cable connector from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display connector from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display connector from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the logic board assembly from the rear case of the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the logic board assembly from the rear case of the iPod.

Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation Rear-Facing Camera Replacement

Lines.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame .
gently twist the spudger to free the camera .
lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket , and remove it from the ipod touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame. Gently twist the spudger to free the camera. Lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket, and remove it from the iPod Touch.

Lines.Text: gently slide the flat end of a spudger underneath the piece of foam tape covering the button ribbon cable .
run the spudger along the full length of the tape to disconnect it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently slide the flat end of a spudger underneath the piece of foam tape covering the button ribbon cable. Run the spudger along the full length of the tape to disconnect it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: peel and remove the foam tape from the rear case of the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel and remove the foam tape from the rear case of the iPod.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel up the edge of the tape covering the button ribbon cable .
use tweezers or your fingers to peel the tape up from the rear case , and remove it from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel up the edge of the tape covering the button ribbon cable. Use tweezers or your fingers to peel the tape up from the rear case, and remove it from the iPod.

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation Button Ribbon Cable Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

three 2.6 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws

do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, as it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

Lines.Text: flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back .
use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board .
this cable is very delicate ; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back. Steps.Text_raw: Remove the logic board assembly from the rear case of the iPod.

Lines.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame .
gently twist the spudger to free the camera .
lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket , and remove it from the ipod touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame. Gently twist the spudger to free the camera. Lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket, and remove it from the iPod Touch.

run the spudger along the full length of the tape to disconnect it from the rear case .

use tweezers or your fingers to peel the tape up from the rear case , and remove it from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel up the edge of the tape covering the button ribbon cable. Use tweezers or your fingers to peel the tape up from the rear case, and remove it from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the button ribbon cable to the rear case of the ipod :
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.3 mm 000 phillips screws
one 1.6 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the button ribbon cable to the rear case of the iPod: Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screws One 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: use tweezers to remove the small metal backing plate from the power switch section of the button ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to remove the small metal backing plate from the power switch section of the button ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: insert a plastic opening tool into the rear-facing camera frame and pry up against the rear case .
twist the plastic opening tool slightly counter-clockwise to pry the camera frame up from the rear case .
only pry enough to lift the camera frame from the rear case ; the rest of the cable is still adhered to the rear case and may break .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a plastic opening tool into the rear-facing camera frame and pry up against the rear case. Lines.Text: the power/sleep button may fall out of the rear case and should be removed at this point .
use the closed tip of a pair of tweezers to push the power/sleep button into the rear case .
use tweezers to remove the power button from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board .

the display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board .
use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board .
this cable is very delicate ; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna .

Title: iPod Touch 5th Generation Rear Case Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.
