Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device , lay the display assembly flat so you can access the back of the home button .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the rubber membrane up from around the home button .

Steps.Text_raw: Being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device, lay the display assembly flat so you can access the back of the home button. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the rubber membrane up from around the home button.

Lines.Text: once you've pried enough to tilt the button up and grab it , gently lift it up from the display assembly , pulling slowly to avoid tearing the rubber .
remove the home button from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you've pried enough to tilt the button up and grab it, gently lift it up from the display assembly, pulling slowly to avoid tearing the rubber. Remove the home button from the iPod.

Subject: Home Button

remove the battery plate .
place your finger at the bottom of the battery .
lift up on the battery until it pops out from the lyra x2400.

disconnect the screen's ribbon cable from the circuit board .
remove the screen .

Title: Removing Creative Zen Vision W Back Cover

Lines.Text: push the black button and slide the battery casing to the left simultaneously , until the battery is completely separated from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the black button and slide the battery casing to the left simultaneously, until the battery is completely separated from the device.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws ( 3.5 mm ) on the compact flash insert , located on the left hand side , with a phillips 000 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2 screws (3.5 mm) on the Compact Flash insert, located on the left hand side, with a Phillips #000 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the 5 screws ( 5.5 mm ) , circled in red , using a phillips 0. use a flashlight if necessary .
peel off the sticker that says creative warranty void if broken and remove the screw ( 5.5 mm ) underneath with a phillips 0.
be careful , some of the screws are difficult to see and can be easily stripped .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 5 screws (5.5 mm), circled in red, using a Phillips #0. Use a flashlight if necessary. Peel off the sticker that says "Creative warranty void if broken" and remove the screw (5.5 mm) underneath with a Phillips #0. Be careful, some of the screws are difficult to see and can be easily stripped.

Lines.Text: carefully pull the back cover off of the rest of the device .
the volume control buttons and power slider may fall off when removing the cover , do not lose these small pieces .
the usb input cover on the bottom of the device may also fall off .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pull the back cover off of the rest of the device. The volume control buttons and power slider may fall off when removing the cover, do not lose these small pieces. The USB input cover on the bottom of the device may also fall off.

Lines.Text: locate the microphone component on your lyra x2400. if you are having difficulty locating this component the picture to the left will show you where it is located .
start using solder/desolder tools to remove the microphone .
once removed replace it with the new working microphone .
use the soldering tools to reattach the component back to the main logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the microphone component on your Lyra X2400. If you are having difficulty locating this component the picture to the left will show you where it is located. Start using solder/desolder tools to remove the microphone. Once removed replace it with the new working microphone. Use the soldering tools to reattach the component back to the main logic board.

remove the ribbon cable from the keypad .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a small flat head screw driver to slide the white tabs away from the ribbon cable connection. Remove the ribbon cable from the keypad.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws ( 3.5 mm ) on the compact flash insert , located on the left hand side , with a phillips 000 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2 screws (3.5 mm) on the Compact Flash insert, located on the left hand side, with a Phillips #000 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the 5 screws ( 5.5 mm ) , circled in red , using a phillips 0. use a flashlight if necessary .
peel off the sticker that says creative warranty void if broken and remove the screw ( 5.5 mm ) underneath with a phillips 0.
be careful , some of the screws are difficult to see and can be easily stripped .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 5 screws (5.5 mm), circled in red, using a Phillips #0. Use a flashlight if necessary. Peel off the sticker that says "Creative warranty void if broken" and remove the screw (5.5 mm) underneath with a Phillips #0. Be careful, some of the screws are difficult to see and can be easily stripped.

Lines.Text: carefully pull the back cover off of the rest of the device .
the volume control buttons and power slider may fall off when removing the cover , do not lose these small pieces .
the usb input cover on the bottom of the device may also fall off .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pull the back cover off of the rest of the device. The volume control buttons and power slider may fall off when removing the cover, do not lose these small pieces. The USB input cover on the bottom of the device may also fall off.

Lines.Text: remove 4 screws ( 3.5 mm ) on the metal cover with a phillips 0.
lift the metal cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove 4 screws (3.5 mm) on the metal cover with a Phillips #0. Lift the metal cover off.

Lines.Text: lift the white and black ribbon connection off of the motherboard .
the hard drive can now be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the white and black ribbon connection off of the motherboard. The hard drive can now be removed.

Lines.Text: remove 2 screws ( 3.5 mm ) on the black compact flash input using a phillips 0.

Steps.Text_raw: Remove 2 screws (3.5 mm) on the black compact flash input using a Phillips #0.

Lines.Text: use a small flat head screwdriver to bend the plastic tab holding the compact flash input in place .
the compact flash input should pop off easily , be careful not to break it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a small flat head screwdriver to bend the plastic tab holding the compact flash input in place. The compact flash input should pop off easily, be careful not to break it.

Lines.Text: turn the device over so the side where the screen was is facing up .
push on the motherboard lightly to separate it from the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device over so the side where the screen was is facing up. Push on the motherboard lightly to separate it from the casing.

Lines.Text: turn the device over again and pull on the motherboard very lightly .
the speaker will be covered in a black glue and you must cut through this in order to remove the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the device over again and pull on the motherboard very lightly. The speaker will be covered in a black glue and you must cut through this in order to remove the motherboard.

Lines.Text: turn the speaker on its side so it can fit through the casing and the motherboard can be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the speaker on its side so it can fit through the casing and the motherboard can be removed.

Lines.Text: you have now removed the motherboard .
speaker

Steps.Text_raw: You have now removed the motherboard. Speaker

Subject: Motherboard

Title: RCA Lyra X2400 USB port replacement

Lines.Text: remove two phillips screws from the silver cover at the top of the lyra .
slowly wiggle the silver cover while pulling it away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove two Phillips screws from the silver cover at the top of the Lyra. Slowly wiggle the silver cover while pulling it away from the device.

Lines.Text: remove two phillips screws from the bottom of the device , next to the charger port and compact flash release button .
pull the silver case from the bottom of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove two Phillips screws from the bottom of the device, next to the charger port and Compact Flash release button. Pull the silver case from the bottom of the device.

Lines.Text: carefully pry up the screen with a plastic opening tool .
disconnect the screen's ribbon cable from the circuit board .
remove the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pry up the screen with a plastic opening tool. Disconnect the screen's ribbon cable  from the circuit board. Remove the screen.

Lines.Text: open the case of the lyra .
remove the four screws that secure the motherboard to the frame of the lyra x2400.

Steps.Text_raw: Open the case of the Lyra. Remove the four screws that secure the motherboard to the frame of the Lyra X2400.

Lines.Text: locate the usb in/out component on your lyra x2400. if you are having difficulty locating this component the picture to the left will show you where it is located .
start using solder/desolder tools to remove the usb in/out .
once removed replace it with the new working usb in/out .
use the soldering tools to reattach the component back to the main logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the USB in/out component on your Lyra X2400. If you are having difficulty locating this component the picture to the left will show you where it is located. Start using solder/desolder tools to remove the USB in/out. Once removed replace it with the new working USB in/out. Use the soldering tools to reattach the component back to the main logic board.

Subject: USB in/out

slowly wiggle the silver cover while pulling it away from the device .

pull the silver case from the bottom of the device .

disconnect the screen's ribbon cable from the circuit board .
remove the screen .

remove the four screws that secure the motherboard to the frame of the lyra x2400.

Steps.Text_raw: Open the case of the Lyra. Remove the four screws that secure the motherboard to the frame of the Lyra X2400.

Lines.Text: locate the audio jack on the lyra x2400. if you have difficulty locating this component look at the picture to the left .
start using the solder/desolder tools to remove this component .
once removed replace the old audio jack with a new audio jack .
use soldering tools to reattach this component back to the main logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the audio jack on the Lyra X2400. If you have difficulty locating this component look at the picture to the left. Start using the solder/desolder tools to remove this component. Once removed replace the old audio jack with a new audio jack. Title: RCA Lyra X2400 DC Power Adaptor Replacement

Lines.Text: using slight pressure with your finger on the word open , slide the battery plate down .
remove the battery plate .
place your finger at the bottom of the battery .
lift up on the battery until it pops out from the lyra x2400.

Steps.Text_raw: Using slight pressure with your finger on the word "OPEN", slide the battery plate down. Remove the battery plate. Place your finger at the bottom of the battery. Lift up on the battery until it pops out from the LYRA X2400.

slowly wiggle the silver cover while pulling it away from the device .

remove the four screws that secure the motherboard to the frame of the lyra x2400.

start using solder/desolder tools to remove the dc power adaptor .
once removed replace it with the new working dc power adaptor .
use the soldering tools to reattach the component back to the main logic board .

remove the battery plate .

lift up on the battery until it pops out from the lyra x2400.

Lines.Text: locate the compact flash card slot on the logic board . for assistance on locating this component look at the picture to the left .
use soldering/desoldering tools to remove the compact flash card .
replace compact flash card and use soldering tools to complete the replacement .

Lines.Text: unplug the device from the wall outlet , and turn it over so that the buttons are on a flat surface .
use your fingers to pinch the tab in the direction of the open arrow until tab is loose . pull the tab vertically to remove it .
remove the battery cover and the batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the device from the wall outlet, and turn it over so that the buttons are on a flat surface. Use your fingers to pinch the tab in the direction of the "Open" arrow until tab is loose. Pull the tab vertically to remove it. Remove the battery cover and the batteries.

Lines.Text: slide a spudger under the two front rubber pads to expose two hidden screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide a spudger under the two front rubber pads to expose two hidden screws.

Lines.Text: remove the following eight screws :
four 15.1 mm phillips 2 screws near the front of the device .
four 12.7 mm phillips 2 screws near the back of the device .
the slots for the four 12.7 mm screws are very narrow , so you will need a slender , phillips 2 screwdriver that does not feature replaceable heads in order to reach them .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following eight screws: Four 15.1 mm Phillips #2 screws near the front of the device. Four 12.7 mm Phillips #2 screws near the back of the device. The slots for the four 12.7 mm screws are very narrow, so you will need a slender, Phillips #2 screwdriver that does not feature replaceable heads in order to reach them.

Lines.Text: turn the ihome 180 degrees so the speaker grille is facing you . carefully lift the bottom case away from the rest of the body and tilt it as shown .
be careful and do not yank the bottom case . a white ribbon wire is the only thing that connects the bottom case to the rest of the device .
using a pair of tweezers , detach the white ribbon cable . make sure to pull on the ribbon , not on the head .
the lower case can now be completely removed from the device !

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees so the speaker grille is facing you. Carefully lift the bottom case away from the rest of the body and tilt it as shown. Be careful and do not yank the bottom case. A white ribbon wire is the only thing that connects the bottom case to the rest of the device. Using a pair of tweezers, detach the white ribbon cable. Make sure to pull on the ribbon, not on the head. The lower case can now be completely removed from the device!

Lines.Text: remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard :
two 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws near the speaker grille .
two 14.3 mm phillips 2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard .
it is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard: Two 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws near the speaker grille. Two 14.3 mm Phillips #2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard. It is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device.

Lines.Text: turn the ihome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case .
prying the motherboard assembly from the upper case will require a good amount of force . be very careful not to break the case , or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside .
pulling outwards on the sides of the upper casing can help loosen the assembly .
if it seems too difficult to remove , chances are that a screw is still attached . make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step .
pull the back adapter cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case. Prying the Motherboard Assembly from the Upper Case will require a good amount of force. Be very careful not to break the case, or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside. Pulling outwards on the sides of the Upper Casing can help loosen the assembly. If it seems too difficult to remove, chances are that a screw is still attached. Make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step. Pull the back adapter cover off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case .
only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the ipod adapter later on :
two 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws near the center of the adapter . these screws have built in washers .
one 4.0 mm phillips 1 screw near the center of the adapter .
the ipod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case. Only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the iPod Adapter later on: Two 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws near the  center of the adapter. These screws have built in washers. One 4.0 mm Phillips #1 screw near the center of the adapter. The iPod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing.

Lines.Text: with the back of the ihome is facing you , tilt the motherboard assembly upwards as shown .
do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables . make sure not to pull on the heads , but on the ribbons themselves .
use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables .

Steps.Text_raw: With the back of the iHome is facing you, tilt the Motherboard Assembly upwards as shown. Do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables. Make sure not to pull on the heads, but on the ribbons themselves. Use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables.

Lines.Text: pull the speakers , motherboard , and ipod adapter up and away from the lower casing .
you have now separated your ihome's inner workings from its protective case !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the speakers, motherboard, and iPod adapter up and away from the lower casing. You have now separated your iHome's inner workings from its protective case!

Lines.Text: remove the eight 7.9 mm phillips 1 screws from the center board .
use tweezers to carefully remove the largest circuit board .
you should be able to easily lift the buttons away .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight 7.9 mm Phillips #1 screws from the center board. Use tweezers to carefully remove the largest circuit board. You should be able to easily lift the buttons away.

Lines.Text: unplug the device from the wall outlet , and turn it over so that the buttons are on a flat surface .
use your fingers to pinch the tab in the direction of the open arrow until tab is loose . pull the tab vertically to remove it .
remove the battery cover and the batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees so the speaker grille is facing you. Carefully lift the bottom case away from the rest of the body and tilt it as shown. Be careful and do not yank the bottom case. A white ribbon wire is the only thing that connects the bottom case to the rest of the device. Using a pair of tweezers, detach the white ribbon cable. Make sure to pull on the ribbon, not on the head. The lower case can now be completely removed from the device!

Lines.Text: remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard :
two 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws near the speaker grille .
two 14.3 mm phillips 2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard .
it is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard: Two 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws near the speaker grille. Two 14.3 mm Phillips #2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard. It is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device.

Lines.Text: turn the ihome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case .
prying the motherboard assembly from the upper case will require a good amount of force . be very careful not to break the case , or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside .
pulling outwards on the sides of the upper casing can help loosen the assembly .
if it seems too difficult to remove , chances are that a screw is still attached . make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step .
pull the back adapter cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case. Prying the Motherboard Assembly from the Upper Case will require a good amount of force. Be very careful not to break the case, or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside. Pulling outwards on the sides of the Upper Casing can help loosen the assembly. If it seems too difficult to remove, chances are that a screw is still attached. Make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step. Pull the back adapter cover off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case .
only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the ipod adapter later on :
two 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws near the center of the adapter . these screws have built in washers .
one 4.0 mm phillips 1 screw near the center of the adapter .
the ipod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case. Only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the iPod Adapter later on: Two 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws near the  center of the adapter. These screws have built in washers. One 4.0 mm Phillips #1 screw near the center of the adapter. The iPod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing.

Lines.Text: with the back of the ihome is facing you , tilt the motherboard assembly upwards as shown .
do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables . make sure not to pull on the heads , but on the ribbons themselves .
use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables .

Steps.Text_raw: With the back of the iHome is facing you, tilt the Motherboard Assembly upwards as shown. Do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables. Make sure not to pull on the heads, but on the ribbons themselves. Use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables.

Lines.Text: pull the speakers , motherboard , and ipod adapter up and away from the lower casing .
you have now separated your ihome's inner workings from its protective case !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the speakers, motherboard, and iPod adapter up and away from the lower casing. You have now separated your iHome's inner workings from its protective case!

Lines.Text: remove the three 7.9 mm phillips 1 screws holding the scroll wheel circuit board in place .
repeat for the other circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 7.9 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the scroll wheel circuit board in place. Repeat for the other circuit board.

Lines.Text: firmly press on the center of each scroll wheel to remove them .
you have successfully removed the scroll wheels !

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly press on the center of each scroll wheel to remove them. You have successfully removed the scroll wheels!

Lines.Text: unplug the device from the wall outlet , and turn it over so that the buttons are on a flat surface .
use your fingers to pinch the tab in the direction of the open arrow until tab is loose . pull the tab vertically to remove it .
remove the battery cover and the batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the device from the wall outlet, and turn it over so that the buttons are on a flat surface. Use your fingers to pinch the tab in the direction of the "Open" arrow until tab is loose. Pull the tab vertically to remove it. Remove the battery cover and the batteries.

four 12.7 mm phillips 2 screws near the back of the device .
the slots for the four 12.7 mm screws are very narrow , so you will need a slender , phillips 2 screwdriver that does not feature replaceable heads in order to reach them .

do not pull apart the red wire connecting the battery to the device .

be careful to not tear the wires while opening the case .

do not disconnect wires from plastic connector .

Lines.Text: before taking apart the id95 , disconnect the ac cord from the wall socket and ac adapter from the dc jack . remove any ipods , iphones , and ipads attached to the device .
flip over the id95 so the bottom cover is visible and the lcd screen is facing you .

Steps.Text_raw: Before taking apart the iD95, disconnect the AC cord from the wall socket and AC adapter from the DC jack. Remove any iPods, iPhones, and iPads attached to the device. Flip over the iD95 so the bottom cover is visible and the LCD screen is facing you.

Lines.Text: remove the 10 mm-length , 5 mm-head screw using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 10 mm-length, 5 mm-head screw using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to take out the backup battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to take out the backup battery.

Lines.Text: unscrew five 17 mm-length , 6 mm-head screws using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew five 17 mm-length, 6 mm-head screws using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: the bottom cover is attached to the back cover by two plastic clips . don't use excessive force .
insert a plastic opening tool between the edge of the bottom cover and the main body .
gently pry the bottom cover from the body . start anywhere along the front side of the id95 and work your way around .
grip the bottom portion of the device and gently lift the front part of the bottom cover a couple centimeters up .

Steps.Text_raw: The bottom cover is attached to the back cover by two plastic clips. Don't use excessive force. Insert a plastic opening tool between the edge of the bottom cover and the main body. Gently pry the bottom cover from the body. Start anywhere along the front side of the iD95 and work your way around. Grip the bottom portion of the device and gently lift the front part of the bottom cover a couple centimeters up.

Lines.Text: be careful not to use too much force or you might break the plastic rings holding the side panels in place .
lift up the bottom cover . pull the side panel up first , out , and away from the device .
the side panels have plastic rings that will need to be lifted up and off the cylinders they are placed around .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful not to use too much force or you might break the plastic rings holding the side panels in place. Lift up the bottom cover. Pull the side panel up first, out, and away from the device. The side panels have plastic rings that will need to be lifted up and off the cylinders they are placed around.

Lines.Text: apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel.

Lines.Text: locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together .
which clip you remove first is up to you . rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right . insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover .
place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open . this may take repeated attempts .
this is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor . if possible , have someone hold the device or provide lighting .
once a clip has been removed , hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place . one clip remains to be removed ; you are almost there !

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together. Which clip you remove first is up to you. Rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right. Insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover. Place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open. This may take repeated attempts. This is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor. If possible, have someone hold the device or provide lighting. Once a clip has been removed, hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place. One clip remains to be removed; you are almost there!

Lines.Text: use the same steps to remove the remaining clip .
the bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the same steps to remove the remaining clip. The bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board .
don't pull the wires . take your time using a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board. Don't pull the wires. Take your time using a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: before opening your audiovox , be sure to turn it upside down .
begin by applying constant pressure to the base of your audiovox while holding the plastic casing . do this until the plastic casing is completely removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Before opening your Audiovox, be sure to turn it upside down. Begin by applying constant pressure to the base of your Audiovox while holding the plastic casing. Do this until the plastic casing is completely removed.

Lines.Text: insert a phillips 1 screwdriver into the hole at the corner of the base and remove the screw .
repeat this step for the remaining other three screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a Phillips #1 screwdriver into the hole at the corner of the base and remove the screw. Repeat this step for the remaining other three screws.

Lines.Text: make sure to orient the audiovox right side up .
gently pull off the top panel of the audiovox , as shown in the picture , to ensure that the panel detaches properly .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure to orient the Audiovox right side up. Gently pull off the top panel of the Audiovox, as shown in the picture, to ensure that the panel detaches properly.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the screw found in the middle of the board .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the screw found in the middle of the board.

Lines.Text: gently , as to not disconnect any of the attached wires , pull back the board to view the soldered connections ( on the other side ) as well as the internal components .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently, as to not disconnect any of the attached wires, pull back the board to view the soldered connections (on the other side) as well as the internal components.

Lines.Text: one by one , de-solder the two wires that connect the power adapter to your audiovox .
if you don't know how to solder , check out guide750.
soldering irons are extremely hot and can burn you if you touch them !
if you hold the soldering iron tip at the same spot for too long , it can strip the metal from the plastic board . you may not be able to solder wire to that point again .

Steps.Text_raw: One by one, de-solder the two wires that connect the power adapter to your Audiovox. If you don't know how to solder, check out [guide|750]. Soldering irons are extremely hot and can burn you if you touch them! If you hold the soldering iron tip at the same spot for too long, it can strip the metal from the plastic board. You may not be able to solder wire to that point again.

Lines.Text: insert the wires of the new adapter into the designated holes and solder them into place .
if you don't know how to solder , check out guide750.
soldering irons are extremely hot and can burn you if you touch them !
if you hold the soldering iron tip at the same spot for too long , it can strip the metal from the plastic board . you may not be able to solder wire to that point again .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees so the speaker grille is facing you. Carefully lift the bottom case away from the rest of the body and tilt it as shown. Be careful and do not yank the bottom case. A white ribbon wire is the only thing that connects the bottom case to the rest of the device. Using a pair of tweezers, detach the white ribbon cable. Make sure to pull on the ribbon, not on the head. The lower case can now be completely removed from the device!

Lines.Text: remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard :
two 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws near the speaker grille .
two 14.3 mm phillips 2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard .
it is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws attaching the top of the case to the motherboard: Two 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws near the speaker grille. Two 14.3 mm Phillips #2 screws that sit in recesses under the motherboard. It is useful to use a screwdriver with a magnetic tip so that the screws don't get lost inside the device.

Lines.Text: turn the ihome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case .
prying the motherboard assembly from the upper case will require a good amount of force . be very careful not to break the case , or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside .
pulling outwards on the sides of the upper casing can help loosen the assembly .
if it seems too difficult to remove , chances are that a screw is still attached . make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step .
pull the back adapter cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case. Prying the Motherboard Assembly from the Upper Case will require a good amount of force. Be very careful not to break the case, or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside. Pulling outwards on the sides of the Upper Casing can help loosen the assembly. If it seems too difficult to remove, chances are that a screw is still attached. Make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step. Pull the back adapter cover off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case .
only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the ipod adapter later on :
two 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws near the center of the adapter . these screws have built in washers .
one 4.0 mm phillips 1 screw near the center of the adapter .
the ipod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case. Only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the iPod Adapter later on: Two 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws near the  center of the adapter. These screws have built in washers. One 4.0 mm Phillips #1 screw near the center of the adapter. The iPod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing.

Lines.Text: with the back of the ihome is facing you , tilt the motherboard assembly upwards as shown .
do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables . make sure not to pull on the heads , but on the ribbons themselves .
use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables .

Steps.Text_raw: With the back of the iHome is facing you, tilt the Motherboard Assembly upwards as shown. Do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables. Make sure not to pull on the heads, but on the ribbons themselves. Use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables.

Lines.Text: pull the speakers , motherboard , and ipod adapter up and away from the lower casing .
you have now separated your ihome's inner workings from its protective case !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the speakers, motherboard, and iPod adapter up and away from the lower casing. You have now separated your iHome's inner workings from its protective case!

Lines.Text: remove the two 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws that connect the speakers to the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws that connect the speakers to the motherboard.

Lines.Text: disengage the clips on both sides of the speaker grille to separate the speakers from the rest of the assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Disengage the clips on both sides of the speaker grille to separate the speakers from the rest of the assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws from the front plate of each speaker .
use a spudger to pry the cone and front plate from the speaker's plastic casing .
congratulations , you have now removed the speakers !

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws from the front plate of each speaker. Use a spudger to pry the cone and front  plate from the speaker's plastic casing. Congratulations, you have now removed the speakers!

Lines.Text: before opening your audiovox , be sure to turn it upside down .
begin by applying constant pressure to the base of your audiovox while holding the plastic casing . do this until the plastic casing is completely removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Before opening your Audiovox, be sure to turn it upside down. Begin by applying constant pressure to the base of your Audiovox while holding the plastic casing. Do this until the plastic casing is completely removed.

Lines.Text: insert a phillips 1 screwdriver into the hole at the corner of the base and remove the screw .
repeat this step for the remaining other three screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a Phillips #1 screwdriver into the hole at the corner of the base and remove the screw. Repeat this step for the remaining other three screws.

Lines.Text: make sure to orient the audiovox right side up .
gently pull off the top panel of the audiovox , as shown in the picture , to ensure that the panel detaches properly .

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the screw found in the middle of the board .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the screw found in the middle of the board.

Lines.Text: gently , as to not disconnect any of the attached wires , pull back the board to view the soldered connections ( on the other side ) as well as the internal components .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently, as to not disconnect any of the attached wires, pull back the board to view the soldered connections (on the other side) as well as the internal components.

Lines.Text: notice that there are two speakers located on opposite sides of the inside of your audiovox .
slide a plastic opening tool along the rim of the faulty speaker where it meets the plastic casing .
this action removes any glue or adhesive that holds the speaker to the wall of your audiovox .

Steps.Text_raw: Notice that there are two speakers located on opposite sides of the inside of your Audiovox. Lines.Text: using your thumb , applying constant pressure , pull back the plastic tab towards the speaker and away from the metal bracket .
simultaneously insert a phillips 00 screwdriver into the square hole on the underside of clock and push through to lift the metal bracket off of the plastic tab .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your thumb, applying constant pressure, pull back the plastic tab towards the speaker and away from the metal bracket. Lines.Text: pull up on the metal brackets , found on either side , until the speaker is completely removed . removing the speaker is rather challenging . don't get discouraged if it takes multiple attempts !
each speaker contains a powerful magnet . try to keep them away from nearby metal objects .

soldering irons are extremely hot and can burn you if you touch them !
if you hold the soldering iron tip at the same spot for too long , it can strip the metal from the plastic board . you may not be able to solder wire to that point again .

electrical connectors
ribbon connectors

pull the back adapter cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the iHome 180 degrees and carefully pull up on speaker cases to pry them loose from the bottom case. Prying the Motherboard Assembly from the Upper Case will require a good amount of force. Be very careful not to break the case, or yank on any of the ribbon wires attached to the underside. Pulling outwards on the sides of the Upper Casing can help loosen the assembly. If it seems too difficult to remove, chances are that a screw is still attached. Make sure you've removed every screw listed before proceeding to this step. Pull the back adapter cover off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case .
only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the ipod adapter later on :
two 6.4 mm phillips 1 screws near the center of the adapter . these screws have built in washers .
one 4.0 mm phillips 1 screw near the center of the adapter .
the ipod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws holding the adapter to the outer case. Only remove the following screws if you are planning on taking apart the iPod Adapter later on: Two 6.4 mm Phillips #1 screws near the  center of the adapter. These screws have built in washers. One 4.0 mm Phillips #1 screw near the center of the adapter. The iPod adapter should now be separate from the upper casing.

Lines.Text: with the back of the ihome is facing you , tilt the motherboard assembly upwards as shown .
do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables . make sure not to pull on the heads , but on the ribbons themselves .
use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables .

Steps.Text_raw: With the back of the iHome is facing you, tilt the Motherboard Assembly upwards as shown. Do not yank or jerk these ribbon cables. Make sure not to pull on the heads, but on the ribbons themselves. Use tweezers to remove the 6 ribbon cables.

Lines.Text: pull the speakers , motherboard , and ipod adapter up and away from the lower casing .
you have now separated your ihome's inner workings from its protective case !

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the speakers, motherboard, and iPod adapter up and away from the lower casing. You have now separated your iHome's inner workings from its protective case!

Title: Insignia Sport NS-4V17 Front Case Cover Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the 3 mm phillips 00 screw on the back of the insignia ns-4 v17.

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 3mm Phillips #00 screw on the back of the Insignia NS-4v17.

Lines.Text: detach the back cover by carefully pulling up and out on the back plastic casing .
do not pull apart the red wire connecting the battery to the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Detach the back cover by carefully pulling up and out on the back plastic casing. Do not pull apart the red wire connecting the battery to the device.

Lines.Text: use the plastic opening tool to reach underneath the battery , opposite from the side with the red wire , and remove it from its plastic case .
be careful to not tear the wires while opening the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the plastic opening tool to reach underneath the battery, opposite from the side with the red wire, and remove it from its plastic case. Be careful to not tear the wires while opening the case.

Lines.Text: reach under the white plastic wire connector using the plastic opening tool and disconnect it from the socket .
do not disconnect wires from plastic connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach under the white plastic wire connector using the plastic opening tool and disconnect it from the socket. Do not disconnect wires from plastic connector.

Lines.Text: remove the four corner plastic covers on the back of the device using the plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four corner plastic covers on the back of the device using the plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 00 screwdriver remove all four 4.5 mm corner screws located underneath the corner pads .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Philips #00 screwdriver remove all four 4.5mm  corner screws located underneath the corner pads.

Lines.Text: carefully wedge the plastic opening tool into either long side of the device .
slowly move the plastic opening tool along the side of the device , separating the front and back case covers .
repeat these steps on the other side of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully wedge the plastic opening tool into either long side of the device. Slowly move the plastic opening tool along the side of the device, separating the front and back case covers. Repeat these steps on the other side of the device.

Lines.Text: once the front cover is loose , use your fingers to remove the front case cover for a new installation .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the front cover is loose, use your fingers to remove the front case cover for a new installation.

Title: XtremeMac Luna Button Circuit Boards Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the device over so that the batteries are closest to you .
remove the battery lid by pressing the battery cover's tab and pulling it away from the device .
push the battery against the spring and lift it out of the casing .
repeat with the other battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device over so that the batteries are closest to you. Remove the battery lid by pressing the battery cover's tab and pulling it away from the device. Push the battery against the spring and lift it out of the casing. Repeat with the other battery.

Lines.Text: unscrew all eight 12 mm phillips head screws with a phillips 1 screwdriver .
the ifixit 26 bit screwdriver kit will not reach the screws . make sure to use a screwdriver that is thin enough to not get stuck in the screw holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew all eight 12mm Phillips head screws with a Philips #1 screwdriver. The iFixit 26 bit screwdriver kit will not reach the screws.  Make sure to use a screwdriver that is thin enough to not get stuck in the screw holes.

Lines.Text: flip the luna back over so that the buttons are facing upward and the lcd screen is facing you .
gently tilt the lid back 45 degrees so that the inside is exposed .
be mindful of the wires inside of the luna . it is easy to break a connection if a wire gets caught .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Luna back over so that the buttons are facing upward and the LCD screen is facing you. Gently tilt the lid back 45 degrees so that the inside is exposed. Be mindful of the wires inside of the Luna. It is easy to break a connection if a wire gets caught.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four black 7 mm screws with the phillips 1 screwdriver that hold the middle circuit board to the top case .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four black 7mm screws with the Phillips #1 screw driver that hold the middle circuit board to the top case.

Lines.Text: unscrew the three 7 mm black screws using the phillips 1 screwdriver on the back end of the left and right circuit board .
removing the right circuit board first will make it easier to unscrew the left because the heat-sinks on the left circuit board can get in the way of the screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the three 7 mm black screws using the Philips #1 screwdriver on the back end of the left and right circuit board. Removing the right circuit board first will make it easier to unscrew the left because the heat-sinks on the left circuit board can get in the way of the screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry the black connections away from the top casing .
be attentive when you separate the circuit boards from the top , as there is a loose wheel inside .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry the black connections away from the top casing. Be attentive when you separate the circuit boards from the top, as there is a loose wheel inside.

Lines.Text: turn the circuit boards over . remove the two connections on the left side by pulling on the tabs .
the glue that holds the connection together will come off when you pull . pull on the tab with enough force to break the glue without damaging the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the circuit boards over. Remove the two connections on the left side by pulling on the tabs. The glue that holds the connection together will come off when you pull. Pull on the tab with enough force to break the glue without damaging the wires.

Subject: Button Circuit Boards

Lines.Text: before taking apart the id95 , disconnect the ac cord from the wall socket and ac adapter from the dc jack . remove any ipods , iphones , and ipads attached to the device .
flip over the id95 so the bottom cover is visible and the lcd screen is facing you .

Steps.Text_raw: Before taking apart the iD95, disconnect the AC cord from the wall socket and AC adapter from the DC jack. Remove any iPods, iPhones, and iPads attached to the device. Flip over the iD95 so the bottom cover is visible and the LCD screen is facing you.

Lines.Text: remove the 10 mm-length , 5 mm-head screw using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 10 mm-length, 5 mm-head screw using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to take out the backup battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to take out the backup battery.

Lines.Text: unscrew five 17 mm-length , 6 mm-head screws using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew five 17 mm-length, 6 mm-head screws using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: the bottom cover is attached to the back cover by two plastic clips . don't use excessive force .
insert a plastic opening tool between the edge of the bottom cover and the main body .
gently pry the bottom cover from the body . start anywhere along the front side of the id95 and work your way around .
grip the bottom portion of the device and gently lift the front part of the bottom cover a couple centimeters up .

Steps.Text_raw: The bottom cover is attached to the back cover by two plastic clips. Don't use excessive force. Insert a plastic opening tool between the edge of the bottom cover and the main body. Gently pry the bottom cover from the body. Start anywhere along the front side of the iD95 and work your way around. Grip the bottom portion of the device and gently lift the front part of the bottom cover a couple centimeters up.

Lines.Text: be careful not to use too much force or you might break the plastic rings holding the side panels in place .
lift up the bottom cover . pull the side panel up first , out , and away from the device .
the side panels have plastic rings that will need to be lifted up and off the cylinders they are placed around .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful not to use too much force or you might break the plastic rings holding the side panels in place. Lift up the bottom cover. Pull the side panel up first, out, and away from the device. The side panels have plastic rings that will need to be lifted up and off the cylinders they are placed around.

Lines.Text: apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel.

Lines.Text: locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together .
which clip you remove first is up to you . rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right . insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover .
place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open . this may take repeated attempts .
this is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor . if possible , have someone hold the device or provide lighting .
once a clip has been removed , hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place . one clip remains to be removed ; you are almost there !

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together. Which clip you remove first is up to you. Rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right. Insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover. Place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open. This may take repeated attempts. This is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor. If possible, have someone hold the device or provide lighting. Once a clip has been removed, hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place. One clip remains to be removed; you are almost there!

Lines.Text: use the same steps to remove the remaining clip .
the bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the same steps to remove the remaining clip. The bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board .
don't pull the wires . take your time using a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board. Don't pull the wires. Take your time using a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: take out four 14 mm screws using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out four 14 mm screws using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to lift the two speaker zip connectors from the logic board .
do not pull on the speaker wires directly . continue to use a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to lift the two speaker zip connectors from the logic board. Do not pull on the speaker wires directly. Continue to use a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: lift and remove both speakers .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift and remove both speakers.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board over .
use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift the ipod adapter zip connector from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board over. Use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift the iPod adapter zip connector from the logic board.

Lines.Text: desolder these 32 joints to detach the hdd data cable from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder these 32 joints to detach the HDD data cable from the logic board.

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful not to use too much force or you might break the plastic rings holding the side panels in place. Lift up the bottom cover. Pull the side panel up first, out, and away from the device. The side panels have plastic rings that will need to be lifted up and off the cylinders they are placed around.

Lines.Text: apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply the same techniques from the previous step to remove the remaining side panel.

Lines.Text: locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together .
which clip you remove first is up to you . rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right . insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover .
place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open . this may take repeated attempts .
this is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor . if possible , have someone hold the device or provide lighting .
once a clip has been removed , hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place . one clip remains to be removed ; you are almost there !

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two plastic clips holding the bottom and back cover together. Which clip you remove first is up to you. Rotate the device 90 degrees either left or right. Insert the flat end of a spudger horizontally between the back speaker and the back cover. Place the flat end of the spudger behind one clip and pry it open. This may take repeated attempts. This is the hardest step because the angle is awkward and the visibility is poor. If possible, have someone hold the device or provide lighting. Once a clip has been removed, hold the bottom cover open so the clip will not fall back into place. One clip remains to be removed; you are almost there!

Lines.Text: use the same steps to remove the remaining clip .
the bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the same steps to remove the remaining clip. The bottom cover is still connected to the logic board by wiring.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board .
don't pull the wires . take your time using a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry off the white zip connector joining the wires to the logic board. Don't pull the wires. Take your time using a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: take out four 14 mm screws using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out four 14 mm screws using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to lift the two speaker zip connectors from the logic board .
do not pull on the speaker wires directly . continue to use a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to lift the two speaker zip connectors from the logic board. Do not pull on the speaker wires directly. Continue to use a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: lift and remove both speakers .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift and remove both speakers.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board over .
use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift the ipod adapter zip connector from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board over. Use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift the iPod adapter zip connector from the logic board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift up the white zip connector holding the lcd screen to the buttons .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry and lift up the white zip connector holding the LCD screen to the buttons.

Lines.Text: gently push the screen away from you to dislodge it from the plastic clip holding it in place and then pull up to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently push the screen away from you to dislodge it from the plastic clip holding it in place and then pull up to remove.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew three , 9.5 mm-length 4 mm-head , screws holding the lcd screen to the screen cover .
remove the screen cover from the lcd .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to unscrew three, 9.5 mm-length 4 mm-head, screws holding the LCD screen to the screen cover. Remove the screen cover from the LCD.

Lines.Text: flip the device over so that the batteries are closest to you .
remove the battery lid by pressing the battery cover's tab and pulling it away from the device .
push the battery against the spring and lift it out of the casing .
repeat with the other battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device over so that the batteries are closest to you. Remove the battery lid by pressing the battery cover's tab and pulling it away from the device. Push the battery against the spring and lift it out of the casing. Repeat with the other battery.

Lines.Text: unscrew all eight 12 mm phillips head screws with a phillips 1 screwdriver .
the ifixit 26 bit screwdriver kit will not reach the screws . make sure to use a screwdriver that is thin enough to not get stuck in the screw holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew all eight 12mm Phillips head screws with a Philips #1 screwdriver. The iFixit 26 bit screwdriver kit will not reach the screws.  Make sure to use a screwdriver that is thin enough to not get stuck in the screw holes.

Lines.Text: flip the luna back over so that the buttons are facing upward and the lcd screen is facing you .
gently tilt the lid back 45 degrees so that the inside is exposed .
be mindful of the wires inside of the luna . it is easy to break a connection if a wire gets caught .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Luna back over so that the buttons are facing upward and the LCD screen is facing you. Gently tilt the lid back 45 degrees so that the inside is exposed. Be mindful of the wires inside of the Luna. It is easy to break a connection if a wire gets caught.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four black 7 mm screws with the phillips 1 screwdriver that hold the middle circuit board to the top case .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four black 7mm screws with the Phillips #1 screw driver that hold the middle circuit board to the top case.

Lines.Text: unscrew the three 7 mm black screws using the phillips 1 screwdriver on the back end of the left and right circuit board .
removing the right circuit board first will make it easier to unscrew the left because the heat-sinks on the left circuit board can get in the way of the screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the three 7 mm black screws using the Philips #1 screwdriver on the back end of the left and right circuit board. Removing the right circuit board first will make it easier to unscrew the left because the heat-sinks on the left circuit board can get in the way of the screwdriver.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry the black connections away from the top casing .
be attentive when you separate the circuit boards from the top , as there is a loose wheel inside .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry the black connections away from the top casing. Be attentive when you separate the circuit boards from the top, as there is a loose wheel inside.

Lines.Text: turn the circuit boards over . remove the two connections on the left side by pulling on the tabs .
the glue that holds the connection together will come off when you pull . pull on the tab with enough force to break the glue without damaging the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the circuit boards over. Remove the two connections on the left side by pulling on the tabs. The glue that holds the connection together will come off when you pull. Pull on the tab with enough force to break the glue without damaging the wires.

Lines.Text: remove the two 12 mm phillips head screws from the back of the device using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 12mm Phillips head screws from the back of the device using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: turn the luna so that the display faces forward .
pull the two white tabs to remove the cables from the front of the radio jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the Luna so that the display faces forward. Pull the two white tabs to remove the cables from the front of the radio jack.

Lines.Text: push the connections through the back casing and lift the radio jack up and out .
reinserting the square am switches can be tricky . make sure they are aligned properly when you are reassembling the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the connections through the back casing and lift the radio jack up and out. Reinserting the square AM switches can be tricky. Make sure they are aligned properly when you are reassembling the device.

Lines.Text: desolder the positive connection ( red ) and the negative connection ( black ) on top of the radio jack to completely remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the positive connection (red) and the negative connection (black) on top of the radio jack to completely remove it.

Lines.Text: before taking apart the id95 , disconnect the ac cord from the wall socket and ac adapter from the dc jack . remove any ipods , iphones , and ipads attached to the device .
flip over the id95 so the bottom cover is visible and the lcd screen is facing you .

insert a plastic opening tool between the edge of the bottom cover and the main body .
gently pry the bottom cover from the body . start anywhere along the front side of the id95 and work your way around .
grip the bottom portion of the device and gently lift the front part of the bottom cover a couple centimeters up .

Title: ilo 1Gb Mp3 Player External volume button and hold switch Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the belt clip by pulling the clip casing up and away from the device starting at the top over the slightly protruding headphones jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the belt clip by pulling the clip casing up and away from the device starting at the top over the slightly protruding headphones jack.

Lines.Text: remove the battery cover by gently pushing inward on the arrow on the cover .
while maintaining pressure push the cover upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery cover by gently pushing inward on the arrow on the cover. While maintaining pressure push the cover upward.

Lines.Text: remove the battery from the socket
when installing the battery take note of the signs displayed in the socket to determine which direction the negative and positive ends should be .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Battery from the socket When installing the battery take note of the signs displayed in the socket to determine which direction the negative and positive ends should be.

Lines.Text: under the cover you will find three ( 3 ) 5 mm screws that will need to be removed . for this you will need to use the 00 screw tip included in your ifixit kit . make sure to keep track of these screws as they will need to be reinserterd during the reassembly of your device .
these screws are different from the two other screws from the interior

Steps.Text_raw: Under the cover you will find Three (3) 5mm screws that will need to be removed. For this you will need to use the PH00 screw tip included in your iFixit kit. Make sure to keep track of these screws as they will need to be reinserterd during the reassembly of your device. These screws are different from the two other screws from the interior

Lines.Text: separate the front housing from the back housing using your thumbs . carefully pry around the edge of the bottom of device then be sure to unhook the clip inside just below the hold switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the front housing from the back housing using your thumbs. Carefully pry around the edge of the bottom of device then be sure to unhook the clip inside just below the hold switch.

Lines.Text: once you have removed the front housing and exposed the internal board and screen locate and remove the two ( 2 ) 4 mm 00 screws on the board .
one is located in the top middle above the screen and the other is located at the bottom left between the stop and back buttons .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have removed the front housing and exposed the internal board and screen locate and Remove the Two (2) 4mm PH00 screws on the board. One is located in the top middle above the screen and the other is located at the bottom left between the Stop and Back buttons.

Lines.Text: once those screws are removed , gently remove the board from the rear casing .
when installing the motherboard into the case be especially careful with the headphone and usb jacks located at the top of the motherboard . these should be slid into their sockets first .

Steps.Text_raw: Once those screws are removed, gently remove the board from the rear casing. When installing the motherboard into the case be especially careful with the headphone and USB jacks located at the top of the motherboard. These should be slid into their sockets first.

Lines.Text: remove the volume button from its rocker socket by gently pushing in on the button until it pops out if the two sockets .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Volume button from its rocker socket by gently pushing in on the button until it pops out if the two sockets.

Lines.Text: remove hold switch from socket by squeezing the prongs that hold the button in the socket together and push the button outward .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove Hold Switch from Socket by squeezing the prongs that hold the button in the socket together and push the button outward.

Subject: External volume button and hold switch

Lines.Text: pry open and pop the clips . note that the bottom two clips are held in with a little bit of rubbery glue . dont rip the face off too quick since there is a ribbon cable you need to disconnect .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry open and pop the clips. Note that the bottom two clips are held in with a little bit of rubbery glue. Don’t rip the face off too quick since there is a ribbon cable you need to disconnect.

Lines.Text: remove ribbon cable connect to the face plate . lift the face off and flip the brown ribbon release flap on the connection on the board . ( the flap in this picture is black , opposite the cable . lift the edge that is closest to you in the picture in order to release the cable . )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove ribbon cable connect to the face plate. Lift the face off and flip the brown ribbon release flap on the connection on the board.  (The flap in this picture is black, opposite the cable.  Lift the edge that is closest to you in the picture in order to release the cable.)

Lines.Text: remove two ( in some versions there are 3 ) screws holding the board down

Steps.Text_raw: Remove two (in some versions there are 3) screws holding the board down

Lines.Text: remove lcd by releasing the 4 clips on each side of the lcd , be carefully to not damage the lcd

Steps.Text_raw: Remove LCD by releasing the 4 clips on each side of the LCD, be carefully to not damage the LCD

Lines.Text: carefully flip the lcd over and disconnect the lcd cable from the board

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully flip the LCD over and disconnect the LCD cable from the board

Lines.Text: remove battery . the battery is taped down with a little double sided tape
if you are replacing the battery just apply a soldering iron to the battery connections on the board and gently pull them off . .
to re-attached the new battery by reheating the old solder and reconnecting the new battery wires
link to a battery clerk - sansa fuze battery
please not if replacing the battery you do not need to remove the board : )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove battery. The battery is taped down with a little double sided tape If you are replacing the battery just apply a soldering iron to the battery connections on the board and gently pull them off.. Lines.Text: there are two parts to the face button panel . the center button or enter is held on by three pins at the top left and right sides and at the bottom left side of the panel ; when you're looking at the device from the inside .
use the bit spanner bit tool to gently pull upward on each of the arms to remove them from the pins .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two parts to the face button panel. The center button or Enter is held on by three pins at the top left and right sides and at the bottom left side of the panel; when you're looking at the device from the inside. Use the bit spanner bit tool to gently pull upward on each of the arms to remove them from the pins.

Lines.Text: the main plate of the face buttons is held on by three arms on pins .
you must first have removed the center button from the pins to access the main plate where it is attached to the same pins .
use the bit spanner bit tool to gently pull upward on each of the arms to remove them from the pins .

Steps.Text_raw: The main plate of the face buttons is held on by Three arms on pins. You must first have removed the center button from the pins to access  the main plate where it is attached to the same pins. Use the bit spanner bit tool to gently pull upward on each of the arms to remove them from the pins.

Lines.Text: all pins that hold the arms of the center button and the main plate of the face buttons have a slight flange at the top acting to hold the arm sockets . this is designed into the device at manufacture and removing the arm sockets will deteriorate the flange .

if removing the buttons for replacement is necessary then after replacement achieving a similar flange may be possible by tapping on the pin after replacement of the arm sockets with the butt of the screwdriver . this might not work though as the pins on our ilo broke off during button removal .

Steps.Text_raw: All pins that hold the arms of the center button and the main plate of the face buttons have a slight flange at the top acting to hold the arm sockets. This is designed into the device at manufacture and removing the arm sockets will deteriorate the flange. If removing the buttons for replacement is necessary then after replacement achieving a similar flange may be possible by tapping on the pin after replacement of the arm sockets with the butt of the screw driver. This might not work though as the pins on our ilo broke off during button removal.
