Title: Opening the Sirius SP-B1 Sportster Boombox

Lines.Text: begin by unscrewing the four recessed screws in the rear of the boombox . they don't seem to be magnetic , and they may not pop out immediately .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by unscrewing the four recessed screws in the rear of the boombox. They don't seem to be magnetic, and they may not pop out immediately.

Lines.Text: next , you will need to remove the mesh that covers the speakers . using the flathead screwdriver , start prying near the top or bottom of the mesh , near the center . the 'corners' come up more easily . once you have part of the mesh pulled out , go around the outside and use indents in the mesh to pry it out . try not to bend the mesh very much .

Steps.Text_raw: Next, you will need to remove the mesh that covers the speakers. Using the flathead screwdriver, start prying near the top or bottom of the mesh, near the center. The 'corners' come up more easily. Once you have part of the mesh pulled out, go around the outside and use indents in the mesh to pry it out. Try not to bend the mesh very much.

Lines.Text: there are screws now accessible near the bottom of each side under the mesh , near the center of the boombox . once you remove these , the faceplate will come right off .

Steps.Text_raw: There are screws now accessible near the bottom of each side under the mesh, near the center of the boombox. Once you remove these, the faceplate will come right off.

Lines.Text: now you can get to some of the electronic components . only eight screws separate you from the inside of the boombox . undo the screws and fix up the inside to your heart's content .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you can get to some of the electronic components. Only eight screws separate you from the inside of the boombox. Undo the screws and fix up the inside to your heart's content.

Title: iPod Nano 7th Generation Front Panel Assembly Replacement

Lines.Text: lay the iopener over the plastic tab to loosen the adhesive . let the bag sit on the device for approximately 90 seconds before attempting to open the panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the iOpener over the plastic tab to loosen the adhesive. Let the bag sit on the device for approximately 90 seconds before attempting to open the panel.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pull the rear plastic cover away from the device until there is enough room to insert a spudger .
insert a spudger under the cover , then pry it up and away from the device .
remove the rear plastic cover from the ipod .
be very careful in removing the plastic cover as the bluetooth antenna is adhered to it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pull the rear plastic cover away from the device until there is enough room to insert a spudger. Insert a spudger under the cover, then pry it up and away from the device. Remove the rear plastic cover from the iPod. Be very careful in removing the plastic cover as the bluetooth antenna is adhered to it.

Lines.Text: gently bend the bluetooth antenna to the right , out of the way of the screws in the bottom of the device .
remove the single 1.4 mm phillips 000 screw from the black plastic spacer .

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger to carefully pry near the lightning connector and under '''all''' parts of the front panel assembly : the front glass/digitizer , the lcd display and the metal midframe .
the adhesive under the metal midframe/display assembly is quite strong and the components are fragile , so go slowly and gently . make sure you do not bend the lcd screen .

Title: iPod Nano 7th Generation Front Glass/Digitizer Replacement

Lines.Text: we recommend that you clean your microwave before proceeding , as any nasty gunk on the bottom may end up stuck to the iopener .
place the iopener in the center of the microwave .
for carousel microwaves : make sure the plate spins freely . if your iopener gets stuck , it may overheat and burn .

Steps.Text_raw: We recommend that you clean your microwave before proceeding, as any nasty gunk on the bottom may end up stuck to the iOpener. Place the iOpener in the center of the microwave. For carousel microwaves: Make sure the plate spins freely. If your iOpener gets stuck, it may overheat and burn.

Lines.Text: heat the iopener for '''thirty seconds''' .
throughout the repair procedure , as the iopener cools , reheat it in the microwave for an additional thirty seconds at a time .
be careful not to overheat the iopener during the repair . overheating may cause the iopener to burst .
never touch the iopener if it appears swollen .

if the iopener is still too hot in the middle to touch , continue using it while waiting for it to cool down some more before reheating . a properly heated iopener should stay warm for up to 10 minutes .

Steps.Text_raw: Heat the iOpener for '''thirty seconds'''. Throughout the repair procedure, as the iOpener cools, reheat it in the microwave for an additional thirty seconds at a time. Be careful not to overheat the iOpener during the repair. Overheating may cause the iOpener to burst. Never touch the iOpener if it appears swollen. If the iOpener is still too hot in the middle to touch, continue using it while waiting for it to cool down some more before reheating. A properly heated iOpener should stay warm for up to 10 minutes.

Lines.Text: remove the iopener from the microwave , holding it by one of the two flat ends to avoid the hot center .
the iopener will be very hot , so be careful when handling it . use an oven mitt if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the iOpener from the microwave, holding it by one of the two flat ends to avoid the hot center. The iOpener will be very hot, so be careful when handling it. Use an oven mitt if necessary.

be very careful in removing the plastic cover as the bluetooth antenna is adhered to it .

Lines.Text: completely separate the front panel assembly from the rest of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Completely separate the front panel assembly from the rest of the device.

Lines.Text: insert a spudger under the metal midframe and display on the left side of the home button .
make sure that the spudger is under the entire display assembly to prevent bending the metal midframe .
rotate the spudger around the home button and across the front panel , releasing the adhesive holding the display in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a spudger under the metal midframe and display on the left side of the home button. Make sure that the spudger is under the entire display assembly to prevent bending the metal midframe. Rotate the spudger around the home button and across the front panel, releasing the adhesive holding the display in place.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive has been released , gently separate the display assembly from the front glass/digitizer .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive has been released, gently separate the display assembly from the front glass/digitizer.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to push the home button gasket toward the center of the button to release the light adhesive .
work your way around the home button in this manner until you can easily remove the button from the front glass .
to prevent tearing the gasket around the home button , do not pry the home button out until the adhesive has been sufficiently loosened .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to push the home button gasket toward the center of the button to release the light adhesive. Lines.Text: remove the home button from the front glass/digitizer .

be very careful in removing the plastic cover as the bluetooth antenna is adhered to it .

Lines.Text: we recommend that you clean your microwave before proceeding , as any nasty gunk on the bottom may end up stuck to the iopener .
place the iopener in the center of the microwave .
for carousel microwaves : make sure the plate spins freely . if your iopener gets stuck , it may overheat and burn .

Lines.Text: heat the iopener for '''thirty seconds''' .
throughout the repair procedure , as the iopener cools , reheat it in the microwave for an additional thirty seconds at a time .
be careful not to overheat the iopener during the repair . overheating may cause the iopener to burst .
never touch the iopener if it appears swollen .

if the iopener is still too hot in the middle to touch , continue using it while waiting for it to cool down some more before reheating . a properly heated iopener should stay warm for up to 10 minutes .

A properly heated iOpener should stay warm for up to 10 minutes.

Lines.Text: completely separate the front panel assembly from the rest of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Completely separate the front panel assembly from the rest of the device.

Lines.Text: flip the battery down over the logic board to gain access to the sleep/power button assembly .
remove the two 1.4 mm phillips 000 screws from the sleep/power button bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the battery down over the logic board to gain access to the sleep/power button assembly. Remove the two 1.4 mm Phillips #000 screws from the sleep/power button bracket.

Lines.Text: remove the bracket with a pair of tweezers .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bracket with a pair of tweezers.

Lines.Text: insert a plastic opening tool under the sleep button , and gently pry upwards to free it from its adhesive .
slide the plastic opening tool along the underside of the sleep button ribbon cable .
continue freeing the ribbon cable until you can access the volume buttons on the left side of the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a plastic opening tool under the sleep button, and gently pry upwards to free it from its adhesive. Slide the plastic opening tool along the underside of the sleep button ribbon cable. Continue freeing the ribbon cable until you can access the volume buttons on the left side of the rear case.

Lines.Text: peel back and remove any tape covering the volume control button assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel back and remove any tape covering  the volume control button assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the three 1.4 mm phillips 000 screws securing the volume control button assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 1.4 mm Phillips #000 screws securing the volume control button assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: use the pointed end of a spudger to pry the volume control button assembly away from the edge of the case .
'''do not''' remove the volume control button assembly from the device entirely ; it is still connected to the logic board assembly by a soldered cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the pointed end of a spudger to pry the volume control button assembly away from the edge of the case. '''Do not''' remove the volume control button assembly from the device entirely; it is still connected to the logic board assembly by a soldered cable.

Lines.Text: using a spudger , gently push the volume rocker into the device from the outside .
the volume rocker is tucked into a thin rubber gasket . try not to stretch the gasket too much as it may tear .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, gently push the volume rocker into the device from the outside. The volume rocker is tucked into a thin rubber gasket. Try not to stretch the gasket too much as it may tear.

Lines.Text: remove the volume rocker from the gasket and rear case .
during reassembly , use the pointed end of a spudger to fold the rubber gasket down away from the side of the case . slip the volume rocker back into its recess and resettle the gasket .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the volume rocker from the gasket and rear case. During reassembly, use the pointed end of a spudger to fold the rubber gasket down away from the side of the case. Slip the volume rocker back into its recess and resettle the gasket.

Subject: Volume Rocker

Title: Disassembling Samsung TFT Color YP-T7J Removing the Front Cover

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws on the back cover using a phillips head 0 screwdriver .

Lines.Text: place the pry tool in-between the front cover and mother board .
gently separate the front cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the pry tool in-between the front cover and mother board. Gently separate the front cover.

Steps.Text_raw: Use the soldering iron to liquefy the solder connecting the microphone to the motherboard.

Lines.Text: the solder and soldering iron will be very hot at this time . do not touch unless wearing protective gloves as you will be burnt .
when not in use , be sure to always elevate the hot end of the soldering iron on a metal stand to prevent incidental burns .

Steps.Text_raw: The solder and soldering iron will be very hot at this time. Do not touch unless wearing protective gloves as you will be burnt. When not in use, be sure to always elevate the hot end of the soldering iron on a metal stand to prevent incidental burns.

Lines.Text: remove the faulty microphone as you heat and melt the soldering points .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the faulty microphone as you heat and melt the soldering points.

Lines.Text: replace the faulty microphone with a new one in working order .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the faulty microphone with a new one in working order.

Lines.Text: with the new microphone in place , use the soldering iron and solder to create a stable connection between the motherboard and microphone .
give the new solder time to cool and harden .

Steps.Text_raw: With the new microphone in place, use the soldering iron and solder to create a stable connection between the motherboard and microphone. Give the new solder time to cool and harden.

Subject: Microphone

Lines.Text: use a 0 phillips head screwdriver to remove the four small black screws from the back of the device .
to ensure you don't lose any tiny parts during the replacement process , place parts on the white magnetic sheet .
once the screws have been removed , proceed to take off back cover .

pull the motherboard out and down away from the top of the phone .

Lines.Text: pry up the small black piece of plastic located between the volume - button and the hold/on button .

Lines.Text: underneath the piece of plastic you just removed , there is a small screw ( phillips 000 , 2.0 mm long ) . use a phillips 000 screwdriver to remove it .

Lines.Text: push on the backplate with both thumbs , sliding it towards the top of the device .
once it begins to move , lift up slightly . you can then slide the backplate all the way off .

Lines.Text: before removing the circuit board , we must remove the ribbon-like wires attached to two sides of the circuit board .
there are two screws ( phillips 000 , 2.0 mm long ) holding in the circuit board . use a phillips 000 screwdriver to take out those screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Before removing the circuit board, we must remove the ribbon-like wires attached to two sides of the circuit board. There are two screws (Phillips #000, 2.0 mm long) holding in the circuit board. Use a Phillips #000 screwdriver to take out those screws.

Lines.Text: the battery is also attached to the circuit board by a cable . the cable is difficult to disconnect with both components in place . it's best to lift the circuit board out partially to give yourself more room to disconnect the connector .
the wire that is connected to the circuit board is connected by a plastic piece with two metal prongs .
use the pointy end of the spudger to place in between the computer board and the plastic piece and gently pry the prongs away from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: The battery is also attached to the circuit board by a cable.  The cable is difficult to disconnect with both components in place.  It's best to lift the circuit board out partially to give yourself more room to disconnect the connector. The wire that is connected to the circuit board is connected by a plastic piece with two metal prongs. Use the pointy end of the spudger to place in between the computer board and the plastic piece and gently pry the prongs away from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: disconnect the battery connector , and then lift the circuit board up .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the battery connector, and then lift the circuit board up.

Lines.Text: finally , disconnect the ribbon cable on the bottom of the circuit board . you can then lift the circuit board all the way out .

Title: Samsung Galaxy Player 4.2 Battery Casing Replacement

Lines.Text: use your finger to press in the battery cover tab on the upper right hand corner of the back of the device .
pry the battery cover off the device by pressing in and lifting up .
when reassembling , align the top portion of the back cover to the top of the device and press down until it clicks into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your finger to press in the battery cover tab on the upper right hand corner of the back of the device. Pry the battery cover off the device by pressing in and lifting up. When reassembling, align the top portion of the back cover to the top of the device and press down until it clicks into place.

Lines.Text: press your finger into the groove on the bottom left hand side of the battery .
pry the battery out by lifting your finger up .

Steps.Text_raw: Press your finger into the groove on the bottom left hand side of the battery. Pry the battery out by lifting your finger up.

Lines.Text: remove the six 2.0 mm phillips 0 screws from the battery casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six 2.0mm Phillips #0 screws from the battery casing.

Lines.Text: starting at the top , insert the plastic opening tool at the seam between the battery casing and the main body of the device .
pry up , working around the seam from top to bottom .
the battery casing fits snuggly against the main body of the device . you may need to apply some moderate force to free it .
the volume button may pop out when you free the battery casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Starting at the top, insert the plastic opening tool at the seam between the battery casing and the main body of the device. Pry up, working around the seam from top to bottom. The battery casing fits snuggly against the main body of the device. You may need to apply some moderate force to free it. The volume button may pop out when you free the battery casing.

Subject: Battery Casing

Lines.Text: before you start remove a possibly inserted flash card !
gently , insert a guitar pick ( or a similar plastic pry tool ) into the upper right corner of the clip+ between the two case halves .
be careful as the plastic is prone to scratches . only use slight force .
with the guitar pick inserted into the two case halves make your way around the edges of the case .
the plastic noses will come off easily .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you start remove a possibly inserted flash card! Gently, insert a guitar pick (or a similar plastic pry tool) into the upper right corner of the Clip+ between the two case halves. Be careful as the plastic is prone to scratches. Only use slight force. With the guitar pick inserted into the two case halves make your way around the edges of the case. The plastic noses will come off easily.

Lines.Text: carefully lift up the battery which is glued to a memory chip .
the battery is wired to the mainboard . be careful to not rip the wires .
identify the three soldering points around the headphone jack that are shown in the second picture . it is likely that at least one of them got loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift up the battery which is glued  to a memory chip. The battery is wired to the mainboard. Be careful to not rip the wires. Identify the three soldering points around the headphone jack that are shown in the second picture. It is likely that at least one of them got loose.

Lines.Text: take a thin soldering iron and heat up the soldering points one by one .
be careful to not touch any other parts on the mainboard with the soldering iron .
after soldering the headphone jack should sit tight on the mainboard .
finally , take your preferred headphones and test the result .

Steps.Text_raw: Take a thin soldering iron and heat up the soldering points one by one. Be careful to not touch any other parts on the mainboard with the soldering iron. After soldering the headphone jack should sit tight on the mainboard. Finally, take your preferred headphones and test the result.

Lines.Text: removal of the battery may require some force .
beginning with the notch directly beneath the battery , use the plastic opening tool to loosen the battery .
once the battery is free , remove it from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Removal of the battery may require some force. Beginning with the notch directly beneath the battery, use the plastic opening tool to loosen the battery. Once the battery is free, remove it from the device.

Lines.Text: turn over the device .
use the plastic opening tool to separate the front and back covers .
move the opening tool around the perimeter of the device until the front cover detaches .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn over the device. Use the plastic opening tool to separate the front and back covers. Move the opening tool around the perimeter of the device until the front cover detaches.

Lines.Text: slowly detach the front cover from the rest of the device to reveal the interior .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly detach the front cover from the rest of the device to reveal the interior.

Lines.Text: insert the flat-head screwdriver into the notch on the bottom of the device . pry the main board and screen from the outer shell of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat-head screwdriver into the notch on the bottom of the device. Pry the main board and screen from the outer shell of the device.

Lines.Text: the power button will come loose upon removal of outer shell . when reassembling , align power button properly .
remove the main board and screen from the outer shell .

Steps.Text_raw: The power button will come loose upon removal of outer shell.  When reassembling, align power button properly. Remove the main board and screen from  the outer shell.

Lines.Text: no tools are needed . the prongs ( pictured ) will release easily to remove the back cover .
carefully remove the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: No tools are needed. The prongs (pictured) will release easily to remove the back cover. Carefully remove the back cover.

Lines.Text: be gentle when removing the main board . the main board is attached to the front panel of the device by wires .
using the flat-head screwdriver , carefully pry open the prongs on the sides of the device , and remove the main board from the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Be gentle when removing the main board. The main board is attached to the front panel of the device by wires. Using the flat-head screwdriver, carefully pry open the prongs on the sides of the device, and remove the main board from the screen.

Lines.Text: do not damage the ribbon tab ( pictured ) . it is vital to the device .
push the ribbon tab ( sticking out below the main screen ) backward through the square hole to remove the main board of the device .

once the wiring is removed from the front panel , release the hinge at the bottom of the device . to do so , gently pry underneath the clip ( pictured ) with a plastic opening tool . the clip will pop up , and the motherboard can be completely removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Do not damage the ribbon tab (pictured). It is vital to the device. Push the ribbon tab (sticking out below the main screen) backward through the square hole to remove the main board of the device. Once the wiring is removed from the front panel, release the hinge at the bottom of the device. To do so, gently pry underneath the clip (pictured) with a plastic opening tool. The clip will pop up, and the motherboard can be completely removed.

Title: Sony Walkman WM-AF48 Headphone Jack Replacement

Lines.Text: remove any batteries or cassettes from the walkman .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove any batteries or cassettes from the Walkman.

Lines.Text: using a spudger , separate the back cover from the front .
remove the back cover evenly on all sides . the best method is to insert the spudger and gently twist it slightly to separate the two parts , slowly working your way around the entire outer shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, separate the back cover from the front. Remove the back cover evenly on all sides. The best method is to insert the spudger and gently twist it slightly to separate the two parts, slowly working your way around the entire outer shell.

Lines.Text: gently pull the ribbon from the jack just above the film revolver , near the edge .
carefully lift the motherboard out of the outer shell .
be careful to only handle the motherboard by the edges . avoid touching the metal parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull the ribbon from the jack just above the film revolver, near the edge. Carefully lift the motherboard out of the outer shell. Be careful to only handle the motherboard by the edges. Avoid touching the metal parts.

Lines.Text: locate the four metal points on the motherboard that hold the headphone jack in place .
using a soldering iron , remove the headphone jack by de-soldering the four points that hold it in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the four metal points on the motherboard that hold the headphone jack in place. Using a soldering iron, remove the headphone jack by de-soldering the four points that hold it in place.

Subject: Headphone Jack

Lines.Text: using a spudger , separate the back cover from the front .
remove the back cover evenly on all sides . the best method is to insert the spudger and gently twist it slightly to separate the two parts , slowly working your way around the entire outer shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, separate the back cover from the front. Remove the back cover evenly on all sides. The best method is to insert the spudger and gently twist it slightly to separate the two parts, slowly working your way around the entire outer shell.

Lines.Text: gently pull the ribbon from the jack above the film revolver , near the edge .
lift the motherboard from the outer shell .
be careful to only handle the motherboard by the edges . avoid touching the metal parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull the ribbon from the jack above the film revolver, near the edge. Lift the motherboard from the outer shell. Be careful to only handle the motherboard by the edges. Avoid touching the metal parts.

Lines.Text: identify the six points where the power switch is soldered to the motherboard .
using a soldering iron , remove the switch by de-soldering these points which hold it in place .

Lines.Text: if you do not have a plastic opening tool , you can open the system using your finger . however , if you choose to use your hands , make sure to wear gloves . the panel is very sharp .

swing the back half of the panel slightly away from the unit . then , starting at the top back corner , slide plastic opening tool through the created gap from back to front . the panel should pop off . repeat the process on the opposite panel .

the process will require the use of moderate force and can be eased by wiggling the ribbon during removal .

slide the back panel toward you and off of the unit .

Lines.Text: rotate the device so that the front is facing towards you .
remove the four 5.5 mm 2 phillips screws securing the mainboard ( the black flat circuit board ) .
remove the cable connector from the mainboard by pulling the connector up .
detach the two side ribbon wires on the green side of the tan and green circuit board by pulling them out of the bottom .

Remove the cable connector from the mainboard by pulling the connector up. Detach the two side ribbon wires on the green side of the tan and green circuit board by pulling them out of the bottom.

Lines.Text: slide the mainboard away from the black and green circuit board and then up .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the mainboard away from the black and green circuit board and then up.

Lines.Text: rotate the device so that the side with the circuit board is facing towards you .
pull the sides of the metal cd assembly case out slightly to disengage the clasps holding the encasing down .
repeat the previous step on the other side .
rotate the device so that the front is facing towards you .
lift the metal cd assembly case up and away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the device so that the side with the circuit board is facing towards you. Pull the sides of the metal CD assembly case out slightly to disengage the clasps holding the encasing down. Repeat the previous step on the other side. Rotate the device so that the front is facing towards you. Lift the metal CD assembly case up and away from the device.

Lines.Text: push down on the two black clasps and pull the plastic grid towards you .
lift the plastic grid off of the cd assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the two black clasps and pull the plastic grid towards you. Lift the plastic grid off of the CD assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the two 9.5 mm screws holding the cd assembly to the base .
one of the screws in this step is inside the cd assembly . you will need to use a long screwdriver to reach in and unscrew it .
when reassembling the device , put the front panel on before screwing , as it will help line up the screw holes correctly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 9.5mm screws holding the CD assembly to the base. One of the screws in this step is inside the CD assembly. Lines.Text: rotate the device so that the front is facing towards you
lift the cd assembly away from the bottom panel .

Lines.Text: remove the motherboard from case .
flip the motherboard around so that the metallic green side is facing you .
desolder the points indicated in picture 2. this should free the wires connected to the motherboard .
remove the motherboard by pulling it out of the device cavity .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motherboard from case. Flip the motherboard around so that the metallic green side is facing you. Desolder the points indicated in picture 2. This should free the wires connected to the motherboard. Remove the motherboard by pulling it out of the device cavity.

Lines.Text: remove the battery cover on the back of the boombox by applying downward pressure to the two clamps .
be sure to unplug the boombox from the wall before attempting to open it for repair .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery cover on the back of the boombox by applying downward pressure to the two clamps. Be sure to unplug the boombox from the wall before attempting to open it for repair.

Lines.Text: push against the positive end of each battery . once it is loose , lift the battery out . repeat for all six batteries .
the top row of batteries have the positive side pointing right . the bottom row of batteries have the positive side pointing left .

Steps.Text_raw: Push against the positive end of each battery. Once it is loose, lift the battery out. Repeat for all six batteries. The top row of batteries have the positive side pointing right. The bottom row of batteries have the positive side pointing left.

Lines.Text: hold the boombox handle at an angle to access the screws behind the cd player .
use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew the top two 14 mm screws . you may need a flashlight to see the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the boombox handle at an angle to access the screws behind the CD player. Use a  Phillips #1 screwdriver to unscrew the top two 14 mm screws. You may need a flashlight to see the screws.

Lines.Text: remove four 14 mm screws using a phillips 1 screwdriver . two of these screws are at the bottom of the boombox and the other two are on either side of the boombox as highlighted in the related images .
all four screws have black arrows ( not visible in the photo ) indicating their location on the boombox .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove four 14 mm screws using a Phillips #1 screwdriver. Two of these screws are at the bottom of the boombox and the other two are on either side of the boombox as highlighted in the related images. All four screws have black arrows (not visible in the photo) indicating their location on the boombox.

Lines.Text: gently separate the front panel from the back panel .
remove the two connections holding the front panel to boombox .
one connection is located on the upper left hand side of the main circuit board .
the other is a large white strip slightly to the right of the cassette player .
do not touch the cylindrical parts on the circuit board . these are capacitors and may deliver a shock !
remove the front panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently separate the front panel from the back panel. Remove the two connections holding the front panel to boombox. One connection is located on the upper left hand side of the main circuit board. The other is a large white strip slightly to the right of the cassette player. Do not touch the cylindrical parts on the circuit board. These are capacitors and may deliver a shock! Remove the front panel.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew the four 12 mm screws that connect the cassette motor to the brackets .
wiggle the cassette motor to remove it from the two brackets . do not remove completely ; only separate the motor from the two brackets .
remove the two wire sets that connect the cassette motor to the main circuit board .
completely remove the cassette motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to unscrew the four 12 mm screws that connect the cassette motor to the brackets. Wiggle the cassette motor to remove it from the two brackets. Do not remove completely; only separate the motor from the two brackets. Remove the two wire sets that connect the cassette motor to the main circuit board. Completely remove the cassette motor.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew the four 12 mm screws that connect the brackets to the main circuit board .
gently pull the brackets outwards to remove them .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to unscrew the four 12 mm screws that connect the brackets to the main circuit board. Gently pull the brackets outwards to remove them.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew the 10 mm screw located on the top left of the tuner wheel bracket .
separate the tuner wheel bracket from tuner wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to unscrew the 10 mm screw located on the top left of the tuner wheel bracket. Separate the tuner wheel bracket from tuner wheel.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 0 screwdriver to unscrew the 6 mm screw in the center of the tuner wheel .
remove tuner wheel completely .
the tuner wheel slightly protrudes out of the top of the boombox . be mindful of this when removing tuner wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #0 screwdriver to unscrew the 6 mm screw in the center of the tuner wheel. Remove tuner wheel completely. The tuner wheel slightly protrudes out of the top of the boombox. Be mindful of this when removing tuner wheel.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to unscrew the five 10 mm screws located on the main circuit board .
note that the second picture depicts the left half of the main circuit board . the third picture contains the right half .

Lines.Text: disconnect the six wire sets that connect to the main circuit board as shown . each of the wires have 3-6 prongs .
the order of removal is not important .
note that the second picture depicts the left half of the main circuit board . the third picture contains the right half .
the connections for each of these wire sets is a different size . when reassembling , use these size differences to determine how the wire sets reconnect to the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the six wire sets that connect to the main circuit board as shown. Each of the wires have 3-6 prongs. The order of removal is not important. Note that the second picture depicts the left half of the main circuit board. The third picture contains the right half. The connections for each of these wire sets is a different size. When reassembling, use these size differences to determine how the wire sets reconnect to the circuit board.

Lines.Text: use a pair of tweezers to pop off the volume and tuner buttons located on the top left of the boombox .
pop the buttons off by placing the tweezers under each button as shown in the first picture . proceed to push upwards until the button pops off .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a pair of tweezers to pop off the volume and tuner buttons located on the top left of the boombox. Pop the buttons off by placing the tweezers under each button as shown in the first picture. Proceed to push upwards until the button pops off.

Lines.Text: gently wiggle and pull the main circuit board outwards until it is fully removed .
ensure that the mode tuner on the top left of the circuit board is not blocked by the tuner wheel attached to the case . sometimes the tuner wheel will obstruct the circuit board during removal .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently wiggle and pull the main circuit board outwards until it is fully removed. Ensure that the mode tuner on the top left of the circuit board is not blocked by the tuner wheel attached to the case. Sometimes the tuner wheel will obstruct the circuit board during removal.

the top row of batteries have the positive side pointing right . the bottom row of batteries have the positive side pointing left .

remove the two connections holding the front panel to boombox .
one connection is located on the upper left hand side of the main circuit board .
the other is a large white strip slightly to the right of the cassette player .
do not touch the cylindrical parts on the circuit board . these are capacitors and may deliver a shock !
remove the front panel .

desolder the two wires connected to the mircophone using the soldering station .

Lines.Text: before disassembly , ensure that the boombox is powered off , unplugged and any batteries have been removed from the device .
begin by turning the boombox over so that the bottom is facing up .
when turning the boombox over , the antenna will be pointing down . take care that the antenna is not damaged when opening the device .
your boombox will have a total of 12 phillips screws on the bottom . the location of the screws needed to remove the bottom panel are circled in red in the image to the left .
remove the 12 screws with a phillips head screwdriver on the bottom panel .
one screw , in the upper left corner , does not need to be removed to disassemble the device . this screw is for the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembly, ensure that the boombox is powered off, unplugged and any batteries have been removed from the device. Begin by turning the boombox over so that the bottom is facing up. When turning the boombox over, the antenna will be pointing down. Take care that the antenna is not damaged when opening the device. Your boombox will have a total of 12 Phillips screws on the bottom. The location of the screws needed to remove the bottom panel are circled in red in the image to the left. Remove the 12 screws with a Phillips head screwdriver on the bottom panel. One screw, in the upper left corner, does not need to be removed to disassemble the device. This screw is for the antenna.

Lines.Text: with all 12 screws removed , it is possible to detach the plastic bottom cover from the top half of the boombox .

push the bottom shell back slightly before pulling it up . the plastic bottom will lift up directly but there is a lip that fits under the black handle that must first be exposed , as seen in the image on the left .
the boombox's antenna must be straight in order for the bottom cover to be pulled up .
several wires run between the bottom half and top half of the boombox . take care not to damage or otherwise tear the wiring when opening the device .

Steps.Text_raw: With all 12 screws removed, it is possible to detach the plastic bottom cover from the top half of the boombox. Push the bottom shell back slightly before pulling it up. The plastic bottom will lift up directly but there is a lip that fits under the black handle that must first be exposed, as seen in the image on the left. The boombox's antenna must be straight in order for the bottom cover to be pulled up. Several wires run between the bottom half and top half of the boombox. Take care not to damage or otherwise tear the wiring when opening the device.

Lines.Text: the boombox should now be in two separate pieces , connected only by two wires .
disconnect the red and black wires by gently grasping its white plastic end and pulling it out of its socket ( circled in red on the image to the left ) .

additionally , the black wire highlighted in the square yellow box in the image to the left is taped onto the main board . this tape may be safely removed to give the wire more slack when separating the two halves of the boombox .
the power supply and antenna are located on the bottom half of the boombox while the headphone jack , function buttons and lcd screen are located on the top half .

Steps.Text_raw: The boombox should now be in two separate pieces, connected only by two wires. Disconnect the red and black wires by gently grasping its white plastic end and pulling it out of its socket (circled in red on the image to the left). Additionally, the black wire highlighted in the square yellow box in the image to the left is taped onto the main board. This tape may be safely removed to give the wire more slack when separating the two halves of the boombox. The power supply and antenna are located on the bottom half of the boombox while the headphone jack, function buttons and lcd screen are located on the top half.

Lines.Text: the circuit board that contains the function buttons is located to the left of the boombox's main circuit board .

the main circuit board can optionally be removed ( covered in other guides0 if it is too difficult to access the board containing the function buttons . however , we do not recommend doing this if it is not necessary since removing the main board is difficult .

Steps.Text_raw: The circuit board that contains the function buttons is located to the left of the boombox's main circuit board. The main circuit board can optionally be removed (covered in other guides0 if it is too difficult to access the board containing the function buttons. However, we do not recommend doing this if it is not necessary since removing the main board is difficult.

Lines.Text: there are a total of four screws holding the function button circuit board onto the outer shell of the boombox .
remove the four screws using a phillips-head screwdriver and gently pull the circuit board up from the case .
be careful not to break or damage the white wires connecting the function button circuit board to the main board .

Steps.Text_raw: There are a total of four screws holding the function button circuit board onto the outer shell of the boombox. Remove the four screws using a Phillips-head screwdriver and gently pull the circuit board up from the case. Be careful not to break or damage the white wires connecting the function button circuit board to the main board.

Lines.Text: remove the circuit board from the case without disconnecting the wires .
flip the circuit board over so that the tan side is up ( instead of the green side ) .
there are a total of six function buttons on the board which correspond to the function buttons on the outer shell . locate the button on this baord that you intend to replace .
the buttons on this board all have white labels near them . this can help you identify which button to replace .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the circuit board from the case without disconnecting the wires. Flip the circuit board over so that the tan side is up (instead of the green side). There are a total of six function buttons on the board which correspond to the function buttons on the outer shell. Locate the button on this baord that you intend to replace. The buttons on this board all have white labels near them. This can help you identify which button to replace.

Lines.Text: once the button to replace has been identified , flip the board over so that the green side is face up .
position the circuit board so that it will be easy to use a soldering iron on .
heat the connections of the button to replace with the soldering iron until all solder is removed . then pull the button from the board .
replace the button with a new , working button and apply new solder with the soldering iron to the connections in back .
each button has a total of four connectors to remove/solder .
ensure that the old solder is completely removed from the board to prevent any electrical shorts when the new button is connected .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the button to replace has been identified, flip the board over so that the green side is face up. Position the circuit board so that it will be easy to use a soldering iron on. Heat the connections of the button to replace with the soldering iron until all solder is removed. Then pull the button from the board. Replace the button with a new, working button and apply new solder with the soldering iron to the connections in back. Each button has a total of four connectors to remove/solder. Ensure that the old solder is completely removed from the board to prevent any electrical shorts when the new button is connected.

unscrew the four 11 mm screws from the base .
pry the base loose using the spudger .
remove the base by hand .

gently pull front housing from the back housing .

Lines.Text: use the spudger to push the usb port on the bottom of the device inward .
hold the device firmly between two fingers . be sure you aren't holding down the top of the device ; the circuit board will slide out of the shell through that end .
the plastic lcd cover and the key pad will now be free ; they were held in place by the tension between the case and the internal circuit board .

Lines.Text: flip the lcd screen off the midsection plate to gain access to the space around the input button chip .

Lines.Text: using a spudger , pry off the button input chip from the mid-section of the device . to gain best leverage , start at the bottom right corner and level your way up the side of the chip .
be aware that the button input chip is glued to the mid-section , so some extra force may be required .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, pry off the button input chip from the mid-section of the device. To gain best leverage, start at the bottom right corner and level your way up the side of the chip. Lines.Text: lift open the lcd screen and button input chip to access the entire midsection plate .

Lines.Text: use a phillips head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3 /16 inch screws that were underneath the button input chip .

Lines.Text: use a phillips head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3 /16 inch screws that were underneath the lcd screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips Head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3/16 inch screws that were underneath the LCD screen.

Lines.Text: use a spudger to pry the battery from the midsection plate .
there is adhesive glue underneath the battery , so additional force might be required to separate the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a spudger to pry the battery from the midsection plate. There is adhesive glue underneath the battery, so additional force might be required to separate the battery.

Lines.Text: locate the soldering joint connecting the battery wires to the power supply , marked by the letters ps on the motherboard .
hold the battery wires in place so that access to the soldering joints is not blocked .
when using a soldering iron , keep your hands and fingers as far as possible from the iron's tip to avoid burning your skin .
using a soldering iron , melt the solder connecting the red wire to the motherboard . do the same action to the black wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the soldering joint connecting the battery wires to the power supply, marked by the letters "PS" on the motherboard. Hold the battery wires in place so that access to the soldering joints is not blocked. When using a soldering iron, keep your hands and fingers as far as possible from the iron's tip to avoid burning your skin. Using a soldering iron, melt the solder connecting the red wire to the motherboard. Do the same action to the black wire.

Title: Eclipse 180G2 MP3 Video Player Buttons Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the two screws on the bottom of the device with a phillips head screwdriver .
use a spudger to remove the plastic plate from the bottom of the player .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws on the bottom of the device with a Phillips head screwdriver. Use a spudger to remove the plastic plate from the bottom of the player.

Lines.Text: use the spudger to push the usb port on the bottom of the device inward .
hold the device firmly between two fingers . be sure you aren't holding down the top of the device ; the circuit board will slide out of the shell through that end .
the plastic lcd cover and the key pad will now be free ; they were held in place by the tension between the case and the internal circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the spudger to push the USB port on the bottom of the device inward. Hold the device firmly between two fingers. Be sure you aren't holding down the top of the device; the circuit board will slide out of the shell through that end. The plastic LCD cover and the key pad will now be free; they were held in place by the tension between the case and the internal circuit board.

Lines.Text: freed from the internal space of the device , the lcd screen as well as the buttons will simply fall out of the face of the device . they can now easily be replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: Freed from the internal space of the device, the LCD screen as well as the buttons will simply fall out of the face of the device. They can now easily be replaced.

Subject: Buttons

Title: Sony Walkman NWZ-S764 Bluetooth module Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the two black 6.4 mm phillips screws from the back of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two black 6.4mm Phillips screws from the back of the device.

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , work your way around the edges of the device , carefully prying off the front panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, work your way around the edges of the device, carefully prying off the front panel.

Lines.Text: remove the two 2.8 mm phillips screws located on either side of the device near the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.8 mm phillips screws located on either side of the device near the top.

Lines.Text: carefully pull the top piece away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pull the top piece away from the device.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of the spudger to flip up the retaining flap for the bluetooth module .
be sure to lift up on the retaining flap , and not the socket itself .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of the spudger to flip up the retaining flap for the bluetooth module. Be sure to lift up on the retaining flap, and not the socket itself.

Lines.Text: remove the two 1.8 mm silver phillips screws on the bluetooth module .
lift up on and remove the bluetooth module .
the ribbon cable must first be removed in order to access the highlighted screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 1.8mm silver Phillips screws on the Bluetooth module. Lift up on and remove the Bluetooth module. The ribbon cable must first be removed in order to access the highlighted screw.

Lines.Text: carefully slide the iopener wedge tool under the edge of the lcd display cover to separate it from the device .
slide the wedge under all edges of the cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully slide the iOpener wedge tool under the edge of the LCD display cover to separate it from the device. Slide the wedge under all edges of the cover. Lines.Text: use a strong pry tool to lift the metal brackets away from the device . you will need to bend the metal slightly to remove it from the dimples .
this step will require slight force to separate the frame . do not bend the brackets too far so that they can be replaced later .
once separated , pull the innermost frame containing the lcd display away from the brackets .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a strong pry tool to lift the metal brackets away from the device. You will need to bend the metal slightly to remove it from the dimples. This step will require slight force to separate the frame.  Do not bend the brackets too far so that they can be replaced later. Once separated, pull the innermost frame containing the LCD display away from the brackets.

the pry tool also works for this step .

Title: Replacing Creative Zen X-Fi Button Input Chip

Lines.Text: using a spudger , wedge the tip between the front and back case to pry them apart .
be careful to not apply excessive force since there are six fasteners on the screen's side that holds the cases firmly together .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, wedge the tip between the front and back case to pry them apart. Be careful to not apply excessive force since there are six fasteners on the screen's side that holds the cases firmly together.

Lines.Text: the black rubber button pad can be removed by simply picking it up .

Steps.Text_raw: The black rubber button pad can be removed by simply picking it up.

Lines.Text: flip the lcd screen off the midsection plate to gain access to the space around the input button chip .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the LCD screen off the midsection plate to gain access to the space around the input button chip.

Lines.Text: using a spudger , pry off the button input chip from the mid-section of the device . to gain best leverage , start at the bottom right corner and level your way up the side of the chip .
be aware that the button input chip is glued to the mid-section , so some extra force may be required .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a spudger, pry off the button input chip from the mid-section of the device. To gain best leverage, start at the bottom right corner and level your way up the side of the chip. Be aware that the button input chip is glued to the mid-section, so some extra force may be required.

Lines.Text: lift open the lcd screen and button input chip to access the entire midsection plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift open the LCD screen and button input chip to access the entire midsection plate.

Lines.Text: use a phillips head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3 /16 inch screws that were underneath the button input chip .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips Head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3/16 inch screws that were underneath the button input chip.

Lines.Text: use a phillips head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3 /16 inch screws that were underneath the lcd screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips Head screwdriver to unscrew the three 3/16 inch screws that were underneath the LCD screen.

Lines.Text: locate the soldering joints connecting the button input pad to the motherboard .
hold the wires in place for easier access to the soldering joints .
when using a soldering iron , keep your hands and fingers as far as possible from the iron's tip to avoid burning your skin .
using a soldering iron , melt the solder connecting the red wire to the motherboard . do the same action to the black wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the soldering joints connecting the button input pad to the motherboard. Hold the wires in place for easier access to the soldering joints. When using a soldering iron, keep your hands and fingers as far as possible from the iron's tip to avoid burning your skin. Using a soldering iron, melt the solder connecting the red wire to the motherboard. Do the same action to the black wire.

Subject: Button Input Chip

Lines.Text: remove the two black 6.4 mm phillips screws from the back of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two black 6.4mm Phillips screws from the back of the device.

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , work your way around the edges of the device , carefully prying off the front panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, work your way around the edges of the device, carefully prying off the front panel.

Lines.Text: remove the two 2.8 mm phillips screws located on either side of the device near the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.8 mm phillips screws located on either side of the device near the top.

Lines.Text: carefully pull the top piece away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully pull the top piece away from the device.

Lines.Text: pull the tab towards you and lift up to remove the battery cover .
remove the two aa batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the tab towards you and lift up to remove the battery cover. Remove the two AA batteries.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four 8 mm phillips 2 screws .
unscrew the six 25 mm phillips 2 screws .
reinstall the backup battery cover so it is out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four 8mm Phillips #2 screws. Unscrew the six 25mm Phillips #2 screws. Reinstall the backup battery cover so it is out of the way.

Lines.Text: pry the backplate up with a plastic opening tool between the back plate and the speaker grill .
be careful when lifting the bottom plate up ; there is a short white and orange 4-pin connector attached to its underside .
lift the bottom plate up while making sure the connector remains attached .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry the backplate up with a plastic opening tool between the back plate and the speaker grill. Be careful when lifting the bottom plate up; there is a short white and orange 4-pin connector attached to its underside. Lift the bottom plate up while making sure the connector remains attached.

Lines.Text: use your hands to flip the backing plate away from you and rest it upside down on the ih9.
unplug the white and orange 4-pin connector by pulling it in the direction of the wires .
set the backing plate aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your hands to flip the backing plate away from you and rest it upside down on the iH9. Unplug the white and orange 4-pin connector by pulling it in the direction of the wires. Set the backing plate aside.

Lines.Text: place the device so that the speaker grill is face down .
remove the two 10 mm phillips 2 screws on interior sides of the speaker housings .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the device so that the speaker grill is face down. Remove the two 10mm Phillips #2 screws on interior sides of the speaker housings.

Lines.Text: place the ih9 upside down .
wires connect the core assembly to the housing ; do not attempt to pull the core assembly completely out .
using both hands , pull the housing siding away from the device while simultaneously lifting the motherboard and speaker assembly straight up .
repeat for the other side .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the iH9 upside down. Wires connect the core assembly to the housing; do not attempt to pull the core assembly completely out. Using both hands, pull the housing siding away from the device while simultaneously lifting the motherboard and speaker assembly straight up. Repeat for the other side.

Lines.Text: stand the ih9 on its grill .
separate the motherboard and speaker assembly by rocking it back and forth and pulling the assembly towards you .
remove the small back panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Stand the iH9 on its grill. Separate the motherboard and speaker assembly by rocking it back and forth and pulling the assembly towards you. Remove the small back panel.

Lines.Text: firmly pull the wide 9-pin connector with black covering on the underside of the upper housing to unplug it .
lay the housing and core assembly flat and close to each one another .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly pull the wide 9-pin connector with black covering on the underside of the upper housing to unplug it. Lay the housing and core assembly flat and close to each one another.

Lines.Text: unplug the narrow 9-pin connector from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the narrow 9-pin connector from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: cut the zip tie holding the wires together with a wire cutter . the two sides of the device housing are now fully separated .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the zip tie holding the wires together with a wire cutter. The two sides of the device housing are now fully separated.

Lines.Text: set the ihome ih9 speaker and mother board assembly upright on the speaker grill .

Lines.Text: set the ih9 flat down with the solder side of the motherboard up and the speaker grill facing away .

set the speaker grill aside .

Lines.Text: flip the ih9 back over , exposing the motherboard components .

for the left speaker , unplug the speaker wire by pulling in the direction of the wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the iH9 back over, exposing the motherboard components. For the right speaker, unplug the speaker wire by pulling in the direction of the wire (pictured). For the left speaker, unplug the speaker wire by pulling in the direction of the wire.

Lines.Text: remove the four 14 mm phillips 1 screws on each of the speaker's four corners .
the right speaker is pictured ; the same procedure is necessary to replace the left speaker .
remove the speaker .

remove the two aa batteries .

Lines.Text: locate the four plugs connecting the motherboard to the rest of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the four plugs connecting the motherboard to the rest of the device.

Lines.Text: begin with remove the plug to your left .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin with remove the plug to your left.

Lines.Text: remove the plug to your right from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plug to your right from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: remove the plug in the front of the lcd screen plug .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plug in the front of the lcd screen plug.

Lines.Text: remove the lcd screen plug last . then , follow the following instructions in reverse to replace the old motherboard with the new one .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the LCD screen plug last. Then, follow the following instructions in reverse to replace the old motherboard with the new one.

Lines.Text: with the phillips screwdriver , remove the three screws that run along the center of the base .

Steps.Text_raw: With the phillips screwdriver, remove the three screws that run along the center of the base.

Lines.Text: remove the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the base.

Lines.Text: using the metal spudger , gently lift the face plate away from the display .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the metal spudger, gently lift the face plate away from the display.

Lines.Text: once the face plate is removed , use the phillips screwdriver to remove the six screws shown here .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the face plate is removed, use the phillips screwdriver to remove the six screws shown here.

Lines.Text: using the metal spudger , lift the speaker grilles from the display .
the speaker grilles will hinge on the side closest to the display .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the metal spudger, lift the speaker grilles from the display. The speaker grilles will hinge on the side closest to the display.

Lines.Text: using the phillips screwdriver , remove the four screws shown here .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the phillips screwdriver, remove the four screws shown here.

Lines.Text: the two pieces of the display will now separate easily .

Steps.Text_raw: The two pieces of the display will now separate easily.

Lines.Text: using the phillips screwdriver , remove the three screws shown here .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the phillips screwdriver, remove the three screws shown here.

Lines.Text: the digital display should now be easy to remove .
replace with new part .

Steps.Text_raw: The digital display should now be easy to remove. Replace with new part.

Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation LCD Shield Plate  Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
