Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the headphone jack , lightning connector , and speaker .
three 2.6 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the headphone jack, Lightning connector, and speaker. Three 2.6 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case .
do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, as it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

Lines.Text: grasping the large ribbon cable , gently pull the lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the large ribbon cable, gently pull the Lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the rear-facing camera ribbon cable from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the rear-facing camera ribbon cable from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to gently pull the rear-facing camera ribbon cable out from underneath the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to gently pull the rear-facing camera ribbon cable out from underneath the logic board.

Lines.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame .
gently twist the spudger to free the camera .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame. Gently twist the spudger to free the camera.

Lines.Text: lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket and remove it from the ipod touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket and remove it from the iPod Touch.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a table or bench. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 000 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #000 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up and remove the lcd plate from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up and remove the LCD plate from the iPod.

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 000 phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screws securing the logic board to the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place .
turn the ipod over and heat the back of the aluminium ipod case . ''do not heat the battery'' .
the aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot ; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive keeping the battery in place. Turn the iPod over and heat the BACK of the aluminium iPod case. ''Do not heat the battery''. The aluminium case does '''not''' have to be hot; you should always be able to touch heated parts with your fingers at all times without it being uncomfortable.

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next few steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point ; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points , in turn .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to flip the front-facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a small piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the headphone jack , lightning connector , and speaker .
three 2.6 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the headphone jack, Lightning connector, and speaker. Three 2.6 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case .
do not try to remove the speaker , as it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, as it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

Lines.Text: grasping the large ribbon cable , gently pull the lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasping the large ribbon cable, gently pull the Lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case.

Lines.Text: flip the entire assembly over , exposing the back of the logic board .
use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the entire assembly over, exposing the back of the logic board. Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket in the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket in the logic board.

Lines.Text: flip the lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board .
the display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board .
use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board. The display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board. Use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the display assembly from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the display assembly from the iPod.

Lines.Text: flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back .
use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board .
this cable is very delicate ; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the logic board assembly back over to expose the connectors on the back. Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to gently pry the antenna connector off the back of the logic board. This cable is very delicate; be careful not to stress the point where it connects to the antenna.

Lines.Text: disconnect the button ribbon cable connector from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the button ribbon cable connector from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display connector from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display connector from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: remove the logic board assembly from the rear case of the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the logic board assembly from the rear case of the iPod.

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the rear-facing camera ribbon cable from the back of the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to disconnect the rear-facing camera ribbon cable from the back of the logic board.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to gently pull the rear-facing camera ribbon cable out from underneath the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to gently pull the rear-facing camera ribbon cable out from underneath the logic board.

Lines.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame .
gently twist the spudger to free the camera .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger between the rear-facing camera and its frame. Gently twist the spudger to free the camera.

Lines.Text: lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket and remove it from the ipod touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the rear-facing camera up out of its socket and remove it from the iPod Touch.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the button ribbon cable to the rear case of the ipod :
two 2.0 mm 000 phillips screws
two 2.3 mm 000 phillips screws
one 1.6 mm 000 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the button ribbon cable to the rear case of the iPod: Two 2.0 mm #000 Phillips screws Two 2.3 mm #000 Phillips screws One 1.6 mm #000 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: use tweezers to remove the small metal backing plate from the power switch section of the button ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to remove the small metal backing plate from the power switch section of the button ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: insert a plastic opening tool into the rear-facing camera frame and pry up against the rear case .
twist the plastic opening tool slightly counter-clockwise to pry the camera frame up from the rear case .
only pry enough to lift the camera frame from the rear case ; the rest of the cable is still adhered to the rear case and may break .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a plastic opening tool into the rear-facing camera frame and pry up against the rear case. Twist the plastic opening tool slightly counter-clockwise to pry the camera frame up from the rear case. Only pry enough to lift the camera frame from the rear case; the rest of the cable is still adhered to the rear case and may break.

Lines.Text: the power/sleep button may fall out of the rear case and should be removed at this point .
use the closed tip of a pair of tweezers to push the power/sleep button into the rear case .
use tweezers to remove the power button from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: The power/sleep button may fall out of the rear case and should be removed at this point. Use the closed tip of a pair of tweezers to push the power/sleep button into the rear case. Use tweezers to remove the power button from the iPod.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry the microphone up from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry the microphone up from the rear case.

Lines.Text: slide a plastic opening tool from right to left underneath the horizontal section of the cable , separating it from the adhesive securing it to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide a plastic opening tool from right to left underneath the horizontal section of the cable, separating it from the adhesive securing it to the rear case.

Lines.Text: gently peel the rest of the cable up from the rear case .
remove the button ribbon cable from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently peel the rest of the cable up from the rear case. Remove the button ribbon cable from the iPod.

Subject: Button Ribbon Cable

Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation Home Button Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device , lay the display assembly flat so you can access the back of the home button .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the rubber membrane up from around the home button .

Steps.Text_raw: Being careful not to rip any ribbon cables still connecting the two halves of the device, lay the display assembly flat so you can access the back of the home button. Use a plastic opening tool to pry the rubber membrane up from around the home button.

Lines.Text: once you've pried enough to tilt the button up and grab it , gently lift it up from the display assembly , pulling slowly to avoid tearing the rubber .
remove the home button from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you've pried enough to tilt the button up and grab it, gently lift it up from the display assembly, pulling slowly to avoid tearing the rubber. Remove the home button from the iPod.

The battery is secured with large amounts of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Do not attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point; you just want to start to loosen the adhesive at each of the prying points, in turn.

Lines.Text: continue with the lower right notch . insert the plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently pry up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue with the lower right notch. Insert the plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently pry up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying the battery up from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying the battery up from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .
you may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery , prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well. You may need to move back and forth between the sides and bottom of the battery, prying a small amount at a time until the battery is entirely free from the adhesive.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loosened , lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case .
be sure not to yank it out , as it is soldered to the logic board .
flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loosened, lift the battery up from the bottom and swing it out over the left side of the rear case. Be sure not to yank it out, as it is soldered to the logic board. Flip the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation Power Button Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving on to the left side of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving on to the left side of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case near the top. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: using the same procedure , loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the same procedure, loosen the last clip securing the plastic frame to the rear case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Do not try to completely remove the front panel, as it is still connected by several cables.

Lines.Text: gently fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , taking care not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a table or bench .
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate .
it may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . always use a low heat setting .
do not attempt to remove the home button switch , as it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD plate. It may be necessary to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. Always use a low heat setting. Do not attempt to remove the home button switch, as it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next few steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation Volume Buttons Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. This may not free the clip initially, but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Take your time and be careful and patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip on the left side. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case.

Lines.Text: repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side .
insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip .
rock the tool sideways , loosening the clip from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on this side. Insert the plastic opening tool between the plastic frame and aluminum rear case behind the second clip. Rock the tool sideways, loosening the clip from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
slightly twist the opening tool to pry the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
do not try to completely remove the front panel , as it is still connected by several cables .

Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation Wi-Fi Antenna Replacement

Lines.Text: if your display glass is cracked , keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass .
lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the ipod's display until the whole face is covered .
this will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display .
wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair .

Steps.Text_raw: If your display glass is cracked, keep further breakage contained and prevent bodily harm during your repair by taping the glass. Lay overlapping strips of clear packing tape over the iPod's display until the whole face is covered. This will keep glass shards contained and provide structural integrity when prying and lifting the display. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes from any glass shaken free during the repair.

Lines.Text: use a hairdryer or an iopener and apply it to the lower edge of the ipod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath .
the bottom of the screen ( near the home button ) is held in place with strong adhesive .
as you start prying the screen off in the next stages , you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a hairdryer or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/iOpener+Heating/25705|prepare an iOpener|new_window=true] and apply it to the lower edge of the iPod for about a minute in order to soften up the adhesive underneath. The bottom of the screen (near the home button) is held in place with strong adhesive. As you start prying the screen off in the next stages, you may need to apply more heat to keep the glue warm and flexible.

Lines.Text: center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass , with its edge centered over the home button .
press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Center the suction cup on the lower section of the glass, with its edge centered over the home button. Press in firmly and make sure the cup has a strong seal.

Lines.Text: hold the ipod firmly against a table or bench .
place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks .
lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the ipod . be patient , and pull with firm , constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case .

it may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive ( especially in cooler climates ) . if you can pry the screen apart , and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza , you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive .
after the display begins to lift from the rear case , be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Hold the iPod firmly against a table or bench. Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far when the adhesive breaks. Lift the suction cup up and back toward the top of the iPod. Be patient, and pull with firm, constant force until the adhesive breaks and the display comes up from the rear case. It may be necessary to use a heat gun to soften the adhesive (especially in cooler climates). If you can pry the screen apart, and the adhesive is still sticking and pulling apart like cheese topping on a pizza, you can slide a thin razor blade in and gently cut the adhesive. After the display begins to lift from the rear case, be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.

Lines.Text: in the following steps , you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen . it is connected to the rear case with several clips .
starting at the top right of the device , insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case .
slide the tool down this crack , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In the following steps, you will be loosening and freeing the plastic frame that surrounds the screen. It is connected to the rear case with several clips. Starting at the top right of the device, insert a plastic opening tool into the gap between the plastic frame and the aluminum rear case. Slide the tool down this crack, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
this may not free the clip initially , but repeating the procedure for each clip will begin to loosen the piece .

you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . take your time and be careful and patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

chances are that the wires running from the battery itself to the connector are firmly tucked behind the battery making it hard to get a grip on the connecter so just leave it connected for now .

Lines.Text: chances are your replacement battery doesn't have foam tape taped around it . if you don't have a roll of foam tape lying around at home just gently peel off the tape from the old battery and aply it to the new battery . this will ensure that the battery will firmly be secured under the battery cover .

both screws are 1 /8 inch in length .
the bottom cap will come off to reveal the inside main component .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws located on the bottom of the device with a phillips head screw driver. The two screws can be removed using the PH00 head from the iFixit repair toolkit. Both screws are 1/8 inch in length. The bottom cap will come off to reveal the inside main component.

Lines.Text: remove the main inner component using spudger , by pushing on the usb port . this will take some force .
hold on the sides with your fingers , and push to release from the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the main inner component using Spudger, by pushing on the USB port. This will take some force. Hold on the sides with your fingers, and push to release from the top.

Lines.Text: the plastic lcd cover and the key pad will now be loose ; they were held in place by the tension between the case and the internal main component .
locate the large square pack with a black and red wire coming out of it , this is the battery .
cut the red and black wires to remove the old battery .

Steps.Text_raw: The plastic LCD cover and the key pad will now be loose; they were held in place by the tension between the case and the internal main component. Locate the large square pack with a black and red wire coming out of it, this is the battery. Cut the red and black wires to remove the old battery.

Lines.Text: to replace , connect the two new lines ( red and black ) between the new battery and the device .
you have successfully replaced the battery !

Steps.Text_raw: To  Replace, connect the two new lines      ( red and black) between the new battery and the device. You have successfully replaced the battery!

Lines.Text: for this procedure , you will need a prying tool and tweezers .

Steps.Text_raw: For this procedure, you will need a prying tool and tweezers.

Lines.Text: the rca opal should have a blue front cover and a black back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: The RCA Opal should have a blue front cover and a black back cover.

Lines.Text: place the blade of the tweezers in between the blue and black surfaces .
twist and pull the blue plastic cover from the black back surface . you may need to work around the edges of the blue plastic in order to pry it free . it should come off in one piece .
the three circular buttons should come off with the front cover . if they do not , then they can be removed with the prying tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the blade of the tweezers  in  between the blue and black surfaces. Twist and pull the blue plastic cover from the black back surface. You may need to work around the edges of the blue plastic in order to pry it free. It should come off in one piece. The three circular buttons should come off with the front cover. If they do not, then they can be removed with the prying tool.

Lines.Text: using the prying tool , insert the tip of the tool in between the black plastic and the back cover of the device .
pull upward to pry the black plastic away from the device . it will come off in pieces , but this is okay .
there will be thin black plastic surrounding four clear pieces where the buttons used to be located . remove this as well .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the prying tool, insert the tip of the tool in between the black plastic and the back cover of the device. Pull upward to pry the black plastic away from the device. It will come off in pieces, but this is okay. There will be thin black plastic surrounding four clear pieces where the buttons used to be located. Remove this as well.

Lines.Text: once the black plastic is removed , you should be able to see the button control panel . this is the green board with the white circle in the middle .
use the tweezers to pry this panel from the main board .

note : there are three small screws connecting the button control panel to the main board . these are covered by black plastic and cannot be unscrewed with a screwdriver . if enough force is supplied when prying the button control panel free , these screws should come off with the panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the black plastic is removed, you should be able to see the button control panel. This is the green board with the white circle in the middle. Use the tweezers to pry this panel from the main board. NOTE: There are three small screws connecting the button control panel to the main board. These are covered by black plastic and cannot be unscrewed with a screwdriver. If enough force is supplied when prying the button control panel free, these screws should come off with the panel .

Lines.Text: now you should be able to see the main board . a small gold connector strip will connect the screen to the main board .
locate a small white rectangular connector found at the top middle of the main board .
using a prying tool or your fingernail , move the black plastic piece located at the bottom of the white connector to an upward position ( toward the screen ) .
this should free the gold connector strip and allow you to remove the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you should be able to see the  main board. A small gold connector strip will connect the screen to the main board. Locate a small white rectangular connector found at the top middle of the main board. Using a prying tool or your fingernail, move the black plastic piece located at the bottom of the white connector to an upward position (toward the screen). This should free the gold connector strip and allow you to remove the screen.

pull upward to pry the black plastic away from the device . it will come off in pieces , but this is okay .

It will come off in pieces, but this is okay. There will be thin black plastic surrounding four clear pieces where the buttons used to be located. Remove this as well.

locate a small white rectangular connector found at the top middle of the main board .
using a prying tool or your fingernail , move the black plastic piece located at the bottom of the white connector to an upward position ( toward the screen ) .

Using a prying tool or your fingernail, move the black plastic piece located at the bottom of the white connector to an upward position (toward the screen). Lines.Text: use the tweezers to pry off the black and silver plastic that lines the edges of the device .

Lines.Text: lift up to remove the black plastic outline that fits within the back cover . this will be connected to the main board and battery .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up to remove the black plastic outline that fits within the back cover. This will be connected to the main board and battery.

Lines.Text: locate four small screws on the four edges of the main board .
using the phillips +j000 screwdriver , remove these four screws .
this should disconnect the main board and battery from the remaining black plastic .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate four small screws on the four edges of the main board. Using the Phillips +J000 screwdriver, remove these four screws. This should disconnect the main board and battery from the remaining black plastic.

Title: iPod Touch 4th Generation 30 Pin Dock Connector Replacement

Lines.Text: the ipod touch 4th generation front panel is attached to the rear case by an adhesive . the use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended .
with the heat gun set on low , begin heating the lower portion of the touch near the home button .
it is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device .

Steps.Text_raw: The iPod Touch 4th Generation front panel is attached to the rear case by an adhesive. The use of a heat gun to soften the adhesive is highly recommended. With the heat gun set on "low", begin heating the lower portion of the Touch near the home button. It is suggested to heat the desired portion in a circular motion pattern to evenly dissipate the amount of heat throughout the device.

Lines.Text: beware , as the touch will be very hot . it may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying .
insert the edge of a plastic opening tool between the front glass panel and the plastic bezel near the home button .
do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case .
pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward , being careful not to bend the glass excessively .
if it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly , reheat it and try again .

Steps.Text_raw: Beware, as the Touch will be very hot. It may be helpful to hold it with a towel while prying. Insert the edge of a plastic opening tool between the front glass panel and the plastic bezel near the home button. Do not try to pry between the plastic bezel and the steel rear case. Pry the bottom edge of the front panel upward, being careful not to bend the glass excessively. If it is too difficult to pry up the front panel assembly, reheat it and try again.

Lines.Text: lift the front panel away from the body of the touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges .
if the adhesive is too difficult to separate , use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the front panel away from the body of the Touch to peel up the adhesive along its left and right edges. If the adhesive is too difficult to separate, use a heat gun to soften it before proceeding.

Lines.Text: use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly , as it is attached to the rest of the touch by the very delicate digitizer cable .

the display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the front facing camera . if it does not disconnect from the logic board while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly , be sure to disconnect it with a plastic opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the touch .
carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the touch , minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components .

Steps.Text_raw: Use extreme caution when handling the front panel assembly, as it is attached to the rest of the Touch by the very delicate digitizer cable. The display data cable is very short and is connected to the logic board near the front facing camera. If it does not disconnect from the logic board while freeing the top edge of the front panel assembly, be sure to disconnect it with a plastic opening tool before rotating the front panel assembly out of the Touch. Carefully pull the top of the front panel assembly away from the adhesive holding it to the Touch, minding the short digitizer cable connecting the two components.

Lines.Text: remove the following eight phillips 00 screws :
one 3.5 mm phillips screw
two 3.0 mm phillips screws
three 2.3 mm phillips screw
one 2.4 mm phillips screw
four 2.0 mm phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following eight Phillips #00 screws: One 3.5 mm Phillips screw Two 3.0 mm Phillips screws Three 2.3 mm Phillips screw One 2.4 mm Phillips screw Four 2.0 mm Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the edge of a plastic opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera .
remove the steel cover from the ipod .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the edge of a plastic opening tool to pry the thin steel cover up from the rear-facing camera. Remove the steel cover from the iPod.

Lines.Text: insert the edge of a plastic opening tool under the emi shield near the bottom left corner of the touch .
pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case .
if the shield is still attached to the logic board , warm this area with a heat gun to loosen the adhesive , then separate the shield from the logic board using the opening tool .
there is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board . be careful when prying in this location as the cable is very fragile and could rip .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the edge of a plastic opening tool under the EMI Shield near the bottom left corner of the Touch. Pry upward to separate the plate from the adhesive securing it to the plastic inner case. If the shield is still attached to the logic board, warm this area with a heat gun to loosen the adhesive, then separate the shield from the logic board using the opening tool. There is a very thin ribbon cable here that connects the volume and power buttons to the logic board. Be careful when prying in this location as the cable is very fragile and could rip.

Lines.Text: slightly tilt the steel emi shield to dislodge it from the rear case .
be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel emi shield .
lift the emi shield up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera .

Steps.Text_raw: Slightly tilt the steel EMI Shield to dislodge it from the rear case. Be careful not to tear the piece of copper tape connecting the rear-facing camera to the steel EMI Shield. Lift the EMI shield up off the rear case and peel off the piece of copper tape stuck to the rear-facing camera.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry the headphone jack connector up and out of its socket on the logic board.

Lines.Text: areas highlighted in red show three solder joints to the right of the battery , along with four smaller solder joints located to the left of the battery .
these joints secure the power/volume flex cable ( leftmost joint ) and the battery flex cable ( rightmost joint ) to the logic board .
in the next few steps you will desolder the battery and power/volume flex cables from the logic board .
these joints may be coated in a clear silicone/glue , which must be removed before desoldering .

Steps.Text_raw: Areas highlighted in red show three solder joints to the right of the battery, along with four smaller solder joints located to the left of the battery. These joints secure the power/volume flex cable (leftmost joint) and the battery  flex cable (rightmost joint) to the logic board. In the next few steps you will desolder the battery and power/volume flex cables from the logic board. These joints may be coated in a clear silicone/glue, which must be removed before desoldering.

Lines.Text: using the heat gun , heat the silicon/glue for 5-10 seconds , then use isopropyl alcohol and a q-tip to remove the silicon/glue .
do not overheat the silicon/glue as it will turn into a liquid and ooze everywhere .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the heat gun, heat the silicon/glue for 5-10 seconds, then use isopropyl alcohol and a q-tip to remove the silicon/glue. DO NOT overheat the silicon/glue as it will turn into a liquid and ooze everywhere.

Lines.Text: the two ribbon cables are attached to the logic board via solder pads with small holes that go through the cables and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board .
to desolder the battery flex cable , place a copper desoldering braid on top of the existing solder pads and press down on the braid with the soldering iron .
once the solder melts and flows into the braid , remove the braid from the pad .
process may need to be repeated two or three times to ensure complete removal of all solder .

beware of overheating the board and the cable . only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt . excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable .
do not bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable . shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board .
repeat this process for the power/volume flex cable .

Steps.Text_raw: The two ribbon cables are attached to the logic board via solder pads with small holes that go through the cables and attach to flat pads on the face of the logic board. To desolder the battery flex cable, place a copper desoldering braid on top of the existing solder pads and press down on the braid with the soldering iron. Once the solder melts and flows into the braid, remove the braid from the pad. Process may need to be repeated two or three times to ensure complete removal of all solder. Beware of overheating the board and the cable. Only hold the tip of the iron against the pad long enough to let the solder melt. Excess heat buildup has the potential to ruin the logic board or melt the ribbon cable. DO NOT bridge the connection between the solder pads both on the board and on the ribbon cable. Shorts have the potential to ruin the logic board. Repeat this process for the power/volume flex cable.

Lines.Text: once all solder pads have been removed , gently pull both ribbon cables from the logic board and bend them back to keep them out of your way .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all solder pads have been removed, gently pull both ribbon cables from the logic board and bend them back to keep them out of your way.

Lines.Text: starting above the battery near the power/volume cable attachment , use a cell phone prying tool to slowly pry the logic board straight up .
do not pry quickly , as the wifi cable will still be attached .
at this point , the top of the logic board should be lifted from the case . the bottom of the logic board and the wifi cable should still be attached to the steel housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Starting above the battery near the power/volume cable attachment, use a cell phone prying tool to slowly pry the logic board straight up. DO NOT pry quickly, as the wifi cable will still be attached. At this point, the top of the logic board should be lifted from the case. The bottom of the logic board and the wifi cable should still be attached to the steel housing.

Lines.Text: the wifi cable is connected to the bottom of the logic board by a small connector . this must be disconnected before removing the logic board from the case .
insert the edge of a metal spudger under the logic board , between the wifi cable connector clip and the logic board .
gently pry the connector from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: The wifi cable is connected to the bottom of the logic board by a small connector.  This must be disconnected before removing the logic board from the case. Insert the edge of a metal spudger under the logic board, between the wifi cable connector clip and the logic board. Gently pry the connector from the logic board.

Lines.Text: lightly heat the areas in red with your heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the logic board .
dont heat this area too much , excessive heat will fry the speaker .
once heated , gently pry the logic board up with a cell phone opening tool .
make sure to angle the cell phone opening tool under the red speaker wire located at the bottom left of the device before prying upwards .
lift the bottom of the logic board out of the casing with your fingers .
the front facing camera may still be attached by adhesive . using a metal spudger , gently pry the front facing camera from the casing .
remove the logic board from the steel casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Lightly heat the areas in red with your heat gun to soften the adhesive underneath the logic board. Don’t heat this area too much, excessive heat will fry the speaker. Once heated, gently pry the logic board up with a cell phone opening tool. Make sure to angle the cell phone opening tool under the red speaker wire located at the bottom left of the device before prying upwards. Lift the bottom of the logic board out of the casing with your fingers. The front facing camera may still be attached by adhesive.  Using a metal spudger, gently pry the front facing camera from the casing. Remove the logic board from the steel casing.

Lines.Text: the dock connector is secured to the logic board by 30 pins and two metal joints that stick up through holes in the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: The dock connector is secured to the logic board by 30 pins and two metal joints that stick up through holes in the logic board.

Lines.Text: desolder the two solder joints and the 30 pins .
to desolder the solder joint , place a copper desoldering braid on top of the existing solder and press down on the braid with the soldering iron .
once the solder melts and flows into the braid , remove the braid from the pad .
process may need to be repeated two or three times to ensure complete removal of all solder .
do not get solder on the highlighted gold ring , as you will not be able to remove it .
repeat this same process for the other solder joint and all 30 pins .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the two solder joints and the 30 pins. To desolder the solder joint, place a copper desoldering braid on top of the existing solder and press down on the braid with the soldering iron. Once the solder melts and flows into the braid, remove the braid from the pad. Process may need to be repeated two or three times to ensure complete removal of all solder. DO NOT get solder on the highlighted gold ring, as you will not be able to remove it. Repeat this same process for the other solder joint and all 30 pins.

Lines.Text: once all solder is removed , pry the dock connector straight down from the logic board using a metal spudger .
do not remove the dock connector before all solder is removed , as the pins will rip from the dock connector and get stuck in the logic board .
if done properly , you should be able to see straight through the logic board where all 30 pins and the two metal joints used to be .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all solder is removed, pry the dock connector straight down from the logic board using a metal spudger. DO NOT remove the dock connector before all solder is removed, as the pins will rip from the dock connector and get stuck in the logic board. If done properly, you should be able to see straight through the logic board where all 30 pins and the two metal joints used to be.

Lines.Text: with the logic board facing down , push the pins of the new connector through the holes in the logic board , making sure each pin goes through the board .
do not use excessive force , as you can bend the pins .

Steps.Text_raw: With the logic board facing down, push the pins of the new connector through the holes in the logic board, making sure each pin goes through the board. DO NOT use excessive force, as you can bend the pins.

Lines.Text: solder the two metal joints back to the logic board .
place the tip of the soldering iron against the metal joint .
melt solder so that it forms a dome on top of the joint .
remove both the solder and the soldering iron tip from the solder pad as soon as enough solder melts onto the pad .
when complete , the soldered pads should have an ovular , pill like shape .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder the two metal joints back to the logic board. Place the tip of the soldering iron against the metal joint. Melt solder so that it forms a dome on top of the joint. Remove both the solder and the soldering iron tip from the solder pad as soon as enough solder melts onto the pad. When complete, the soldered pads should have an ovular, pill like shape.

Lines.Text: solder all 30 pins back to the logic board .
heat all 30 pins with the tip of the soldering iron .
melt a drop of solder onto the pins and spread it around with the tip of the soldering iron .
repeat until all pins are covered in solder .
make sure solder covers every pin and pushes through to the other side of the logic board .
do not push too hard on the pins with the tip of the soldering iron as you could bend the pins .
remove any excess solder with desoldering braid .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder all 30 pins back to the logic board. Heat all 30 pins with the tip of the soldering iron. Melt a drop of solder onto the pins and spread it around with the tip of the soldering iron. Repeat until all pins are covered in solder. Make sure solder covers every pin and pushes through to the other side of the logic board. DO NOT push too hard on the pins with the tip of the soldering iron as you could bend the pins. Remove any excess solder with desoldering braid.

the touch pad can now be easily replaced .

remove the case , and with the spudger , apply force to the usb port to remove the inner component .
be careful , as releasing the tension will cause all parts to become loose and separate .

be sure that the screen fits perfectly , as dust getting in the screen will cause pixels to die .

Title: Sony Walkman NWZ-E438 USB Port Replacement

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws on the back of the device using a phillips 000 screwdriver .
keep the phillips 000 screwdriver aside for further steps in the guide . it will be the only screwdriver needed for this replacement .

Lines.Text: use a small prying tool to carefully pry open the back of the device .

Lines.Text: first , you must remove the black tape on the circuit board .
next , pull up on the red and gold band until it detaches from the chip .

Steps.Text_raw: First, you must remove the black tape on the circuit board. Next, pull up on the red and gold band until it detaches from the chip.

Lines.Text: using a small plastic prying tool , slip the end under the device circuit board and slowly lift it .
