Title: Eclipse T180 MP3 remove casing & Belt Clip 3 Steps

Lines.Text: basically there is a tiny screw just above the belt clip , which must come out ( where that very small hole is at the top of the case , centre ) . i actually used a flat-head watch screwdriver tilted because i didn't have a phillips screwdriver which is what you should use .

Steps.Text_raw: Basically there is a **TINY** screw just above the belt clip, which must come out (where that very small hole is at the top of the case, centre). I actually used a flat-head watch screwdriver tilted because I didn't have a phillips screwdriver which is what you should use.

Lines.Text: once i had the screw out it is a simple matter of pushing down vertically on the top portion of the player where all the buttons are - the metal casing will slide down and off . i actually took the belt clip off before i realized it didn't have screws hidden beneath it and i probably could have slid the case off without removing the clip .

Steps.Text_raw: Once I had the screw out it is a simple matter of pushing down vertically on the top portion of the player where all the buttons are - the metal casing will slide down and off.  I actually took the belt clip off before I realized it didn't have screws hidden beneath it and I probably could have slid the case off without removing the clip.

Lines.Text: there is a 2.5 cm x 1 mm pin that passes through the hinge spring - use your screwdriver push the pin out from right to left with clip facing towards you . once the pin is extruding from the left , you can grab it ( it is crimped so you cannot push it from the left side ) with pliers and pull it all the way through , releasing the clip and spring .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a 2.5 cm x 1mm pin that passes through the hinge & spring - use your screwdriver & push the pin out from right to left with clip facing towards you.  Once the pin is extruding from the left, you can grab it (it is crimped so you cannot push it from the left side) with pliers and pull it all the way through, releasing the clip and spring.

you can leave it there if you only intend to replace the battery with a similar one
post note : this speaker may have some sound benefits . also i had to replace the black membrane with a stiff plastic cover beacause the vibrations were hitting on the 18650-cell .

Lines.Text: unsrew the two scres on the side and twist the thing to get to the battery
its glued in place so with a little force you can remove it .
cut off the wires maybe in the middle or so . . .
if you want to or have one lying around you can solder a new similar battery to the terminals and you're done .

Lines.Text: there are some reasons , why i chose to use a new battery charge controller
1. i wanted a micro usb port
2. i no longer trust the original one
3. there is place for a new one : )

so i made slots for the charger ( it is a liion-battery-charger/protector ) to get it centered over the original usb-connector . you can move it back an forth because at this point you dont know the exact position . google it if you wand , they are about a dollar .

Steps.Text_raw: there are some reasons, why i chose to use a new battery charge controller 1. I wanted a micro USB port 2. I no longer trust the original one 3. there is place for a new one :) so i made slots for the charger ( it is a liion-battery-charger/protector) to get it centered over the original usb-connector. you can move it back an forth because at this point you dont know the exact position. google it if you wand, they are about a dollar.

Lines.Text: i grinded a bit off the front of the circuit-board so the the connector reaches further out .
pull the strap close an determine the final position by trial and error . then fix it with hot glue .
here i also made 4 slots to mount the new battery with straps an a slot behind the charger to move the board in the build in state .

Steps.Text_raw: i grinded a bit off the front of the circuit-board so the the connector reaches further out. pull the strap close an determine the final position by trial and error. then fix it with hot glue. here i also made 4 slots to mount the new battery with straps an a slot behind the charger to move the board in the build in state.

Lines.Text: to mount the new battery i used double sided tape and straps .
solder the new battery to the b+ and b- points on the charger
solder the out+ and out- points to the original battery connections on the board

Title: Dell DJ Front Panel Buttons Replacement

Lines.Text: disassemble the device . see the guide for further directions . slide the internal circuit board out of the protective device shell .
use the metal spudger to remove the device's center toggle button .
inspect contacts on the device . also , inspect the device buttons ( front and back ) for damage . damage may include broken or missing prongs that will interrupt the devices circuit .

Steps.Text_raw: Disassemble the device. See the [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Dell+DJ+Disassembly/56638|disassembly] guide for further directions.      Slide the internal circuit board out of the protective device shell. Use the metal spudger to remove the device's center toggle button. Inspect contacts on the device. Also, inspect the device buttons (front and back) for damage. Damage may include broken or missing prongs that will interrupt the devices circuit.

Lines.Text: inspect and clean device buttons with appropriate materials .
wipe down the circuit board and the buttons with a disposable wipe . then , use a cotton swab to remove dirt and grime in the crevices of the device .

disposable wipes designed for cleaning devices are most appropriate for cleaning device circuit board . other appropriate materials include : water dampened cotton cloth , microfiber cloth , cotton swabs , and disposable wipes made for electronic devices .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect and clean device buttons with appropriate materials. Wipe down the circuit board and the buttons with a disposable wipe. Then, use a cotton swab to remove dirt and grime in the crevices of the device. Disposable wipes designed for cleaning devices are most appropriate for cleaning device circuit board. Other appropriate materials include: water dampened cotton cloth, microfiber cloth, cotton swabs, and disposable wipes made for electronic devices.

Lines.Text: inspect the shell of the device before placing the button pad and center toggle back into the device .
look for cracks in the device's shell and identify whether the device shell is obstructing the button connection .
clean the shell thoroughly using a cotton swab into the creases of the the device shell . use a water dampened cloth to wipe down the device shell inside and out .
the center toggle ( circled in red ) button snaps into place . be sure the center button is placed in correctly .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the shell of the device before placing the button pad and center toggle back into the device. Look for cracks in the device's shell and identify whether the device shell is obstructing the button connection. Clean the shell thoroughly using a  cotton swab into the creases of the the device shell. Use a water dampened cloth to wipe down the device shell inside and out. The center toggle (circled in red) button snaps into place. Be sure the center button is placed in correctly.

Lines.Text: after the device is assembled , power the device on . the issue with the unresposnive/sticky buttons should be repaired .
if the device buttons are still defective , an issue greater than the device button connection is the cause .

Title: How to Repair a Scratched CD

Lines.Text: rinse the disc with water and wipe clean to remove any dust or dirt .

Steps.Text_raw: Rinse the disc with water and wipe clean to remove any dust or dirt.

Lines.Text: apply a rubbing compound , moving from the center of the disc outwards .
use enough force to create a mirror polished surface when rubbing compound application is complete .
we found that applying the rubbing compound for at least 30 seconds to 1 minute is sufficient .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply a rubbing compound, moving from the center of the disc outwards. Use enough force to create a mirror polished surface when rubbing compound application is complete. We found that applying the rubbing compound for at least 30 seconds to 1 minute is sufficient.

Lines.Text: let the cd sit for 5 minutes .

Steps.Text_raw: Let the CD sit for 5 minutes.

Lines.Text: wipe the cd clean with a new rag , removing any excess compound .

Steps.Text_raw: Wipe the CD clean with a new rag, removing any excess compound.

Lines.Text: apply a thin coat of car wax directly to the cd , using a circular application method .
apply in either small circular motions or large motions that follow the circumference of the disc .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply a thin coat of car wax directly to the CD, using a circular application method. Apply in either small circular motions or  large motions that follow the circumference of the disc.

Lines.Text: wipe the cd clean , removing any excess wax .

Steps.Text_raw: Wipe the CD clean, removing any excess wax.

Lines.Text: unplug and remove the power cord . turn the boombox upside down .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug and remove the power cord.  Turn the boombox upside down. Grip the sides of the case and use your thumbs to pop open the battery cover.

Lines.Text: pry out the batteries with your fingers .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry out the batteries with your fingers.

Lines.Text: turn the boombox upside down again . with the phillips ph1 or the flathead 3 screwdriver , remove the three 14 mm black screws .
remove the four 18 mm chrome screws with the phillips ph1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the boombox upside down again. With the Phillips PH1 or the Flathead #3 screwdriver, remove the three 14mm black screws. Remove the four 18mm chrome screws with the Phillips PH1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently remove the bottom half of the casing from the top half of the casing .
the antenna base is connected to the motherboard by a red wire . this wire will prevent the two halves from separating completely .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently remove the bottom half of the casing from the top half of the casing. The antenna base is connected to the motherboard by a red wire.  This wire will prevent the two halves from separating completely.

Lines.Text: remove the 10 mm chrome screw from the antenna base with the phillips ph1 screwdriver . remove the antenna base from the casing .

Lines.Text: unsolder the two wires at the given points . if you need help soldering , see guide .
the speaker has two colored wires attached to the orange plate : one attached to the positive ( + ) end , and the other attached to the negative ( - ) end .
the ''left'' speaker ( ''shown'' ) has a ''yellow'' wire on the positive ( + ) end , and an ''orange'' wire on the negative ( - ) end .
the ''right'' speaker ( ''not shown'' ) has a ''brown'' wire on the positive ( + ) end , and a ''red'' wire on the negative ( - ) end .

Steps.Text_raw: Unsolder the two wires at the given points.  If you need help soldering, see  [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|this guide]. The speaker has two colored wires attached to the orange plate: one attached to the positive (+) end,  and the other attached to the negative (-) end. The ''left'' speaker (''shown'') has a ''yellow'' wire on the positive (+) end, and an ''orange'' wire on the negative (-) end. The ''right'' speaker (''not shown'') has a ''brown'' wire on the positive (+) end, and a ''red'' wire on the negative (-) end.

Lines.Text: orient the ihome upside down with the speakers facing you .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the iHome upside down with the speakers facing you.

Lines.Text: remove the two 9.5 mm phillips 1 screws from the dock cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 9.5 mm Phillips #1 screws from the dock cover.

Lines.Text: remove the dock cover by grabbing its sides and pulling it up and away from the faceplate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the dock cover by grabbing its sides and pulling it up and away from the faceplate.

Lines.Text: orient the ihome upside down with the speakers facing away from you .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the iHome upside down with the speakers facing away from you.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws located on each of the four corners of the ihome's back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws located on each of the four corners of the iHome's back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the ihome .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the iHome.

Lines.Text: rotate the ihome so that the speakers are facing you .
disconnect the silver ribbon cable connected to the 30-pin connector ( the middle one ) by pulling it directly up .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the iHome so that the speakers are facing you. Disconnect the silver ribbon cable connected to the 30-pin connector (the middle one) by pulling it directly up.

Lines.Text: rotate the ihome so that the speakers are once again facing away from you and the motherboard is still exposed .
unplug the wide red/white/black wire bundle from the lower right-hand corner of the motherboard by pulling it out of their connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the iHome so that the speakers are once again facing away from you and the motherboard is still exposed. Unplug the wide red/white/black wire bundle from the lower right-hand corner of the motherboard by pulling it out of their connection.

Lines.Text: rotate the ihome ip1 so that the speakers are now facing you .
remove both of the speaker covers by pulling them off of the faceplate .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the iHome iP1 so that the speakers are now facing you. Remove both of the speaker covers by pulling them off of the faceplate.

Lines.Text: unscrew the twelve 14.5 mm phillips 2 screws holding the faceplate to the speaker housing . ( there are six screws connecting the faceplate to each speaker . )

completing this step will loosen the faceplate enough to pull the bundle of cables attached to the 30-pin connector through a hole in the faceplate , allowing the 30-pin connector to be removed from the ihome .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the twelve 14.5 mm Phillips #2 screws holding the faceplate to the speaker housing. (There are six screws connecting the faceplate to each speaker.) Completing this step will loosen the faceplate enough to pull the bundle of cables attached to the 30-pin connector through a hole in the faceplate, allowing the 30-pin connector to be removed from the iHome.

Lines.Text: detach the 30-pin connector from the dock housing by pushing it through the slot which it sticks out of .

sometimes the 30-pin connector can get stuck in the dock housing , making it difficult to push through . to prevent this , push each side of the 30-pin connector evenly . this step can be accomplished without the use of any additional tools .
the command buttons have been shown as removed to show how to detach the 30-pin connector . however , it is not necessary to remove the command buttons in order to remove the 30-pin connector .

Steps.Text_raw: Detach the 30-pin connector from the dock housing by pushing it through the slot which it sticks out of. Sometimes the 30-pin connector can get stuck in the dock housing, making it difficult to push through. To prevent this, push each side of the 30-pin connector evenly. This step can be accomplished without the use of any additional tools. The command buttons have been shown as removed to show how to detach the 30-pin connector. However, it is not necessary to remove the command buttons in order to remove the 30-pin connector.

Lines.Text: remove the 30-pin connector from the ihome by pulling the bundle of cables attached to it through the center hole in the faceplate .
you may have to wiggle the faceplate to be able to pull the bundle of cables through its center hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 30-pin connector from the iHome by pulling the bundle of cables attached to it through the center hole in the faceplate. You may have to wiggle the faceplate to be able to pull the bundle of cables through its center hole.

Lines.Text: orient the ihome upside down with the speakers facing away from you .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the iHome upside down with the speakers facing away from you.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws located on each of the four corners of the ihome's back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws located on each of the four corners of the iHome's back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the ihome .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the iHome.

Lines.Text: disconnect all five wire bundles attached to the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection .
the order in which the wire bundles are removed does not matter .
you may need to remove some black foam tape in order fully disconnect some of the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect all five wire bundles attached to the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection. The order in which the wire bundles are removed does not matter. You may need to remove some black foam tape in order fully disconnect some of the wires.

Lines.Text: unscrew the four 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws on the four metal brackets located at each corner of the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the four 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws on the four metal brackets located at each corner of the motherboard.

Lines.Text: unscrew the grey 6.0 mm phillips 1 screw directly above the red , blue , and green component ports .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the grey 6.0 mm Phillips #1 screw directly above the red, blue, and green component ports.

Lines.Text: remove the motherboard from its housing by grabbing it near its edges and carefully pulling it upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motherboard from its housing by grabbing it near its edges and carefully pulling it upward.

Lines.Text: orient the ihome upside down with the speakers facing away from you .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the iHome upside down with the speakers facing away from you.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9.5 mm phillips 2 screws located on each of the four corners of the ihome's back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9.5 mm Phillips #2 screws located on each of the four corners of the iHome's back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the ihome .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back cover by grabbing its sides and lifting it off the iHome.

Lines.Text: disconnect the white/black wires from the edges of the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection .
you may need to remove some black foam tape in order to fully disconnect some of the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the white/black wires from the edges of the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection. You may need to remove some black foam tape in order to fully disconnect some of the wires.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the glue attaching the wires to the housing using a metal spudger kit .
the glue is only used to keep the wires in place . it does not affect the function of the ihome .
if not all the glue can be removed at this step , remove the remaining glue after step 8 , where you can access the glue from the inside of the speaker housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the glue attaching the wires to the housing using a metal spudger kit. The glue is only used to keep the wires in place. It does not affect the function of the iHome. If not all the glue can be removed at this step, remove the remaining glue after Step 8, where you can access the glue from the inside of the speaker housing.

Lines.Text: rotate the ihome so that the speakers are facing you .
remove the speaker covers by pulling them off of the faceplate .
after this step , this guide only shows how to replace the left speaker . to remove the right speaker , follow the remaining steps as if they are mirrored .

Lines.Text: remove the four 12.0 mm phillips 2 screws from the edges of the speaker .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 12.0 mm Phillips #2 screws from the edges of the speaker.

Lines.Text: remove the speaker from the housing by gripping the rubber ring near the edge of the speaker and pulling it away from the faceplate .
be careful not to tear the rubber . once the speaker is loose enough , you can remove it from the housing by grabbing the metal speaker edges .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the speaker from the housing by gripping the rubber ring near the edge of the speaker and pulling it away from the faceplate. Be careful not to tear the rubber. Once the speaker is loose enough, you can remove it from the housing by grabbing the metal speaker edges.

Lines.Text: remove the speaker from the ihome by feeding the black/white wires through the hole on the opposite side of the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the speaker from the iHome by feeding the black/white wires through the hole on the opposite side of the housing.

Lines.Text: '''both speakers should be removed at this point . ''' if only one speaker has been removed , follow steps 12-14 of this guide to remove the other speaker .
disconnect the two red/black wire bundles located on the upper corners of the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Both speakers should be removed at this point.''' If only one speaker has been removed, follow steps 12-14 of this guide to remove the other speaker. Disconnect the two red/black wire bundles located on the upper corners of the motherboard by pulling them away from their connection.

Lines.Text: feed the red/black wires through the hole in the speaker housing through which they stick out of . do this to each of red/black wires you just disconnected .

Steps.Text_raw: Feed the red/black wires through the hole in the speaker housing through which they stick out of. Do this to each of red/black wires you just disconnected.

Lines.Text: orient the ihome so that the now-removed speakers would be facing you .
remove the black foam tape on the inside of the speaker housing that attaches the red/black wires to the speaker housing .
pull the wires out of the speaker housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the iHome so that the now-removed speakers would be facing you. Remove the black foam tape on the inside of the speaker housing that attaches the red/black wires to the speaker housing. Pull the wires out of the speaker housing.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the glue that attaches the red/black wires to the speaker housing adjacent to the tweeters using a metal spudger kit .
the glue is only used to keep the wires in place . it does not affect the function of the ihome .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the glue that attaches the red/black wires to the speaker housing adjacent to the tweeters using a metal spudger kit. The glue is only used to keep the wires in place. It does not affect the function of the iHome.

Lines.Text: unscrew the twelve 14.5 mm phillips 2 screws holding the faceplate to the speaker housing . ( there are six screws connecting the faceplate to each speaker . )

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the twelve 14.5 mm Phillips #2 screws holding the faceplate to the speaker housing. (There are six screws connecting the faceplate to each speaker.)

Lines.Text: remove the faceplate from the ihome by pulling it away from the speaker housing .
the 30-pin connector may not fit through the hole in the center of the faceplate . if this is the case , push the 30-pin connector into the dock housing ''before'' trying to remove the faceplate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the faceplate from the iHome by pulling it away from the speaker housing. The 30-pin connector may not fit through the hole in the center of the faceplate. If this is the case, push the 30-pin connector into the dock housing ''before'' trying to remove the faceplate.

Subject: Faceplate and Tweeters

Title: iPod Touch 6th Generation Display Assembly Replacement

Lines.Text: make sure you ipod is powered off before starting the repair
hold the sleep/wake button ( power button ) for about 3-5 seconds .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure you iPod is powered off before starting the repair Hold the Sleep/Wake Button (Power Button) for about 3-5 seconds.

Lines.Text: if your display is cracked to prevent you from cutting your self we recommend you place clear duck tape over the screen until all the cracks are fully covered .
wear safety glasses to prevent glass from from going into your eyes

Steps.Text_raw: If your display is cracked to prevent you from cutting your self we recommend you place clear duck tape over the screen until all the cracks are fully covered. Wear Safety glasses to prevent glass from from going into your eyes

Lines.Text: the bottom of the screen is held in place with adhesive .
use the iopener or heat gun to soften the adhesive
alternatively you can use an hair dyer
as you start to prying the screen off , you may need to apply more heat

Steps.Text_raw: The bottom of the screen is held in place with adhesive. Use the iOpener or Heat gun to soften the adhesive Alternatively you can use an Hair dyer As you start to prying the screen off, you may need to apply more heat

Lines.Text: place a suction cup just above the home button , towards the lower section of the glass .
press it firmly to ensure the cup has a strong seal .
hold ipod firmly on a hard surface
to prevent you from breaking the ribbon cables connected to the lcd , place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far .
start to lift the suction cup , and start to firmly pull constantly until the adhesive breaks , and the display comes up from the rear case .
when lifting the screen apart if adhesive is still sticking to the display you may get a razor blade to cut the adhesive .
'''be careful not to lift more than about an incha fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case . '''

Steps.Text_raw: Place a suction cup just above the home button, towards the lower section of the glass. Press it firmly to ensure the cup has a strong seal. Hold iPod firmly on a hard surface To prevent you from breaking the ribbon cables connected to the LCD, Place your thumb and index finger over the lower corners of the display to stop the display from opening too far. Start to Lift the suction cup, and start to firmly pull constantly until the adhesive breaks, and the display comes up from the rear case. When lifting the screen apart if adhesive is still sticking to the display you may get a razor blade to cut the adhesive. '''Be careful not to lift more than about an inch—a fragile plastic frame still connects the display assembly to the rear case.'''

Lines.Text: in this part we will be losing and freeing the bezel ( the plastic frame ) that surround the screen .
start at the top of the bezel , using a plastic opening tool , insert it into the gap between the plastic frame and the rear case .
slid to tool down the bezel to loosen it from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: In this part we will be losing and freeing the Bezel (The plastic Frame) that surround the screen. Start at the top of the Bezel, Using a plastic opening tool, insert it into the gap between the plastic frame and the rear case. Slid to tool down the Bezel to loosen it from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
initially this may not free the clip , but by repeating the procedure for each clip , it will begin to loosen the piece .
repeat the procedure with the next two clips on that side
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . be patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. Initially this may not free the clip , but by repeating the procedure for each clip, it will begin to loosen the piece. Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on that side You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Be patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: moving onto the left side of the bezel , insert the plastic opening tool into the gap between the frame and the rear case near the top .
now slide the tool down , loosening the frame from the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Moving onto the left side of the bezel, insert the plastic opening tool into the gap  between the frame and the rear case near the top. Now slide the tool down, loosening the frame from the case.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip .
rock the tool sideways , to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case .
initially this may not free the clip , but by repeating the procedure for each clip , it will begin to loosen the piece .
repeat the procedure with the next two clips on that side
you may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them . be patient , as the plastic frame is quite fragile .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the frame and the rear case behind the first clip. Rock the tool sideways, to spread the gap behind the clip and separate it from the rear case. Initially this may not free the clip , but by repeating the procedure for each clip, it will begin to loosen the piece. Repeat the procedure with the next two clips on that side You may have to go back and forth between the clips to free all of them. Be patient, as the plastic frame is quite fragile.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the ipod .
barley twist the opening tool to lift the front panel up from the rear case .
separate the display assembly from the ipod .
don't try to remove the front panel , because there are still many cables connected to it .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool between the display assembly and the rear case near the top of the iPod. Barley twist the opening tool to lift the front panel up from the rear case. Separate the display assembly from the iPod. Don't try to remove the Front panel, because there are still many cables connected to it.

Lines.Text: carefully fold the display over away from the rest of the ipod , watching out not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables . set the two halves flat on a flat surface
use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the lcd plate
you may need to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button . ( use a low heat setting )
do not try to remove the home button switch , because it is connected to components below the lcd plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully fold the display over away from the rest of the iPod, watching out not to disconnect or break any of the ribbon cables. Set the two halves flat on a flat surface Use a plastic opening tool to pry the home button switch up from the LCD Plate You may need to use a heat gun or hair dryer to soften the adhesive on the back of the home button. (Use a low heat setting) Do not try to remove the home button switch, because it is connected to components below the LCD plate.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the lcd plate to the rear case :
two 1.2 mm 00 phillips screws
nine 1.6 mm 00 phillips screws
one 2.3 mm 00 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the LCD plate to the rear case: Two 1.2 mm #00 Phillips screws Nine 1.6 mm #00 Phillips screws One 2.3 mm #00 Phillips screw

Lines.Text: lift up the lcd plate to remove it

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the LCD plate to remove it

Lines.Text: remove three 1.6 mm 00 phillips screws that are securing the logic board onto the rear case .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove three 1.6 mm #00 Phillips screws that are securing the logic board onto the rear case.

Lines.Text: there are two strips of adhesive holding the battery onto the rear case .
do not heat the battery ! !
turn the ipod to the '''back '''were you can see the apple logo and apply heat there to soften adhesive
the rear case does not have to be hot , you should be able to touch it without felling discomfort

Steps.Text_raw: There are two strips of adhesive holding the battery onto the rear case. Do not heat the battery!! Turn the iPod to the '''back '''were you can see the Apple logo and apply heat there to soften adhesive The rear case does not have to be hot, you should be able to touch it without felling discomfort

Lines.Text: there are three notches on either side of the battery . in the next steps , you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case .
the battery is secured with a lot of adhesive , so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery .
insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery .
don't try to attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point , just slowly start to loosen the adhesive at each point .
continue with the lower right notch . insert a plastic opening tool into the notch , and gently lift up on the side of the battery .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three notches on either side of the battery. In the next steps, you will be using these notches to gradually pry the battery up from the rear case. The battery is secured with a lot of adhesive, so you'll need to go slowly and carefully to avoid puncturing or creasing the battery. Insert a plastic opening tool into the top right notch and gently pry up on the battery. Don't try to attempt to pry up the entire battery at this point, just slowly start to loosen the adhesive at each point. Continue with the lower right notch. Insert a plastic opening tool into the notch, and gently lift up on the side of the battery.

Lines.Text: continue prying up the battery from the bottom .
when prying along the bottom , be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue prying up the battery from the bottom. When prying along the bottom, be careful not to press down too hard against the speaker or headphone jack.

Lines.Text: pry along the left side as well .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry along the left side as well.

Lines.Text: once all of the adhesive is loose , lift the battery up from the bottom and sway it out over the left side of the rear case .
make sure not to pull it out because it is soldered onto the logic board .
once battery is out of case turn the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all of the adhesive is loose, lift the battery up from the bottom and sway it out over the left side of the rear case. Make sure not to pull it out because it is soldered onto the logic board. Once battery is out of case turn the battery over to straighten its cable and set it down.

Lines.Text: get a spudger and use the flat end of it to take out facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a spudger and use the flat end of it to take out facing camera out of its socket in the display assembly.

Lines.Text: use the tip of a spudger to peel back a piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to peel back a piece of tape covering a screw on the side of the headphone jack.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws securing the headphone jack , lightning connector , and speaker .
three 2.6 mm 00 phillips screws
two 2.0 mm 00 phillips screws

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the headphone jack, Lightning connector, and speaker. Three 2.6 mm #00 Phillips screws Two 2.0 mm #00 Phillips screws

Lines.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to lift the speaker up from the rear case .
do not try to remove the speaker , because it is soldered to the lightning connector assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to lift the speaker up from the rear case. Do not try to remove the speaker, because it is soldered to the Lightning connector assembly.

Lines.Text: gripping the large ribbon cable , gently pull the lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Gripping the large ribbon cable, gently pull the Lightning connector assembly out of the bottom of the case.

Lines.Text: flip the entire assembly over , showing the back of the logic board .
use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the entire assembly over, showing the back of the logic board. Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the digitizer cable from the logic board.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to disconnect the display cable from its socket.

Lines.Text: flip the lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board .
the display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board .
use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Lightning connector/logic board assembly back over to expose the top of the logic board. The display cable is lightly adhered to the top of the logic board. Use the flat end of a spudger to peel the display cable up from the logic board.

Lines.Text: finally remove the display assembly from the ipod
you can use an ipod touch 5 lcd on the ipod touch 6 the're exactly the same .

Steps.Text_raw: Finally remove the display assembly from the iPod You can use an iPod touch 5 LCD on the iPod touch 6 the're exactly the same.

Subject: Display Assembly

this completes the battery replacement process . well done !

Toolbox.Name: piece of tape e.g. electrical masking

Lines.Text: place a small piece of tape over the lens . you need to use something with minimal stickiness . i used electrical tape . this is to protect the lens when you do the sanding .

Steps.Text_raw: Place a small piece of tape over the lens. You need to use something with minimal stickiness. I used electrical tape. This is to protect the lens when you do the sanding.
Tools_extracted: piece of tape e.g. electrical masking

Lines.Text: get some fine wet-and-dry sandpaper . i used p400 grade .
sand the area highlighted in the photo . be extra-thorough on the bits close to the spindle .
try to avoid sanding the spindle .
don't try to stop the spindle rotating - if you do accidentally go over it with the sandpaper a bit , you want it to move with the sandpaper , not offer resistance to it .

Steps.Text_raw: Get some fine wet-and-dry sandpaper. I used P400 grade. Sand the area highlighted in the photo. Be extra-thorough on the bits close to the spindle. Try to avoid sanding the spindle. Don't try to stop the spindle rotating - if you do accidentally go over it with the sandpaper a bit, you want it to move with the sandpaper, not offer resistance to it.

Lines.Text: blow the plastic dust away .
wipe the area you have sanded with a cloth that is slightly damp .
insert a cd that was previously rubbing , ideally the one that rubbed the most . don't close the lid . spin the cd manually using your fingers .
if the cd is now spinning freely , remove it from the player . gently vacuum the player , taking care not to touch the lens transport . remove the tape from the lens . now play your cds !
if the cd is not spinning freely but there has been an improvement , sand some more until there is no longer any scraping and then follow the bullet point above .
if you notice no improvement at all , it may be that the problem does not lie with the cd rubbing on this part of the player .

Steps.Text_raw: Blow the plastic dust away. Wipe the area you have sanded with a cloth that is slightly damp. Insert a CD that was previously rubbing, ideally the one that rubbed the most. Don't close the lid. Spin the CD manually using your fingers. If the CD is now spinning freely, remove it from the player. Gently vacuum the player, taking care not to touch the lens transport. Remove the tape from the lens. Now play your CDs! If the CD is not spinning freely but there has been an improvement, sand some more until there is no longer any scraping and then follow the bullet point above. If you notice no improvement at all, it may be that the problem does not lie with the CD rubbing on this part of the player.
Tools_extracted: piece of tape e.g. electrical masking

Title: Sony Walkman NWZ-E353 Navigation Key Replacement

Lines.Text: before you start , turn off your player .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you start, turn off your player.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two phillips screws on the back of the drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two Phillips screws on the back of the drive.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to pry on the edges of the drive .
once the cover is detached from the front panel of the player , be careful not to lose the volume key .
also be careful not to lose the small room below the hold switch ( see image 2 )

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to pry on the edges of the drive. Once the cover is detached from the front panel of the player, be careful not to lose the volume key. Also be careful not to lose the small room below the Hold switch (see image 2)

Lines.Text: remove the single phillips screw that holds the front panel and the interior components of the drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the single Phillips screw that holds the front panel and the interior components of the drive.

Lines.Text: the interior components of the reader are held by 4 plastic clips .
be careful not to break them by removing the display assembly , battery and the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: The interior components of the reader are held by 4 plastic clips. Be careful not to break them by removing the display assembly, battery and the motherboard.

Lines.Text: remove the 5-way navigation key .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 5-way navigation key.

Lines.Text: remove the rubber from the bottom of the speaker , use a medium blue plastic spudger to gently work its way under the rubber and slowly peel off for each of the three feet . the order does not matter .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the rubber from the bottom of the speaker, use a medium blue plastic spudger to gently work its way under the rubber and slowly peel off for each of the three feet. The order does not matter.

Lines.Text: remove the six 11 mm phillips 1 screws found underneath the foam to remove the steel outer metal frame .
once the screws come off , keep them safely off to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six 11 mm Philips #1 screws found underneath the foam to remove the steel outer metal frame. Once the screws come off, keep them safely off to the side.

Lines.Text: remove the metal frame gently and set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the metal frame gently and set aside.

Lines.Text: remove the two remaining 11 mm phillips 1 screws holding the base and set them aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two remaining 11 mm Philips #1 screws holding the base and set them aside.

Lines.Text: lift the base up gently keeping in mind that the base is connected with wires to internal parts of the speaker .
disconnect the white bundled cable connector attached to the charging node using a spudger . the base of the speaker is now free to be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the base up gently keeping in mind that the base is connected with wires to internal parts of the speaker. Disconnect the white bundled cable connector attached to the charging node using a spudger. The base of the speaker is now free to be removed.

Lines.Text: remove the white power cable connector that connects the charging node to the battery , using the plastic spudger .
pry the battery off using the plastic spudger .

Lines.Text: lift the base up gently keeping in mind that the base is connected with wires to internal parts of the speaker .
disconnect the white bundled cable connector attached to the charging node using a spudger . the base of the speaker is now free to be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the base up gently keeping in mind that the base is connected with wires to internal parts of the speaker. Disconnect the white bundled cable connector attached to the charging node using a spudger. The base of the speaker is now free to be removed.

Lines.Text: remove the white power cable connector that connects the charging node to the battery , using the plastic spudger .
pry the battery off using the plastic spudger .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the white power cable connector that connects the charging node to the battery, using the plastic spudger. Pry the battery off using the plastic spudger.

Lines.Text: pry off the mesh frame from the back side of the speaker with a plastic spudger until you hear a click noise when the clip is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry off the mesh frame from the back side of the speaker with a plastic spudger until you hear a click noise when the clip is removed.

Lines.Text: use a plastic spudger to remove the rubber grommets from the four corners of the speaker underneath the mesh frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic spudger to remove the rubber grommets from the four corners of the speaker underneath the mesh frame.

Lines.Text: remove the four 11 mm phillips 1 screws from beneath the rubber grommet that was removed from the previous step in all four corners .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 11 mm Philips #1 screws from beneath the rubber grommet that was removed from the previous step in all four corners.

Lines.Text: separate the mesh frame and plastic frame by placing the spudger in between them .
do not pull the two pieces since the two pieces are held together with the ribbon cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the mesh frame and plastic frame by placing the spudger in between them. Do not pull the two pieces since the two pieces are held together with the ribbon cable.

Lines.Text: remove the ribbon cable by pulling the black clip towards the cable , then gently pull the ribbon cable to fully separate the mesh frame and plastic frame .
the black locking clip will only move about 2 mm out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the ribbon cable by pulling the black clip towards the cable, then gently pull the ribbon cable to fully separate the mesh frame and plastic frame. The black locking clip will only move about 2mm out.

Lines.Text: remove the second ribbon cable that is connected to the main circuit board and the wifi adapter .
the black locking clip will only move about 2 mm out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the second ribbon cable that is connected to the main circuit board and the WiFi adapter. The black locking clip will only move about 2mm out.

Lines.Text: unscrew the five 11 mm phillips 1 screws found on the outside of the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the five 11 mm Philips  #1 screws found on the outside of the circuit board.

Lines.Text: lift the circuit board to expose the wifi antenna wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the circuit board to expose the wifi antenna wire.

Lines.Text: pry the glue and unclip the wifi antenna plug from the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry the glue and unclip the wifi antenna plug from the circuit board.

Lines.Text: remove the thirteen 11 mm phillips 1 screws from the perimeter of the plastic case .
remove the screws from the center of the plastic case as well .
lift the case up to expose the woofer , tweeter , and filter .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the thirteen 11 mm Philips #1 screws from the perimeter of the plastic case. Remove the screws from the center of the plastic case as well. Lift the case up to expose the Woofer, Tweeter, and filter.

Lines.Text: desolder the wires going from the woofer to the filter .
some tips on soldering can be found by clicking this link .
make sure to remember the orientation and color coding of the wires before desoldering .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the wires going from the woofer to the filter. Some tips on soldering can be found by clicking this link. https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750 Make sure to remember the orientation and color coding of the wires before desoldering.

Lines.Text: remove the two 11 mm phillips 1 screws holding the filter to move it out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 11 mm Philips #1 screws holding the filter to move it out of the way.

Lines.Text: remove the six 11 mm phillips 1 screws from the perimeter of the woofer .
gently lift the woofer from the plastic frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six 11 mm Philips #1 screws from the perimeter of the woofer. Gently lift the woofer from the plastic frame.

Lines.Text: remove the two 11 mm phillips 1 screws holding the tweeter bracket using a ph1 bit and screwdriver .
pry the tweeter from the plastic housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 11 mm Philips #1 screws holding the tweeter bracket using a PH1 bit and screwdriver. Pry the tweeter from the plastic housing.

Lines.Text: desolder the two wires leading to the tweeter .
some tips on soldering can be found by clicking this link .
don't forget to remember the color code and location of the wires !

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the two wires leading to the tweeter. Some tips on soldering can be found by clicking this link. https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750 Don't forget to remember the color code and location of the wires!

Title: Roku Streaming Stick Motherboard Port replacement

Lines.Text: grab the blue plastic opening tool to open the roku streaming stick 3500 r .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the blue plastic opening tool to open the Roku Streaming Stick 3500R.

Lines.Text: place the blue plastic opening tool into one of the cracks on the back of the roku to pop open the roku streaming stick 3500 r . be careful not to break anything while removing the back .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the blue plastic opening tool into one of the  cracks on the back of the Roku to pop open the  Roku Streaming Stick 3500R. Be careful not to break anything while removing  the back.

Lines.Text: once you have removed the cover , you can now access the motherboard of the roku streaming stick .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have removed the cover, you can now access the motherboard  of the Roku Streaming Stick.

Lines.Text: remove the motherboard by grabbing a hold of the micro-usb port , or you can also use tweezers to grab a hold of it and pull it out . but be careful with where you grab the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motherboard by grabbing a hold of the micro-usb port,   or you can also use tweezers  to grab a hold of it and pull it out. But be careful with where you grab the motherboard.

Lines.Text: once you identify the hdmi port and the micro-usb port , you can investigate to see which port may be damaged .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you identify the HDMI port and the micro-usb port, you can investigate to see which port may be damaged.

Lines.Text: once you have identified the problem you can then desolder the points at the hdmi as highlighted , or at the micro-usb ports .
if the soldering gun , or iron is set too high you then run the risk of destroying the motherboard altogether , or even damaging the wireless antennas .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have identified the problem you can then desolder the points at the HDMI as highlighted, or at the  micro-usb ports. If the soldering gun, or iron is set too high you then run the risk of destroying the motherboard altogether, or even damaging the wireless antennas.

Subject: Roku Streaming Stick Motherboard Port

Title: Roku Streaming Stick Battery Coil Contact Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the remote so that the buttons lay face down and then remove the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the remote so that the buttons lay face down and then remove the back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the batteries by compressing the spring .
this will expose the screw shown in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the batteries by compressing the spring. This will expose the screw shown in red.

Lines.Text: remove the screw using a phillips 00 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screw using a Phillips #00 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the face of the remote with the plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the face of the remote with the plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: using tweezers , remove the motherboard from the remote .

Steps.Text_raw: Using tweezers, remove the motherboard from the remote.

Lines.Text: the contacts should be present with one set being in the bottom of the remote casing and the other set being on the underside of the motherboard for the remote .

Steps.Text_raw: The contacts should be present with one set being in the bottom of the remote casing and the other set being on the underside of the motherboard for the remote.

Lines.Text: this step will require a soldering iron .
now you will have to remove the existing contacts by way of clipping the line of at an appropriate length away from the contacts .
now solder on your new connections on the board .

for the connections to the casing , you should be able to remove them with a little force . if you feel like you are using too much force , feel free to use a heat gun to eliminate some adhesive on the casing side of the contact .
finally , adhere the new contacts to the casing with a super glue like krazy glue .

Steps.Text_raw: This step will require a soldering iron. Now you will have to remove the existing contacts by way of clipping the line of at an appropriate length away from the contacts. Now solder on your new connections on the board. For the connections to the casing, you should be able to remove them with a little force. If you feel like you are using too much force, feel free to use a heat gun to eliminate some adhesive on the casing side of the contact. Finally, adhere the new contacts to the casing with a "super glue" like Krazy glue.

Subject: Battery Coil Contact

Title: Roku Streaming Stick Macro Button Contacts Replacement

Lines.Text: place the remote so that the battery cover is facing upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the remote so that the battery cover is facing upwards.

Lines.Text: remove the battery cover to expose the battery compartment .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery cover to expose the battery compartment.

Lines.Text: remove batteries .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove batteries.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 00 screwdriver to remove the 1.5 mm wide screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #00 screwdriver to remove the 1.5 mm wide screw.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool to gently pry apart the plastic enclosure . make sure you create a large enough gap before you attempt to separate the two pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool to gently pry apart the plastic enclosure.  Make sure you create a large enough gap before you attempt to separate the two pieces.

Lines.Text: gently remove the circuit board or motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently remove the circuit board or motherboard.

Lines.Text: first , gently remove the three plastic sheets . then , remove the button panels from the remote control .
repair the contact sheet as noted on the button contact repair kit listed above . otherwise replace with new conductive button contacts .

Steps.Text_raw: First, gently remove the three plastic sheets. Then, remove the button panels from the remote control. Repair the contact sheet as noted on the Button Contact Repair Kit listed above. Otherwise replace with new conductive button contacts.

Subject: Macro Button Contacts
